content.title: Faith and careful planning
content.introtext:
We should make plans - counting on God to direct us.

PROVERBS 16:9 TLB
Get the balance between faith and careful planning. You can't say, 'I'm gonna upgrade from my pay-as-you-go phone to the phattest, sleekest pay monthly on the market', if you ain't got the money. And none of that, 'The Lord will provide'. Is your network really going to send the bill to God? Give everything to God, yes, but not your sanity; you're given a brain for a reason. Walking by faith does not mean walking into oncoming traffic. Trust God to provide, but don't 'blow your budget'. Trust God for safety, but don't try to pull a wheelie round the M60! Trust God for your health, but don't chain smoke for England. Faith in God isn't a 'get out of jail' card; if you can't do the time, don't do the crime. 'Foolish dreamers live in a world of illusion; wise realists plant their feet on the ground' (Proverbs 14:18 TM).Wisdom says do all you can, then trust God to do what you cannot do. Faith and careful planning go hand-in-hand. Dream dreams but keep your feet firmly on the ground. If you want to be a worship leader start practicing your chords and scales. If you want to win the Olympics, put down that bag of Doritos and get out there training. God can do heaps if you've got the faith but He expects you to do your part as well.

content.title: Keep watch
content.introtext:
Keep watch...you do not know...what day your Lord will come.

MATTHEW 24:42 NIV
If you've ever gushed and blushed over Leonardo Di Caprio and Kate Winslet falling big time in lurrrve in the film 'Titanic', you'll know it all ends tragically as the 'unsinkable' sinks. I bet you didn't know that it could all have so easily ended with Hollywood heroics. You see, not far from where The Titanic was sinking, the ocean liner Californian, was getting a ring side seat of the whole event. The crew hadn't realized The Titanic's flares were distress signals. The radio distress calls were within range - except for one small detail. The Californian's radio operator had dozed off. So on April 12, 1912, without knowing what he was seeing, the liner's second officer watched the real Titanic sink! Jesus said: 'People were eating...drinking, marrying...to the day Noah entered the ark; and they knew nothing...until the flood came and took them...That is how it will be at the coming of the Son of Man...keep watch...you do not know...what day your Lord will come' (Matthew 24:38-42 NIV). As a Church, we don't want to be like the Californian's radio operator, having forty winks whilst the world around us is desperately sinking. As individuals, we don't want to be like the people in Noah's day, getting all lairy when big, big change is about to happen. So be warned; keep your eyes peeled, better still, keep your lives peeled!

content.title: Take the initiative (5)
content.introtext:
Be sure to do what you should.

GALATIANS 6:4 NLT
Any actor will tell you one of the trickiest moments in performing is getting the first line out. Will it be loud enough? What if your voice breaks mid-sentence? What if your mind goes completely blank? Once the play's rocking, the doubts seem to take care of themselves. Sometimes our lives can be a bit like that; we get too wrapped up in the nagging doubts that we stop ourselves from starting. We worry about the things that might happen tomorrow, or next week or in ten years time. James knew this: 'Look here, you people who say, "Tomorrow we are going to a certain town...We will do business there and make profit." How do you know what will happen tomorrow? For your life is like the morning fog - it's here a little while, then it's gone' (James 4:13,14 NLT). It might be that God eventually leads you to an Oscar for 'Alpha: The Musical'; it might be that God has plans for you smuggling Bibles into dangerous locations, but where have you been placed today? What's cooking on the menu now? The easier you can get to grips with rolling with what you've got now, the easier you'll get to grip with what God asks you to do in the future. So, wherever you're up to at the moment, work out your best use of time and get on with it.

content.title: Take the initiative (4)
content.introtext:
Make a careful exploration of...the work you have been given...then sink yourself into that.

GALATIANS 6:4 TM
Successful people don't need a fuse lit under them. Their driving force comes from their God-given purpose within. They live for a cause greater than themselves. If you want a blueprint in 'how to make your life stand up and count', check out what Martin Luther King Jr did. The United States had a terrible history of treating black people with no value and worth, unfairly forcing second class existences on millions of lives. Like an Old Testament prophet, Martin Luther King Jr took the initiative' becoming the voice of justice, the people's spokesperson, God's messenger. How did he do it? Not by fists, force or ferocity, but with the power of peace, the lesson of love and the grace of God. Half a century later it's easy to lose sight of the opposition King and his followers faced: they were handcuffed and beaten up, clubbed with sticks, water cannoned, jolted by jailers' cattle prods, many, including King himself, eventually would lose their lives. These history makers recognised the time to stand up and be counted, they used their lives to live out God's justice on Earth as it is in Heaven. Jesus said, 'It's who you are and the way you live that count before God...' (John 4:23 TM). Learn from the civil rights heroes; live for a cause greater than yourself. Take up the baton and run.

content.title: Take the initiative (3)
content.introtext:
Do not be afraid...The Lord...is going before you.

DEUTERONOMY 1:29-30 NIV
Two blooming well obvious things about initiative, and well you know it! 1) Just do it. Do you suffer from the 'six weeks holidays' syndrome? Remember, when your Maths teacher set you homework to do over the holidays, and week one you stayed in bed 'til dinner, week two you played on the PS3, week four and five were a bit of a blur, week 6... well, its your last week, you may as well enjoy it whilst it lasts! In fact, you let it slide and slide, and now here you are Sunday night before you go back with unfinished homework. Is that you? Does that attitude follow you whatever you do in life? The best way to get rid of something you don't like doing is; to do it! Take the initiative. 2) You've got to turn the engine on. People who take their driving test and give it their best shot may succeed, or fail. People who don't bother to turn the engine on, just fail. It ain't quantum physics this 'initiative' stuff; anyone who doesn't take initiative is guaranteed to fail! Solomon writes, 'If you wait for perfect conditions, you will never get anything done' (Ecclesiastes 11:4 TLB). It's better to be 80% sure, and start, than to wait until you're 100% sure, because by then the opportunity may have passed you by. Now, what are you waiting for?

content.title: Take the initiative (2)
content.introtext:
Act with courage, and may the Lord be with those who do well.

2 CHRONICLES 19:11 NIV
So you thought Moses was the only one who crossed through waters without getting so much as a little toe wet, did you? Crack open your Bible to Joshua 3. One of the last obstacles between Israel and the Promised Land was the River Jordan. But God had a plan. He told the priests carrying the Ark that when they stepped in the river, the waters would roll back. Let's talk 'initiative' again: 1) Nothing happens until you quit holding back! You can't wait for everything to be perfect. You can't wait until your butterflies go. You must take the initiative. Sometimes, it's only when we step out and move forward that things become clearer. Actually, many problems tend to take care of themselves once we have started to go with the flow 2) You've got to keep at it. The Jordan River didn't dry up the moment the priests stepped into it. God dried it up 26 miles upstream, so they had to wait till all that water passed by (Joshua 3:14-17). Why did God do it that way? Because He sees the big picture. God planned an opening wide enough for not just one or two people, but for a whole nation (more than a million people) to cross. Is there an obstacle between you and your Promised Land? Trust God, quit holding back, and keep at it!

content.title: Take the initiative (1)
content.introtext:
Look at an ant.

PROVERBS 6:6 TM
Sometimes we can spend too much time twiddling our thumbs waiting for the nod from God to go to China or Africa. Listen: being a missionary is not a career choice, we're called to be alert to God's work wherever we've been placed at any particular time. There really is no time or place like the present for knuckling down and doing the things that pleases God. John Lennon once sang, 'Life is what happens whilst you're busy making other plans'. I wonder how many opportunities from God you've missed in the moment because you've been busy making other plans. Don't waste a lifetime waiting for your big break; be alert to today and take the initiative. Solomon writes: 'Look at an ant...Nobody has to tell it what to do. All summer it stores up food...So how long are you going to laze around doing nothing? How long before you get out of bed? A nap here, a nap there, a day off here, a day off there, sit back, take it easy - do you know what comes next?...a dirt-poor life, poverty your permanent houseguest' (Proverbs 6:6-11 TM). He meant: whatever we do (or neglect to do) catches up with us. God has a brilliant future mapped out for you, but you don't live in the future, you live in the now. So how about making a difference now? Go on; take the initiative.

content.title: Make your money - His servant!
content.introtext:
Whoever loves money never has money enough.

ECCLESIASTES 5:10 NIV
Sure everyone needs a bit of cash, but don't let it take over your life. Three things that money aint: 1) a best mate. A wad of money might buy you a bit of bling, but it won't be a shoulder to cry on when you're hurting, it won't have you in stitches over the phone, it won't have a kick about with you down the park. Money can buy people, it can't buy friends 2) a ticket to happiness. So what would you spend your millions on anyway:a fast car; swimming pool for the house; pair of solid gold underpants? You'd soon become bored of your latest new gadget and toy. Jesus knows this, that's why He said, 'Life is not defined by what you have, even when you have a lot' (Luke 12:15, TM) 3) a comfort. Jesus told a story (Luke 12: 16-21) about a rich idiot who thought he had things sussed. He had so much stuff he didn't have enough room for it. Rather than being creative and kind with it, he decides to build bigger spaces to keep it all for himself. That same night he dies, so who ends up with it all? Not him that's for sure. The point is we end up with nowt when we fill up on ourselves rather than God. Bottom line: Aim to be loaded with God not cash.

content.title: Don't be a Diotrephes diva
content.introtext:
Diotrephes, who loves to be first.

3 JOHN 1:9 NIV
It's an old cliché, but you know when your PE teacher harps on about their being 'No "I" in team", well, they're right. Cristiano Ronaldo is thought to be pretty darn good at dribbling a ball, but if he was to face a whole team just by himself, he'd get nowhere. It doesn't matter how gifted he is, he still needs forwards to pass to, defenders to mop up mistakes, a keeper for a clean sheet - you get the picture. It's the same with us. Our gifts and strengths fit in with other people's gifts and strengths. The last thing you want in a team is a Prima Donna who refuses to work with others. The early church knew all about that: 'But Diotrephes, who loves to be the leader, refuses to have anything to do with us...Not only does he refuse to welcome the travelling teachers, he also tells others not to help them. And when they do help, he puts them out of the church' (3 John 1: 9-10 NLT). What a muppet Diotrephes was! He wasn't into team play, he was a diva. He wanted centre stage for himself. But 'stars' are insecure; they can't get beyond themselves to work with others. They stay weak in certain areas. Don't be a Diotrephes diva, use your talent as part of a team. Get connected. You'll go further with your church than without.

content.title: Character
content.introtext:
The Lord tested Joseph's character.

PSALM 105:19 NLT
If we can learn anything from Joseph it's that there's no gain without pain. Joseph is a textbook example of putting up with the pain and hanging in there with God. The story begins with a classic case of Golden Child syndrome. Jacob had many sons, but only Golden Child Joseph is given the now world-famous Technicolor Dreamcoat. This, understandably, miffed his brothers good and proper. Later, when he reports an arrogant dream he has had about them, things get rough for the golden one. His brothers leave him for dead, he's sold to people traffickers, then gets banged up in prison for a crime he didn't even commit, and he's pretty much left there, as everyone forgets all about him. A horrific chain of events sparked off all because he was a bit big headed and stupid as a teenager. Yet he hung in there, and that should give us all hope. Joseph's character was being tested (all the big headedness being booted out of him along the way), with plenty of occasions for him to get the hump with God, but as he keeps on in there his character gets refined. The story ends with all of Joseph's earlier dreams coming true, but that doesn't seem to be the point. The point seems to be that God wants more than to just do stuff through you, he wants to do it in you.

content.title: Stay in step with God!
content.introtext:
For we are...created in Christ Jesus to do good works, which God prepared in advance for us to do.

EPHESIANS 2:10 NIV
Any Strictly Come Dancing fans out there? Yes? Well, then you'll know the importance of keeping in step, not missing the beat, and moving in rhythm. Acts 17:28 says something similar; 'In him, we live, and move, and have our being'. The Holy Spirit is like our dance partner in life, laying down the beat, setting the rhythms, and moving us with grace. Once you start moving your feet in time to the Spirit, nothing is going to matter as much as keeping in step. When the Spirit moves, we move. When the Spirit pauses, we pause. When The Spirit acts, we act. The Bible puts it like this: 'live a life worthy of the calling you have received' (Ephesians 4:1 NIV), meaning: 'don't drag your feet, don't try and do it yourself, walk in step with God'. Any dancers off doing their own thing on 'strictly' are sure to be booted off the show; good movement is about being in tune with each other. Don't go it alone, only God can direct you in the best way for your life. Listen to His timing, its perfect for how you will move. In the film, Billy Elliot, Billy's dad wants him to be a boxer like him and his dad before him. But Billy knows he's cut out for ballet not boxing. Likewise, only you know (through The Holy Spirit) what God's cut you out for.

content.title: Spiritual sat-nav (2)
content.introtext:
He persevered because he saw Him who is invisible.

HEBREWS 11:27
Is God into nutters or what? 1 Kings tells the tale of a widow who lived during a famine, with only enough food to scrape together for one last meal. Yet she was nutty enough to share it with the prophet Elijah. Even though most of her must have been thinking 'I've not even enough for myself', her spiritual sat-nav whispered 'Give what you've got, God will give you back what you need'. She was right, God provided for her throughout the famine. And what about Mr. Nutty himself: Noah. He was the fruitloop who started to build the world's biggest boat bang in the middle of a desert, miles and miles from water, all because his spiritual sat-nav hinted at it. History is full of nutters, and it seems there's a fine line between nutty and genius: The Wright brothers were crazy enough to believe they could fly like birds, and set the blueprint for the modern aeroplane. Benjamin Franklin discovered electricity ; a genius then? Not when you find out how he did it; by flying a kite in a thunder storm (don't try this at home folks)! All these people trusted their instincts and acted on them. So yes, its official, God loves a nutter, or at least blesses them for their crazy ideas. What might God be showing you that others haven't seen? Check your spiritual sat-nav.

content.title: Spiritual sat-nav (1)
content.introtext:
Abraham Saw the Place afar off.

GENESIS 22:4
Girls, you'll understand this - you know when you go shopping for that certain, special something, that 'je ne sais quoi'....you're not quite sure what it is yet, but you'll just KNOW it when you see it! You'll just trust in your retail radar to carry you there. Well, that's what it's like with God sometimes. Listen: 'We have an unction [insight] from God and we know things' (1John 2:20 paraphrase). It's like God gives us spiritual sat-nav. Abraham had it when God sent him to a place he'd never even seen (read Genesis 22). But he still found it: 'On the third day Abraham...saw the place...' (Genesis 22:4). Sorted! There's nothing like the moment you see what you've been looking for and your spiritual sat-nav shouts, 'You have reached your destination!' When there's no way through ahead, sat-nav tells you before you get there. Have you ever noticed people who see things that are just not there. We call these people one of two things, a prize loon or a visionary (sometimes a bit of both) Visionaries usually end up doing the impossible. Why? Because they've learned to follow their spiritual sat-nav! Jesus followed His every day, through the garden of Gethsemane, all the way to the cross, into the grave and back out again! If He hadn't been tuned in the consequences are unimaginably bad. Thank God He's given you a spiritual sat-nav, learn to use it.

content.title: Mums are impressive
content.introtext:
As a mother comforts her child, so will I comfort you.

ISAIAH 66:13 NIV
Anna Jarvis was impressed with her mum. So impressed that after she passed away in May 1905 Anna began a campaign to get her accomplishments recognised. One thing led to another and within 3 years Anna and a group of friends had organised the world's first ever Mother's Day service. They thought it would be a pretty popular idea so they booked the biggest venue in town - it held 5000 people - but 15,000 showed up! That was exactly 100 years ago and as we now know the idea really did catch on. Pastor Chuck Swindoll thinks mums are impressive too: 'As significant as political, military, educational, or religious figures may be, none compare to the impact made by mothers. Their words are never fully forgotten, their touch leaves an indelible impression...the memory of their presence lasts a lifetime. I ask you, who else has that kind of influence?' He's right, nobody has the unique ability to shape a life more than a mum. Think about all the little ways over the years of your life that you've been shaped by that loving influence. Sometimes loving from close by, sometimes loving from a distance. At that first Mother's Day service Anna Jarvis showed she had a special window into a mother's heart saying, 'A mother's love is new every day.' So how are you going to show your appreciation for that love today?

content.title: Keep your dream alive
content.introtext:
Now to him who is able to do immeasurably more than all we ask or imagine.

EPHESIANS 3:20 NIV
Some dreams get you into trouble; like when you're caught daydreaming of Shayne Ward out of the Geography room window. Others are plain unrealistic; like when you dream that Pizza Hut have taken over catering in the school canteen. Then some seem plain 100% impossible; yet maybe God has placed this kind of dream in your head or heart for a reason. Strangely enough, it can be the ones that tamper with logic, that defy gravity, that scream 'CAN'T BE DONE!' that God wants you to chase. What's bugging you at the moment? What's waking you up at 3am every night with its bright wild idea? What tugs at your heart strings and plays a symphony of goose bumps on the back of your neck? Could it be a prompting from the Holy Spirit? Test it and see, ask God about it, share it with your youth group leader, do some research. Are you dreaming about mission work abroad? Find out about the country, what good organizations already work there. Are you thinking about University? Work at it, even if it seems impossible at the moment. Whether its taking up cross stitching, learning the guitar or bungee jumping from the moon (perhaps not such a good one), check it out before it dies out. When God gives you a dream, He leads you to the resources to help you. Ask God. Keep the dream alive!

content.title: Spiritual intimacy
content.introtext:
That I may...become more deeply and intimately acquainted with Him.

PHILLIPPIANS 3:10 AMP
How annoying are couples in lurrrve? They have one topic of conversation: each other. Yuk - their secret whisperings and in-jokes, their long dreamy stares into each others eyes, how they can finish each others sentences off because they know exactly what the other is thinking; somebody pass the bucket, please! Actually, you'd have to know somebody intimately well to do those kind of things. Imagine knowing God that intimately. That's what Paul wanted: '[For my determined purpose is] that I may know Him [that I may progressively become more deeply and intimately acquainted with Him, perceiving and recognising and understanding the wonders of His Person more strongly and more clearly]' (Philippians 3:10 AMP). What about you? Where's your relationship at? Imagine if your girl only ever phoned you when she needed your help out of a tricky situation, or if your boyfriend never said hello because he was always too busy; how shallow would that be? We'd never dream of treating our better half like that, yet sometimes that's how we can treat God. So here follows three quick lurrrve lessons to boost your relationship with God: 1) spend loads of time together. Chat, laugh and listen 2) share what's on your heart. Future, past and present 3) take the bad days with the good. Work at it, persevere. Get to know God intimately.

content.title: Faith in hand
content.introtext:
The Lord said..."What is that in your hand?"

EXODUS 4:2 NIV
If you've ever thought 'I wish I had what they've got', you've failed to grasp what you already do have. It's like once, when God asked Moses what was in his hand (Exodus 4:2), all Moses saw was the same old, scabby, walking stick he'd carried around for years. But, that same old, scabby, walking stick became the rod used to dry up a path through the Red sea! God can take something you've had all your life (which you've always thought of as scabby and old) and use it to do 'out-there things. All you have to do is have the faith to believe God can do it. There's nothing like a bit of faith. It takes faith to move home to a country you've never even seen; but Abraham did it. It takes faith to believe that by marching around like loonies in Jericho, walls would come tumbling down but Joshua did it. It takes faith to believe a stone in a sling shot could turn your nation into a mighty world power; but David did it. Faith is that crazy, out-there idea in your head, that believes this is not just a scabby, old walking stick, this is not just a slingshot and stone, this is in my hand for a reason. What is in your hand? Give it to God, see what happens?

content.title: 'Get over it!'
content.introtext:
In every thing give thanks.

1 THESSOLONIANS 5:18
What kind of a future would a murderer, known as public enemy number one, on the run, living in the back end of nowhere, have? Apparently a God filled one, as this pretty much sums up 40 years of Moses' life, and if God can use Moses, despite his well dodgy past, God can certainly use you. You see, sometimes with the past it's best just to get over it. Don't let your history haunt you; get over it! Don't let your hurts rent too much brain space; get over it! Don't take a round the world guilt trip; get over it! Paul writes, 'In every thing give thanks.' In everything? Surely not. Are we to give thanks when a close mate has stitched us up? Are we to be thankful when we're feeling desperately lonely? What about when the bottom has fallen out of our lives; do we say a big, cheesy 'Thanks' then too? Actually, something bizarre happens when we focus on the thanks despite how we're feeling. God meets us, and circumstances may not change, but our hearts do. God loves an attitude of faith. The Bible is full of stories of broken people in nasty situations who come out the other end of it doing pretty amazing things. Don't let situations give you a headache, let them get you closer to God. Give thanks, get God, and get out of the past.

content.title: Confidence (3)
content.introtext:
Do not throw away your confidence.

HEBREWS 10:35
Confidence is catching! It has a knock on effect. How many giant-killers were in Saul's army? None! When Goliath shot his mouth off, everyone bricked it. Yet David, small in size but massive in faith, knew what the big gob didn't have: God on his side. We all know the rest, David triumphed and later became king, but I bet you didn't know the knock on effect he had, check this out: '... then Sibbecai... killed Sippai, one of the descendants of the giants, and they were subdued. And there was war with the Philistines again and Elhanan... killed Lahmi the brother of Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like a weaver's beam. Again there was war at Gath, where there was a man of great stature who had twenty-four fingers and toes, six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot; and he also was descended from the giants. When he taunted Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimea, David's brother, killed him. These were descended from the giants in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants' (1 Chronicles 20:4-8 NAS). Now that's a firm you wouldn't mess with! You see, Saul had never touched a giant, so neither had his army. But David was fearless, so his crew was fearless. Why? Because confidence is catching.

content.title: Confidence (2)
content.introtext:
Do not throw away your confidence.

HEBREWS 10:35
Three ways to boost your confidence: 1) Don't put your faith in your threads. It's good to have image; it's essential to know you're made in God's image. You may feel useless but in reality you're priceless. Even if nobody else had ever been born, Jesus would still have died just for you. Why? Because you're worth it! 2) Bag yourself a good mate, bin yourself a bad vibe. Bad vibes bring you down saying things like 'you'll never do it', 'you're too young', 'you're too stupid', 'you're not good enough'. A good mate is like gold dust. A good mate believes in you despite the odds, building you up, ever ready to share the struggle - bag yourself a good 'un. 3) Quit comparing yourself with others. So you can't shake your booty like Beyonce or scissor kick like Rooney. Remember God's given you stuff that they could never do. There'll only ever be one you. Only you can achieve what God has planned for you to do since before the beginning of time. Maybe you don't believe in you, but God does and always has. You come fully endorsed by the creator of the universe. 'God doesn't want you to be shy with his gifts, but bold and loving and sensible' (2 Timothy 1:7 The Message) What more reason do you want?

content.title: Confidence (1)
content.introtext:
Do not throw away your confidence.

HEBREWS 10:35
Why do we think celebs are so special? Who gave them a double dose of confidence? Who put the kick ass in their attitude? Unlike us mere mortals, were they just born to do it? Actually, it's because they've got expensive PR people working behind the scenes, making them look good. Now, you probably don't earn enough pocket money to hire your own ace PR department, but don't worry, God is well up for the job. God's always working behind the scenes. Check this out: '... I have learned [during a lifetime of walking with God] the secret of being happy at any time in everything that happens, when I have enough to eat and when I go hungry, when I have more than I need and when I do not have enough. I can do all things through Christ, because He gives me strength' (Philippians 4:12-13 NCV). Paul didn't need some high flying PR guru working behind the scenes, he had Jesus working through him! Knowing that gave him the ability to handle everything that came his way. Confidence is taking your present situation; whatever's in your face, whatever's limiting your life, messing with your head or screwing up your dreams; and then facing the fear and giving it to God. If you think you can't cope, remind yourself who can by reading Philippians 4:12 -13 again.

content.title: Buff on the inside (3)
content.introtext:
God determined...the way to bring out his best in us.

1 CORINTHIANS 2:7 TM
Bobby Jones was winning golf tournaments by age 12. But he had a temper. His nickname was club-thrower. An older bloke called Grandpa Bart recognized Jones' talent and his character issues. He said. 'Bobby, you're good enough to win, but you'll never win big until you control that temper of yours.' Jones did master his temper, and went on to win his first Open Championship at 21. Grandpa Bart said, 'Bobby was 14 when he mastered golf, but he was 21 when he mastered himself.' One of the key ways to overcome your issues and grow that much-needed character is to have a clear sense of purpose. So, where do you find your life's purpose? By turning to what God has revealed about life in His Word. By reading about God working in the lives of all those Bible people we find amazing insights into how life works, we see what to avoid, and get clues about what to expect in the future. The Bible says, 'God's wisdom...goes deep into the interior of his purposes...It's not the latest message, but more like the oldest - what God determined as the way to bring out his best in us.' (1 Cor 2:7 TM) His best. That's what God is focused on for you. He sees you from the inside out and wants to help you get into tip top condition. It's true; God wants you to be buff!

content.title: Buff on the inside (2)
content.introtext:
The integrity of the upright guides them.

PROVERBS 11:3 NIV
A writer called Margaret Mead once stated, 'What people say, what people do, and what people say they do, are entirely different things.' She's talking about the need to have integrity and integrity is an essential part of being buff on the inside. The word integrity simply means 'to integrate, to become one with.' It requires having your values, thoughts, and actions all lined up not zig-zagging all over the place. Some people just want to make a 'good impression' but impressions are like shadows; they disappear when a strong enough light is shone on them. Integrity is the genuine article - the more you shine the light on it, the more detail you can see. People of integrity always stand out. Author Pat Williams tells of Gandhi's trip to England to speak before Parliament. The Government had opposed India's independence and as a result Gandhi had often been threatened, arrested and jailed. Gandhi spoke passionately for two hours, after which the packed hall gave him a standing ovation. Afterwards, a reporter asked Gandhi's assistant how he'd been able to deliver such a speech without notes. 'You don't understand Gandhi,' he responded. 'What he thinks is what he feels. What he feels is what he says. What he says is what he does. What Gandhi feels, thinks, says and does, are all the same. So he doesn't need notes.' Now, that's integrity!

content.title: Buff on the inside (1)
content.introtext:
[It is] better to have self-control than to conquer a city.

PROVERBS 16:32 NLT
You've seen 'em on the TV, stretching their superbly toned legs on the edge of the track. They're the world's top athletes and every single one of them is buff! You don't get to that level in a sport if you're carrying a pie-belly around with you. But just like getting buff on the outside means the right diet and lots of training - so does getting buff on the inside - building a strong character. An old Greek bloke called Plato said, 'The first and best victory is to conquer self,' and he was bang on. If you're serious about building strong character, set high standards for yourself and refuse to lower them. Need a role model? You won't find a better one than Jesus. He said, 'If anyone would come after me, he must deny himself' (Matthew 16:24 NIV). Every day look for an opportunity to say 'no' to yourself in some small area. Try it; it'll be hard but the payoff will come when you need to say no to yourself in some big area of life. Like saving for a rainy day, you'll have strength to draw on when you need it. Over 100 years ago Henry Parry Liddon observed, 'What we do on some great occasion will probably depend on what we already are; and what we are will be the result of previous years of self-discipline'; and that statement's as fresh today as it was then.

content.title: Self-control
content.introtext:
Do not let sin control the way you live.

ROMANS 6:12-13 NLT
Self-control is listed in the Bible as proof God's Spirit lives in us (Galatians 5:22-23). Without it your life is like a car without any brakes - it may be exciting for a while, but eventually you'll end up in a mangled mess! It's impossible to live a lifestyle of purity unless you're ruthless with those basic flesh-impulses. The Bible says, 'All your lives you've let sin tell you what to do. But thank God you've started listening to a new master, one whose commands set you free to live openly in his freedom!' (Romans 6:18 TM). Every day your body will send you messages that are likely to lead you off in all sorts of random directions. It's not that your body is evil, it's just that your mind is wired to respond to the signals it gets from the surrounding world; a world that's pretty messed up. One Bible boffin writes: 'Life on earth is really nothing more than a string of moments, one after another. And I do not want my testimony for Jesus Christ to be shattered by a single moment of indulging my flesh. I don't want one moment of rage or pride or lust to cast a shadow over a lifetime of walking with my Lord. Frankly, I fear that possibility. And do you know what? I want to fear that possibility. When I stop fearing it, I'm in grave danger.'

content.title: What's 'persevering'?
content.introtext:
Blessed are those who persevere.

JAMES 1:12 TNIV
On June 1, 1965, a 13-foot boat slipped quietly out of Falmouth, USA. Its destination? Falmouth, England. It would be the smallest craft ever to make the trans-Atlantic voyage. The sailor, Robert Manry, had been working for a local newspaper but felt 10 years at a desk was enough boredom for anyone. He was afraid, not of the ocean but of all the people who would try to talk him out of the trip. So he only shared it with some relatives and his wife. Out at sea He endured many sleepless nights trying to cross shipping lanes without getting run over by huge tankers. He had no radio and the loneliness led to hallucinations. His rudder broke three times. Storms swept him overboard. Finally, after 78 days alone at sea he sailed into Falmouth, England. Alone on the boat he'd dreamed about what he'd do once back on land. He expected to just check into a hotel, eat dinner, then maybe find out if a journalist might be interested in his story. Then came the surprise! While he was at sea word had spread. To his amazement nearly 50,000 people stood cheering him to the shore! One of the Bible's great themes is perseverance - it's what Robert Manry had. No matter how great your calling, your talent or your cause without perseverance you won't make it. 'Blessed are those who persevere.'

content.title: Money talk!
content.introtext:
Though you have built stone mansions, you will not live in them.

AMOS 5:11 NIV
You don't have to look far in the Bible to find mention of money. You won't find any Pounds, Euros or Dollars but the stories about both generosity and corruption weave in and out of the pages on a pretty regular basis. The message is loud and clear - God's bothered about what you do with what's in your wallet and He's also bothered about how it gets there. For example, in one bit of the Bible we hear God giving wealthy people a right rollocking for making themselves richer by making other people poorer (Amos 5:11-12) Sadly, by the time the church had been set up nearly a thousand years later it was still going on (James 5). Even sadder still, it's happening in our world today. In fact it's worse than ever. When you're choosing a career path for your life the temptation is there to go for the kind of job that will earn you the most money without asking too many questions about how that money is made. 'Well, when I'm making a big fat wad I'll be able to give loads to the church!' Does God really want dirty money? You might not have much cash right now because you might not have much 'earning power' right now, you need to get some qualifications and experience; but even so, make it your goal today to make God happy by earning a living the right way.

content.title: Marching to Zion
content.introtext:
The Lord has chosen Zion, he has desired it for his dwelling.

PSALM 132:13 NIV
Before David became King in Zion (Jerusalem), he had to live in three other places. Each place was a training ground: 1) At home in Bethlehem. David learned responsibility, to earn a living, to support his family, to develop his relationship with God, and to overcome the resentment of others because of God's favour on his life. At home you prepare to handle bigger tasks by being faithful in smaller ones. It's here that your character is developed and your trust is proven. 2) In the cave of Adullam. Living with the misfits and rejects of society David learned to give to other people without expecting anything in return; loving and serving even when his own life was under attack. Your Adullam is where God deals with your selfish motives. Sadly, some of us never make it out of this cave. 3) The Fortress of Hebron. The word Hebron means covenant or promise. It was one of the highest mountains in Israel and there was no easy road to the fortress city at the top; it was uphill all the way. And that's the thing about God's promises, they don't just come about accidentally, you have to push forward with determination to enter into them. So where has your journey taken you so far? Which place are you in at the moment? How close are you to Zion?

content.title: Teachability (2)
content.introtext:
Blessed is the man who finds wisdom.

PROVERBS 3:13 NIV
It's estimated that only one-third of all adults read an entire book after they leave school. Why? Because these people view education as a stage of life, not a way of life. Derr! Every stage of life presents lessons to be learned. Everybody has the choice either to be teachable and continue to learn, or to be closed-minded and stop growing. The Roman statesman Cato is an example of someone who made the right choice. He started to study Greek when he was 80! When asked why he was tackling such a hard task at his age he replied, 'It's the earliest age I have left.' Unlike Cato, too many of us see learning as an event instead of a process. Another reason that staying teachable is really important is because the things that make you may not be the things that keep you. You have to remain open to new ideas and new revelation. Locked in a Roman dungeon and facing execution, Paul wrote to Timothy and asked him to bring his stash of books (2 Timothy 4:13). It's like he's saying, 'They've locked up my body but my mind's still active - I still have so much more to learn' (2 Timothy 4:13). If Paul, not knowing if he was ever going to see the light of the sun again, was keen to keep on learning what kind of example does that give to us?!

content.title: Teachability (1)
content.introtext:
The discerning heart seeks knowledge.

PROVERBS 15:14 NIV
Besides being possibly the world's most amazing painter and sculptor, Leonardo da Vinci was a genius in every aspect of science too! His notebooks still exist and show how 500 years ago he was dreaming up submarines, helicopters and all sorts of other gadgets. In one notebook he wrote, 'Iron rusts from disuse; stagnant water loses its purity and in cold weather becomes frozen; even so does inaction sap the vigour of the mind.' He was driven by his desire to create and kept on learning and developing ideas until the very end of his life. The good news is, even if you don't have talent like Leonardo you can still go a long way if you have a Leonardo attitude. What was that attitude; Leonardo was 'teachable'. Teachability is the hunger to discover and grow. It's the willingness to learn, unlearn, and relearn. If you're talented, you may have trouble when it comes to being teachable. Gifted people sometimes act like they know it all and that makes it hard for them to keep developing. So remember, the most important skill to get is learning how to learn. Try this for the next week; ask people for their advice and deliberately keep your mouth shut when you feel tempted to chip in your own 'expert' opinion. Write down what you learn when you start being teachable by others. You'll be amazed!

content.title: Valentine's Day
content.introtext:
The LORD was grieved... and his heart was filled with pain.

Gen 6.6
Today's the day when a few people will feel very special and a lot of people will feel pretty miserable. One or two people will actually go as far as to send themselves a card so that when it arrives through the letter box everybody else thinks they've got a secret admirer! One way or another, Valentine's Day is an emotional day for everyone. Emotions are weird aren't they? Some people always have their emotions hanging out like washing on a line. Other people hide them away where nobody can see. One thing's for sure, God made us with emotions. The Bible's full of them! Your mind might jump to Psalms as the 'emotional' bit of the Bible, but feelings run right through it, and not just human feelings. Early on in the story of God and His creation we get the sense that when God made us 'in His image' (Genesis 1:26-27) it involved blessing us with His ability to 'feel'. That sets us apart from all the rest of creation. Yes, your dog might pull a sad face and whimper when you leave the house in the morning but Rover can't understand how it feels to get a Valentine's card, or not! Happiness, sadness, pleasure and anger are all 'gifts' from God, who feels all these things too. But most of all He has given us love, a better love than any human can give.

content.title: What's your danger zone?
content.introtext:
Run from temptations.

2 TIMOTHY 2:22 CEV
The ancient Greeks loved hero-stories. One of the most famous involves mysterious creatures called Sirens who lived by the sea. The Sirens sang songs so beautiful that passing sailors who heard it were hypnotized and jumped overboard to their death. The hero Odysseus ordered himself to be tied to the mast and the crew's ears filled with wax to block the music; that way they sailed past in safety. Clever guy that Odysseus! Maturity is about being aware of your danger zones and coming up with ways to avoid that danger. Paul said, 'If you think you are strong...be careful not to fall' (1 Corinthians 10:12 NCV). He told Timothy, 'Run from temptations that capture young people...do the right thing.' That's what Joseph did. When his boss's wife tried to get off with him he didn't a) get super-spiritual and try to convert her b) think, 'I'm young, lonely, far from home, and her husband's out of town; maybe just this once' c) hang around to see how strong his will-power was. No, he legged it saying, 'How...could I do such a wicked thing...against God?' (Genesis 39:9 NIV). The bottom line is this: when you're weak in certain areas you need to steer clear of anything that feeds into them. The Psalmist said, 'You are my safe refuge...where my enemies cannot reach me' (Psalm 61:3 NLT). So, what do you need to avoid?

content.title: When your enemy is your friend
content.introtext:
Friend, do what you came for.

MATTHEW 26:50 NIV
There's no pain like being stabbed in the back by a friend. But the truth is, God allows certain people into our lives to bring about His plans - even people like Judas, a person Jesus called 'friend'. Before Jesus was betrayed He told the disciples, 'I am not saying these things to all of you... this fulfils the Scripture that says, "The one who eats my food has turned against me"' (John 13:18 CEV). In a bizarre twist of destiny Judas' betrayal kick-started the sequence of events that led Jesus to the cross. You can't always avoid getting hurt. When some doors swing open all you see inside is darkness. Only when you get inside that darkness do you realise that the light you've been given is on the inside. Jesus isn't the only one who suffered like this. David poured out his heart: 'My best friend, the one I trusted...has turned against me' (Psalm 41:9 NLT). At times like this you need to know that God will never allow His plans for you to be wrecked by somebody else's actions. He may allow your Judas to go so far, but no further. And in the end, God loves to turn negatives into positives. None of us enjoys pain, but enduring it takes us to places that, taking the bright and easy path, we'd never reach.

content.title: Design and Destiny
content.introtext:
Everything got started in Him and finds its purpose in Him.

COLOSSIANS 1:16
Today's technology is designed to be more and more 'intelligent', but what if a DVD player could really think? Would it get upset, 'I really want to make toast today?' BONKERS! Design determines destiny. The one who made you also knows what you will be best at. 'So, how can I discover His destiny for me?' you wonder. Listen: 'It's in Christ that we find out who we are and what we are living for. Long before we first heard of Christ [He] had designs on us for glorious living, part of the overall purpose He is working out in everything and everyone' (Ephesians 1:11 TM). Notice three things here: 1) You only discover your life's destiny through a relationship with Christ 2) God determined your life's destiny before you existed; without your input! 3) Your destiny fits into a much larger destiny. Not too many years ago, a Russian novelist, called Andrei Bitov, was growing up under the heavy communist regime, but God got his attention. He recalls, 'One dreary day while riding the Metro in St. Petersburg, I was overcome with a despair so great that life seemed to stop at once, pre-empting the future entirely, let alone any meaning. Suddenly, all by itself, a phrase appeared: without God life makes no sense. Repeating it in astonishment, I rode the phrase up like a moving staircase, got out of the Metro and walked into God's light.' Are you settling for making toast when you're really a DVD player? Pray today that God, your master designer, would give you a glimpse of your destiny. 'Everything got started in Him and finds it's purpose in Him.'

content.title: Trouble and Trials
content.introtext:
When you have many kinds of troubles, you should be full of joy.

JAMES 1:2 NCV
OK, let's get something straight - there's a big difference between a) having 'many kinds of troubles' and b) getting into lots of trouble. You can't avoid the first category but you can avoid the second! God can, and will, use our mistakes to teach us, but enough trouble will come your way just from 'life'; don't go out looking for more! James describes 'many kinds of troubles' because usually it's not one big thing but a lot of little things. We have to deal with health trouble, money trouble, relationship trouble or emotional trouble, it all gets us stressed out. Peter helps to put it all in perspective for us though, saying: 'when your faith remains strong through many trials, it will bring you much praise and glory and honour on the day when Jesus Christ is revealed to the whole world (1Peter 1:7 NLT). There's nowhere we can go to escape the trial of our faith. Trying to avoid it is like changing your school so that you might not have to do that exam you're dreading. Well the next school will have exams too, probably harder than the ones in the school you just left, and by switching all you've actually done is get further behind in your studies and preparation. The Word 4U 2day is you can't outrun troubles and trials, but God is with you and He will strengthen you.

content.title: You + church
content.introtext:
We see it taking shape day after day-a holy temple built by God, all of us built into it, a temple in which God is quite at home.

EPHESIANS 2:22 TM
Yesterday we saw that there are times when we need to get one to one with God. But that's not the end of the subject. Like many truths in the Bible this is a coin with two sides. There are other times when we can only experience the fullness of God's presence as we get together with God's people. The place where this happens is Church. When people who all love Jesus gather together to worship, to praise and to share words of encouragement God's Spirit shows up in a powerful way. We grow together and move forward as we stir each other up with His Word. The world around us can be messy and confusing, stuff happens that leaves us feeling ragged and raw. We struggle and stumble and sometimes feel like losers, but when we gather with the big family called the Church we're reminded that we're on the winning side. Let's get real; it's hard to celebrate all by yourself! When you have something worth celebrating you text everybody an invite to the party so you can share the joy. Well Jesus is so excited about His awesome victory at the cross that He invites us every week (and even more often if we're up for it) to celebrate what He achieved for us. And celebration is a group activity.

content.title: You + God
content.introtext:
I sat alone because your hand was on me.

JEREMIAH 15:17 NIV
Having your mates around you is a great feeling - but being alone can be even better - when you're alone with God! In fact there are times when it's absolutely essential to make space for just you and God. The life of Jesus shows that over and over again: 1) 'Jesus often withdrew to lonely places and prayed' (Luke 5:16 NIV) 2) 'Jesus... withdrew by boat privately to a solitary place' (Matthew 14:13 NIV) 3) 'he went up on a mountainside by himself to pray.' (Matthew 14:23 NIV); God loves to clarify His plans for your life when there's nobody else around. That's because He wants you to be more influenced by Him, than them! When God's getting you ready for the next phase of growth He'll beckon you aside, away from the company of others. The great prophets of old new this. Elijah spent the night alone in a cave learning about the true power of God (1 Kings 19). Daniel 'was left alone, gazing at this great vision' (Daniel 10:8 NIV), and Jeremiah wrote: 'I sat alone because your hand was on me.' Learn to understand the difference between being lonely and being alone. When God calls you to spend time away from your mates don't treat it like a detention; it's a special honour! Learn all you can so that you're ready to be a world-changer.

content.title: Obstacles... what obstacles?
content.introtext:
Forgetting those things which are behind.

PHILLIPPIANS 3:13
It's impossible to reach your God-given destiny without overcoming your past. If you need inspiration to overcome your life's obstacles, look straight to Jesus. His national identity labelled him as part of a hated minority, people who faced prejudice every day. The stubborn religious leaders refused to listen to his message of love, instead they hounded him as a heretic. One of His closest friends betrayed Him to make himself wads of cash. Ultimately He was classified as 'too dangerous to live' and so was sentenced without a fair trial and died like the worst criminal. And what does He say about His suffering, and ours? 'But cheer up! I have defeated the world' (John 16:33 CEV). It seems like the only kind of party some people enjoy being at is a pity-party. And there's only ever one person on the invite list; yourself! Listen, don't waste your time and energy replaying things in the past that can't be changed. The past is over so get over it. That might sound a bit harsh but maybe today's the day you need to hear it. Make today the day you look forward. Get up and get on! God says, 'The plans I have for you...are...good' (Jeremiah 29:11 NLT). That means the best is yet to come!

content.title: Deep to Deep
content.introtext:
Let us worship God in a way that will please Him.

HEBREWS 12:28
In John, Chapter 4, a woman with a chequered past, tried to argue with Jesus as to the best time, place, and style for worship. But Jesus made it clear to her that these issues were irrelevant. Where you worship God isn't as important as why you worship God. What you get out of it isn't as important as what you put into it. Listen: 'His worshippers must worship in spirit and in truth' (John 4:24). Worship is your spirit responding to God's spirit, 'Deep calls to deep' (Psalm 42:7). Praise that isn't from deep down isn't really praise at all. You can have a lot of fun when you worship, which doesn't mean you don't take worship seriously. The best style of worship for you is the one that is authentic and enables you to express your love for God without denying your culture and personality. If God intentionally made us all different why would we all be expected to express our love for Him in the same way? There's no one-size-fits-all. You don't glorify God by trying to be something He doesn't need one more of. God wants you to be yourself! The Message Bible really explains this well: 'That's the kind of people the father is out looking for: those who are simply and honestly themselves before Him in their worship' (John 4:23 TM). If your worship is mindless, it's meaningless. Jesus called thoughtless worship, 'babbling' (Matthew 6:7). So watch out for biblical lingo, coz it can easily become tired from overuse. Be creative with your worship words. Expand your praise dictionary. Better to receive 2 specific compliments than 20 vague generalities. Dig deep and give God some creative praise today!

content.title: Your bodyguard
content.introtext:
I will protect those who trust in my name.

PSALM 91:14 NLT
Not long ago Volkswagen ran a TV advert that showed a city full of people going about their lives. Sitting on top of all the cars, and walking alongside all the pedestrians there are angels busily doing their job of looking after people, cleverly preventing them from having accidents. However, one angel looks bored, he's wandering around aimlessly getting funny looks from the other angels. Only at the end of the advert do we find out why; he person he's looking after doesn't need help because she's driving a Volkswagen Polo! People have some funny ideas about guardian angels and stuff like that but that's not the point here. The point is that God Himself takes a personal interest in looking out for you, even when you don't know you're in danger! Psalm 91 says: 'This I declare about the Lord: He alone is my refuge, my place of safety; he is my God, and I trust him. For he will rescue you from every trap and protect you from deadly disease. He will cover you with his feathers. He will shelter you with his wings. His faithful promises are your armour and protection.' (Psalm 91:2-4 NLT). These words flow from a heart that has found complete security in God. Yes, the Bible also makes it clear that life will get tough at times but even then there will be no safer place than in God's arms.

content.title: Laws for life
content.introtext:
Do everything written in it. Then you will be...successful.

JOSHUA 1:8 NIV
People in the Bible, especially in the Old Testament, often refer to God's Word as His law. Why? Well laws govern, guide, and guard us. Without laws all you have is confusion. Imagine living in a world where 100cm no longer makes one metre and 2+2 doesn't make 4. God's Word creates the boundaries within which the world works. When people start operating outside of the limits set by God's Word the result is chaos. Just flick to News 24 and see the proof! Once again we can find a lesson here from Joshua. At the time he was taking over the leadership of the nation from Moses, God spoke to him about His law: 'Do everything written in it. Then you will be...successful.' Did you get that, everything. God's laws are not like a McDonald's menu; you can't pick what you like and leave the rest. You have to have the lot! You can't just pick up your Bible and skim over the bits that sound painful or difficult. Paul says to Timothy, 'All Scripture is inspired by God and is useful to teach us what is true and to make us realise what is wrong in our lives. It corrects us when we are wrong and teaches us to do what is right' (2 Timothy 3:16 NLT) If your life is confusing and chaotic start living by God's laws.

content.title: Big Shoes (2)
content.introtext:
Be careful to obey all the law.

JOSHUA 1:7 NIV
Do you know the story of Alice in Wonderland? At one point she meets the Cheshire cat and asks him: 'Would you please tell me which way I ought to go from here?' 'That depends on where you want to get,' the cat replies. 'I don't care much where,' she answers. 'Then it doesn't matter which way you go,' the cat responds. People with an 'I don't care' attitude just drift through life like a ball of tumbleweed - they never really put down any roots and its impossible for them to bear any fruit. Joshua wasn't like that. He had a clear sense of direction. Let's take another look at his story. God said: 1) 'Get ready to cross...into the land' (Joshua 1:2 NIV). The frustrating thing about preparation is, sometimes it takes more time than the actual event you're preparing for. There's an old saying: 'You can claim to be surprised once; after that, you're unprepared' 2) 'Your territory will extend from...' (Joshua 1:4 NIV). You have to know the boundaries that God has set for you so that you don't step outside his blessing 3) 'Be careful to obey all the law...that you may be successful.' Our spiritual values are principles to be lived by every day. They give stability and structure to our inner world. And when that world is in order, we can step out and face anything - in our own shoes!

content.title: Big Shoes (1)
content.introtext:
I will never leave you nor forsake you.

JOSHUA 1:5 NIV
It's a bit of a weird saying isn't it 'filling someone else's shoes'? It's really just code for: 'Listen pipsqueak, so-and-so was a total living legend but to be honest you're a no-hoper'. When you put it like that the only shoes that are gonna get filled are yours - with poo! But this is the situation Joshua found himself in after 40 years serving as assistant to Moses the great deliverer, law-giver and best buddy of Almighty God. 'Do I have what it takes?' Joshua asked himself. God must've heard him because the beginning of the book of Joshua is filled with amazing words from the Big Boss to the new recruit. God told him: a) 'I will give you every place where you set your foot' (Joshua 1:3 NIV). God promises success to those who have the faith to take the first step, and to keep walking with Him.b) 'No one will be able to stand up against you all the days of your life' (Joshua 1:5 NIV). Expect opposition; people will try to get in your way but they can't stop God's promises! c) 'Be strong and courageous, for you are the one who will lead these people...' (Joshua 1:6 NIV). When the job feels too big and you feel too small don't be ashamed to ask God for a word of hope, He'll remind you of His calling so that you can stand in His power.

content.title: The key is in the Gift
content.introtext:
Giving a gift can open doors; it gives access to important people!

PROVERBS 18:16 NLT
We often talk about the way that God gives people 'gifts'. When we say this we're referring to certain talents and abilities that a person may have; for instance, you might be able make people laugh by the way you tell stories, but your sister might be a real brainbox. Different people, different gifts. But this Proverb is actually talking about gifts in the touchy-feely sense of the word, in fact, it almost sounds like bribery! Yes, your giftedness will get you noticed, and may give you a head start on others but you need to combine your gifting with generosity. How do you feel when someone gives you a gift? You feel special, right? You think, 'Hey, thanks, you noticed me.' Well, that's what this Proverb is getting at. Giving a gift to someone sends out the signal that you aren't only interested in yourself; you're a giver, not just a taker. Haven't you known people who had all the talent they'd ever need, but they never got the big break they deserved? Their talent made them stand out but their lack of generosity revealed their self-centredness. Who wants to give a big break to a person like that? Their talent might be able to push open the door, but their lack of concern for anyone but themselves slams it shut again. There's a reason they call Proverbs 'the wisdom book'!

content.title: He can make it up to you
content.introtext:
MY FATHER AND MOTHER WALKED OUT AND LEFT ME, BUT GOD TOOK ME IN.

PSALM 27:10
Most of us at some point have lost someone close to us. You might have had a close friend who moved a long way away, or perhaps someone close to you passed away before their time, or maybe your family has felt the pain of a divorce. Going through life without the hugs and support you need can make you really struggle and even find it difficult to understand who you are. When you grow up listening to endless arguments but never seeing affection, it's easy to think that's normal, then in a few years when it's your turn you can't help wondering 'How should I act as a parent, and why do I still feel like a lost child?' David said, 'My father and mother walked out and left me, but God took me in' (Psalm 27:10 TM). How about that! God can hold you and heal your pain. When you're hurting, you can get on His couch and He'll be your 'Wonderful Counsellor' (Isaiah 9:6). When you feel like an orphan, He can be to you an 'Everlasting Father' who doesn't abandon His kids, no matter what. With Him you're always safe and protected, because that's what loving fathers do. You're His child, which means if something's important to you, it's important to Him too! What's more, He can send people into your life who'll be to you, the father, the mother, the brother, or the sister you never had. Listen, 'God sets the lonely in families...' (Psalm 68:6 NIV). Don't be so focused on what you don't have that you miss out on having Him in your life making it better.

content.title: K to the I to the N to the D
content.introtext:
MAKE EVERY EFFORT TO [SHOW]...KINDNESS.

2 Peter 1:5-7 NIV
Have you noticed that the busier you get the meaner you get? That's because kindness (the opposite of mean-ness) is a 'fruit of the Spirit,' it grows in your life as you spend time with God (Galatians 5:22). Kindness doesn't grow as the result of listening to a good preach you downloaded from iTunes. You have to practice it. You have to do what Peter says: 'Make every effort to [show]...kindness.' One morning William McKinley was riding to his office on a tram. A sick woman got on and couldn't find a seat so she hung onto an overhead strap next to one of McKinley's political colleagues. Pathetically this guy hid behind his newspaper to avoid giving up his seat. Immediately McKinley gave her his seat and took her place in the aisle. Years later when McKinley had become President of the USA this same colleague was recommended for the position of ambassador but McKinley refused. He said, 'If his kindness is of the quality he showed that morning on the tram, I fear what he might do representing us in a foreign land.' The disappointed politician never did find out why McKinley chose someone else for the job. What good is it to be really busy if it's all to help yourself? Face it; without kindness what good are all our titles, traditions and testimonies? If you don't know the answer here it is: 'If I had the gift of prophecy and knew all about...the future, knew everything about everything, but didn't love others, what good would it do?' (1 Corinthians 13:2 TLB). So today, make up your mind to practice kindness!

content.title: What can you learn from this crisis?
content.introtext:
DO NOT THINK IT STRANGE CONCERNING THE FIERY TRIAL WHICH IS TO TRY YOU.

1 Peter 4:12 NKJV
Trouble never surprises God! Everyone He uses will tell you life is pretty much one challenge after another. Listen to how Paul describes the Christian life: 'In everything we do, we show that we are true ministers of God. We patiently endure troubles and hardships and calamities of every kind. We have been beaten, been put in prison, faced angry mobs, worked to exhaustion, endured sleepless nights, and gone without food. We prove ourselves by our purity, our understanding, our patience, our kindness, by the Holy Spirit within us, and by our sincere love. We faithfully preach the truth. God's power is working in us. We use the weapons of righteousness in the right hand for attack and the left hand for defence. We serve God whether people honour us or despise us, whether they slander us or praise us. We are honest, but they call us imposters. We are ignored, even though we are well known. We live close to death, but we are still alive. We have been beaten, but we have not been killed. Our hearts ache, but we always have joy. We are poor, but we give spiritual riches to others. We own nothing, and yet we have everything' (2 Corinthians 6:4-10 NLT). God never promised you that life would be a rose garden but did promise never to leave you, to take you through your storm and use all things for good in the end. When your faith is being tested it actually attracts God's power and brings His grace to your situation! Even Jesus learned through the things He suffered (Hebrews 5:8). So cheer up, you're not losing; you're learning!

content.title: The rubber band principle
content.introtext:
STRAINING TOWARD WHAT IS AHEAD, I PRESS ON TOWARD THE GOAL TO WIN THE PRIZE.

Philippians 3:13-14 NIV
All rubber bands work on the same basis; they must be stretched to be effective! Anybody who has ever achieved anything worth mentioning has been stretched to their limit. There are no exceptions. Loads of people make the common mistakes of thinking that success in life is for clever people or some 'special something-or-other' you just don't have. Well that's rubbish! Success comes when you're up for something, you give it your all and really let yourself be stretched to meet the challenge. Failure comes when you shrink back from it. Now, stretching makes you vulnerable; think about that rubber band when it's pulled really tight, there's always that chance it's going to snap. Is that why you're afraid to stretch? To go where you haven't gone and do something new? Don't worry; you're more flexible than you think! In life you'll always have critics. Jesus had them. And He said, 'No servant is greater than his master. If they persecuted me, they will persecute you also' (John 15:20 NIV). Here's a modern example of how the criticism process usually works: Dr Jonas Salk, who invented the vaccine for the terrible disease Polio, got loads of flak from other medical professionals who didn't appreciate for his pioneering work. He found that criticism came in three stages. First they'll tell you, 'It won't work!' Then when you begin to succeed they'll say, 'What you're doing isn't really important!' Finally, after they see that it's important they'll say, 'We knew you'd do it all along!' So don't worry that you're not good enough. Just make yourself available to God and let Him show you what He can do with your life.

content.title: You'll laugh again!
content.introtext:
THE LORD SAID TO ABRAHAM, "WHY DID SARAH LAUGH?"

Genesis 18:13 NIV
Have a little read of Genesis 18:13-14. In this passage we see God tell Abraham that his very old lady wife Sarah is going to have a baby. Not surprisingly Sarah did what any ninety something year old would do if someone said 'you're going to have a baby', she laughed her head off! God didn't really get what was so funny, especially when the following year, just as predicted she did indeed have a baby. After many years of desperation to be a mum and dealing with the fact that she couldn't have kids, when she popped out her son she called him Isaac which means, 'God has brought me laughter' (Genesis 21:2-6 NIV). There's a few things we learn from this. One is that God can do absolutely anything He wants. But another is a little deeper than that. Between the first and the last laugh Sarah went through a gut wrenching time of disappointment and heartache. Her hubby, Abraham, betrayed her to save his own skin and in the process a random King nearly ended up marrying her. Like Sarah you'll also celebrate good times and suffer some bad. Some days you'll feel like you can't go a step further, yet through it all you'll learn to trust God more than you ever dreamed possible. Here's an idea: when you share your story with other people don't just tell how you started or where you are today, tell them what God brought you through. The way God brings you through tough times gives Him as much glory as the good times, and chances are other people are having the same problems!

content.title: You can make a comeback!
content.introtext:
SAMSON PRAYED..."LORD, REMEMBER ME...PLEASE STRENGTHEN ME JUST ONE MORE TIME."

Judges 16:28 NLT
Have you ever read the story of Samson? It's worth a look. Here's a guy who has a massive weakness which seems to ruin him but in the end God uses him in a way few men have been. His weakness? A woman: 'She pressed him daily...and urged him' (Judges 16:16 NAS). Note the words pressed and urged. Be ready, your enemy will keep trying and all it takes is one moment of weakness to ruin everything. There are doors you should never open. There's an old saying that goes like this, 'Every morning in Africa a gazelle wakens and knows it has to run faster than the fastest lion or it will be killed. Every morning in Africa a lion wakens and knows it must outrun the swiftest gazelle or it will starve to death. It matters not whether you're a lion or a gazelle, when the sun comes up you'd better be ready to run!' Peter warns us to be alert because 'Your enemy the devil prowls around like a roaring lion looking for someone to devour. (1 Peter 5:8 NIV). Samson remembered God! It's pretty awesome thing when someone runs back to God, and as always God was there patiently waiting, arms open the whole time. Samson's last recorded prayer was from a prison cell, 'Lord, remember me...please strengthen me one more time.' Was his prayer answered? Yes, and his final moments were used to bring havoc to the enemies of God. Regardless of where you are today or what shape you're in, turn to God. He'll straighten out the crooked places in your life and help you make a comeback!

content.title: You're in His hands!
content.introtext:
AS THE CLAY IS IN THE POTTER'S HAND, SO ARE YOU IN MY HAND.

Jeremiah 18:6 NLT
Jeremiah was told by God to go down to the potter's house and see how he made his pottery: 'The jar he was making did not turn out as he had hoped, so [the potter] crushed it into a lump of clay...and started over' (Jeremiah 18:4 NLT). Sounds a bit harsh considering we're supposed to be like the clay. But, the potter crushed the clay in order to make something loads better out of it! Here's the good news: life may have crushed you but you're still in God's hands! Your family and friends may think you're a waste of space or beyond repair but God doesn't and His opinion is what counts. Your life may seem to be out of control today but in reality you're still on the potter's wheel - being stretched, shaped and moulded. 'As the clay is in the potter's hand, so are you in my hand.' One day a friend of Michelangelo saw him working on a piece of marble he'd found on a rubbish dump. When he asked Michelangelo what he was doing he replied: 'There's an angel inside and I'm going to bring him out.' How good is that? From a rubbish dump piece of reject rock to a priceless work of art. That's what our God does! Hannah said 'He raises the poor from the dust...To set them among princes' (1 Samuel 2:8 NKJV). You're not born qualified; you become qualified by spending time with Jesus. So stay where God has you today and let Him keep working on you. Tomorrow you'll be glad you did.

content.title: If you want mercy, show mercy!
content.introtext:
BE MERCIFUL, JUST AS YOUR FATHER IS MERCIFUL.

Luke 6:36 NIV
The award-winning writer Ernest Hemingway tells the story of a father and his teenage son who lived in Spain. Their relationship fell apart and the son ran away from home. After a few years the father began the long journey looking for his boy, and after a long time, he put an ad in the Madrid newspaper as a last resort. His son's name was Paco (a very common name in Spain). It just read, 'Dear Paco, meet me in front of the Madrid newspaper office tomorrow at noon. All is forgiven. I love you.' The next day at noon, in front of the newspaper office there were 800 Pacos all looking for forgiveness! Whom do you need to forgive today? Forgive them! You can't have a sorted relationship with God if you have a load of un-sorted issues with other people. Yes, people will hurt us, especially those we're close to. Letting go of hurt (especially when you've been wronged) is really hard to do, but not impossible. We tend to want revenge or at least for everyone to know what really happened. But when you won't forgive someone the truth is it's you that hurts. For one thing, you weren't created to carry the stress that goes with bearing a grudge! Indeed there's a mountain of medical evidence to say that holding onto resentment can actually destroy your health. If you think you'll ever need mercy, show it. Jesus said, 'Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy' (Matthew 5:7 NIV). Is God speaking to you about this? If so, deal with it today. Don't put it off any longer!

content.title: Can you see God's hand in it?
content.introtext:
THE LORD DIRECTS THE STEPS OF THE GODLY.

Psalm 37:23 NLT
Has something so painful happened that it's left you feeling scarred and a bit useless? Have you experienced people picking on things about you that's left you very sensitive and insecure? Do you find it difficult to trust people? Ever wonder why God made you that way? If that's where you're at today read these words: 'The Lord directs the steps of the godly. He delights in every detail of their lives. Though they stumble, they will never fall, for the Lord holds them by the hand' (Psalm 37:23-24 NLT). Do you believe that? Ask God right now to root those words deep in your heart. You see, God loves to use people who aren't perfect, which pretty much includes all of us! It's often hard to understand often why God made us that way, yet if you give Him time and a chance you're guaranteed a good reason. When people with big flaws are used for Gods glory, God gets even more glory because they clearly couldn't have done it by themselves. God loves to bless people with flaws they aren't arrogant like those people who think they deserve it. They're usually warmer and much more willing to give others a chance too. They understand that without God they never would have made it. Don't limit what you think you're capable of or what you want to do with your life - just because you're not perfect or not the best at something. God is capable of anything and if you're willing to be used, then you can't possibly begin to imagine the things he has in store for you.

content.title: A thankful heart
content.introtext:
I WILL BLESS THE LORD AT ALL TIMES.

Psalm 34:1
David said, 'I will bless the Lord at all times: his praise shall continually be in my mouth.' It may sound like a very sweet, Christian thing to say, but is it realistic? Absolutely! A thankful heart really should be a way of life. Did you know that a thankful heart can even save your life? When Jonah legged it from God then ended up in the belly of the whale he told God, 'I will sacrifice to You with... thanksgiving' (Jonah 2:9 NKJV). And when he did God gave the whale a dose of collywobbles and it spewed Jonah up onto the beach! When you're down in the dumps and all hell's breaking loose around you, that's when you need to raise your voice and praise God. When you can still praise God in a crisis, that's real faith. When your lips are full of thanksgiving and praise, even if you're not feeling it, this has a massive effect on your life and builds your faith no end. The reason we can walk by faith and not by sight (2 Corinthians 5:7), is because we know that whatever is going on right now, God is working on our behalf. David said, 'Magnify the Lord with me!' (Psalm 34:3). Praise acts like a magnifying glass; it helps you realise that God is much bigger than your problem. Nothing has really changed apart from your focus! Instead of sulking and moping about the problem, your faith is released and you start wanting solutions (we all like a bit of self-pity sometimes) and looking to God for them.

content.title: How to get out of the storm
content.introtext:
IN ALL THESE THINGS WE ARE MORE THAN CONQUERORS THROUGH HIM.

Romans 8:37 NIV
Yesterday we learned some lessons from Paul's shipwreck experience. Today let's look at getting out of one without losing everything! 1) Prepare for the storm before you get into it! The wise man built his house on a rock because he understood that life is never smooth, sooner or later a storm will come along (Matthew 7:24). 'For it has been granted to you on behalf of Christ not only to believe on him, but also to suffer for him' (Philippians 1:29 NIV). Being prepared for a storm will help get you through it. 2) Stay calm! Panic kills more pilots than bad weather because it clouds their ability to think. In the storm Jesus said to His disciples, 'It is I; don't be afraid' (Mark 6:50). Get your eyes fixed on Jesus and keep them there, otherwise your fear will take over and you'll be all over the place. If you're not looking to Jesus you're either looking at the problem, frantically searching for a solution or looking for other people to support you and sort things out. None of these are going to get you through in one piece like looking at Jesus in the first place. 3) Never abandon your purpose! They threw their cargo, the purpose for their journey, overboard. Don't do it! Never let go of the plans God called you to because it's these goals that will sustain you through the hard times. Later Paul would write, 'We know that all things work together for good...to them who are the called according to his purpose' (Romans 8:28). So be strong; the storm doesn't decide your future, God does. He's still in charge.

content.title: How to avoid a shipwreck
content.introtext:
YOU WISELY AND TENDERLY LEAD ME, AND THEN YOU BLESS ME

Psalm 73:24 TM
Your life is like a voyage. If you want to avoid a shipwreck read Acts 27:12 (NIV) and notice the following things: 1) They thought they knew best.
