Dry spells can be caused by: a) disobedience. He won't reveal step two until you've taken step one. If God's told you something make sure you are doing it b) being in a hurry. Samuel Chadwick said, 'Hurry is the death of prayer', so go for quality and content, not mileage! c) being in a rut. When your quiet time becomes a ritual instead of a relationship, it dies. So be flexible; change your routine, keep it interesting for you and the Lord d) not sharing your thoughts with others. When we give out, we get back more in return. Share your quiet-time thoughts with others and see what happens. If you're still not getting anything out of it, tell God about it. It takes time to develop a relationship. You must learn to see God in all kinds of circumstances in order to get to know Him well. So don't give up: 'Let us not become weary in doing good, for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up' (Galatians 6:9 NIV).

content.title: Your quiet time with God (3)
content.introtext:
O GOD, YOU ARE MY GOD, EARNESTLY I SEEK YOU.

PSALM 63:1 NIV
For the next few days let's deal with some 'quiet time problems.' Today we'll look at: The problem of discipline, also known as the battle of the blankets! It faces you the moment you wake up. Your body may be protesting at the thought of starting a new day; it's a battle to get out of bed. So here are some tips on overcoming this problem: a) go to bed on time. Too many of us stay up late watching TV or sitting on MSN and Myspace, so we have a hard time getting up in the morning. Dawson Trotman, a writer and preacher, lived by the Bible verse 'Early will I seek you.' Even if he had mates over the night before, he would excuse himself and go to bed because his top priority was meeting with Jesus each morning b) get up as soon as you wake up. If you lie there thinking about it, you've already lost the battle. When you wake up in the morning it's not the time to pray 'Jesus should I get up?' If you have to pray about it, do so the night before and pray that you'll have the willpower to do it. Resolve like the Psalmist, 'In the morning, O Lord, you hear my voice' (Psalm 5:3 NIV) c) go to bed thinking about Jesus. Fall asleep with the attitude of, 'See you in the morning, Lord.' Ask Him to wake you up with thoughts of Him. One of the best ways to do that is to go to sleep with a Scripture verse on your mind. 'Do not let this Book...depart from your mouth; meditate on it day and night' (Joshua 1:8 NIV).

content.title: Your quiet time with God (2)
content.introtext:
O GOD, YOU ARE MY GOD, EARNESTLY I SEEK YOU.

PSALM 63:1 NIV
A famous preacher said, 'I want to hear God's voice before anyone else's in the morning. And His is the last voice I want to hear at night.' David and Daniel met with the Lord three times daily (see Psalm 55:17; Daniel 6:10). Whatever time you set, stick at it. Put a reminder in your phone, pda, calendar; whatever! Just make a date with God and keep it! The question is often asked, 'How much time should I spend? Here are some guidelines: 1) Don't start with a two-hour quiet time. You might last a day or maybe two but then you'll get discouraged. You need to grow in your relationship with God like you do in any other. So begin with a few minutes and let it grow. 2) Don't clock-watch. That will ruin your quiet time faster than anything else. Decide what you can do in God's Word and prayer during the time you've selected; then do it! Sometimes it'll take more time than you've set aside, sometimes less but don't keep looking at your watch. 3) Go for quality, not quantity. It's what you do during your quiet time, whether 15 minutes or two hours, that's important. 4) Choose a special place. 'Next morning Abraham got up and returned to the place where he had stood before the Lord' (Genesis 19:27 NIV). Your special place ought to be a place where a) you can pray out loud without embarrassment b) you're comfortable; (don't have your quiet time in bed; that's too comfortable!). As the days go by your special place will come to mean everything to you because of the awesome times you have there with God.

content.title: Your quiet time with God (1)
content.introtext:
O GOD, YOU ARE MY GOD, EARNESTLY I SEEK YOU.

PSALM 63:1 NIV
When you come to meet with God you should check you attitude. Have you got: 1) Expectancy. Expect to 'give and get' from your time together. Expect a time of intimacy. It's impossible to have a love affair in a crowded public place; intimacy calls for being alone with the one you love. The Bible uses the example of the closest possible relationship when it talks about us and Jesus, the example of the Bridegroom and His bride. 2) Respect. Don't rush your time with God. Prepare your heart by being still for a minute before talking to Him. Deliberately clear away the cluttered thoughts of the day. Respect is reminding yourself with whom you are meeting; God! 'You are worthy...to receive glory and honour' (Revelation 4:11 NIV). 3) Alertness. God deserves your full attention so give God the best part of your day; when you are on top form. You might be a morning person like Jesus: 'Very early in the morning...Jesus...went off to a solitary place, where he prayed' (Mark 1:35 NIV) or you might be a night owl like David: 'On my bed I remember you; I think of you through the watches of the night' (Psalm 63:6 NIV) 4) Willingness. This attitude is crucial: you won't develop a deeper relationship with God if you've already made your mind up about what you will or won't do if He asks. Decide right now to do everything God wants you to do. Jesus said, 'If anyone chooses to do God's will, he will find out whether my teaching comes from God' (John 7:17 NIV). So, once again, check your attitude if you want to move on with God today.

content.title: Sweaty worship!
content.introtext:
NOR WILL I OFFER...THE LORD...THAT WHICH COST ME NOTHING.

2 SAMUEL 24:24 NKJV
Hard work = sweat! A long, long time ago when Adam and Eve were banned from the Garden of Eden they had to 'sweat to earn a living' (Genesis 3:19 CEV). Farmers sweat to turn their crops into cash, the same as bricklayers sweat on a building site or an executive sweats over writing a report for an important deadline. You tend to value what you have to work for and God values your efforts as well. That's why when David had the chance to offer God a sacrifice he said, 'Nor will I offer...the Lord...that which cost me nothing.' So what does your worship to God cost you? Not in terms of money but in terms of energy. This doesn't necessarily mean singing loudly and raising your hands in church (but it might). In-depth worship goes far beyond that. The word worship comes from an old Anglo-Saxon word 'worth-ship,' which is 'the act of giving worth or value to a person or object'. In the New Testament worship can be understood as serving, singing, showing proper respect, humility, love and generosity. That's right, even the offering bag at church is part of worship where you give back to God a tasty slice of the dosh He's given you. It's another way of honouring Him with the result of your sweat! When you sacrifice sleep to get up early and spend time with God, you're also doing something that costs you and when you go out of your way to help somebody in need, you're offering God something of real worth (see 1 John 3:17). So check your heart today and make sure you're giving God something of value.

content.title: Peace 'in spite of'
content.introtext:
YOU WILL EXPERIENCE GOD'S PEACE, WHICH IS FAR MORE WONDERFUL THAN THE HUMAN MIND CAN UNDERSTAND.

PHILIPPIANS 4:7 TLB
Catherine Marshall writes 'A king once offered a prize to the artist who could paint the best picture of peace. Many tried, but there were only two the king really liked. One was of a calm lake. It was a perfect mirror for the peaceful towering mountains all around it. Overhead was a blue sky with fluffy white clouds. The other picture had mountains too. But they were rugged and bare. Above them was an angry sky from which fell rain, and in which lightning played. Down the side of the mountains tumbled a waterfall. This did not look peaceful at all. But when the king looked closely he saw behind the waterfall a tiny bush growing in a crack in the rock. In the bush a mother bird had built her nest. There, in spite of the rush of angry water, she sat on her nest; in perfect peace. Which picture do you think won the prize? The king chose the second picture. Why? "Because"' explained the king, "peace does not mean to be in a place where there is no noise, trouble or hard work. Peace means to be in the middle of all these things and still be calm in your heart."' At some point we all discover that there's no safe harbour free from storms. At that point peace becomes even more special than we'd imagined because peace brings with it: a) the assurance of God's reality and protection right in the middle of them b) the growth of our faith and character because of them c) God's solid promise to bring us through situations stronger and wiser.

content.title: Are you being unrealistic?
content.introtext:
DON'T DO YOUR GOOD DEEDS PUBLICLY, TO BE ADMIRED BY OTHERS...

MATTHEW 6:1 NLT
When you do something for somebody expecting the favour to be returned, you're setting yourself up for disappointment. Jesus said, 'When you help someone...do it - quietly and unobtrusively' (Matthew 6:3-4 TM); 'Your Father knows what is done in secret, and he will reward you' (Matthew 6:4 CEV). There are certain things everybody has a right to, like basic respect but too often we place expectations on other people that they will never be able to fulfil. Then when they don't meet our demands we act hurt, when in reality it was our own misguided assumptions that caused the problem. A well-known counsellor says, 'Many of us have unmet needs from the past...we want others to fulfil our desire to be loved unconditionally...some of us are so needy we drive people away.' Couples can be really tragic at projecting on to each other things they need to work on personally. It's not fair to expect another person to 'fix you' or try to make them whom you want them to be in order to make you happy. That kind of behaviour just causes stress, arguments and an unhealthy dependency you'll end up dealing with later. Do you ever expect other people to read your mind when you haven't taken the time to spell out your expectations? How can you blame somebody for not doing something they didn't know you wanted?! Understand this: people aren't your answer, God is. If He chooses to use a certain person to bless you He'll do it; if not He'll use somebody else. So check your thinking today and ask God to reveal and remove any unrealistic expectations you're living with.

content.title: Can we learn about life from dogs?!
content.introtext:
I DELIGHT TO DO THY WILL, O MY GOD.

PSALM 40:8
Ruth Graham writes: 'Tonight I sit on the porch, our old German Shepherd dog lying at my feet. Thunder rumbles in the distance. As the storm nears, he tears into the front yard to meet it...furiously doing battle. As it passes he returns to the porch, convinced he has driven it away. He's a German guard dog carefully trained in search and rescue, attack and obedience. Search and rescue in these mountains can come in handy. I cannot imagine an occasion on which I would give the order to attack. But a well-trained dog can sense hostility or spot a weapon (even what resembles a weapon), in which case it's a wise person who freezes in his tracks. But it's the obedience training that gives real joy. To stop, to sit, to lie down, to go away, to search, to stay, to heel. A disobedient dog is not only a headache; he can be a liability. Obedience makes a dog a joy. Is it less so with God and His children? There are some I knew who have been trained in attack. We will not mention their names. You may know a few, but they are skilled at it. Then there are those trained in search and rescue. And there are those who have been trained in obedience. I think this, more than anything else, must give the Lord pleasure. Simple obedience. Joyful, eager, unquestioning obedience; to be able to say with the Psalmist, "I delight to do thy will, O my God," would be the height of training for the Christian. For this is what gives God the greatest pleasure.'

content.title: Practice self-discipline!
content.introtext:
FOR A SERVANT...DISCIPLINE IS NEEDED.

PROVERBS 29:19 NLT
Solomon said, 'It is better to have self-control than to conquer a city' (see Proverbs 16:32 NLT). So, how are you doing when it comes to self-control? Here are four easy steps to start making it more of a reality in your life: 1) Don't always do the easy or fun stuff first. You know the sort of stuff that typically gets ignored; making your bed, picking up your clothes off the floor, washing the dishes! And if you get sidetracked halfway through, make yourself go back and finish the job! 'Work hard at whatever you do' (Ecclesiastes 9:10 CEV). Plus, don't start several things all at once; do one thing at a time! 2) Discipline yourself to be punctual. Lateness is a hard habit to break. To beat it you must be brave enough to call it what it is; inconsiderate, selfish behaviour. 3) Plan ahead. Everything takes longer than you think, so don't wait 'til the last minute then rush around like a chicken with its head cut off. Living under that sort of constant pressure leads to being over-stressed but getting started early will mean you enjoy doing stuff much more! 4) Accept correction without sulking or getting defensive. The Bible says, 'Wisdom is found in those who take advice' (Proverbs 13:10 NIV). If you're wise you'll welcome honest feedback about your attitude. Ask God to help you control your unruly thoughts, feelings and behaviour. Identify unmanageable areas in your life, ditch the excuses, face the truth even when it hurts, refuse to feel sorry for yourself and set a few attainable goals. 'Learn to sense what is vital...and of real value' (Philippians 1:10 AMP).

content.title: Soul health
content.introtext:
I AM PRAYING...YOUR BODY IS AS HEALTHY AS...YOUR SOUL.

3 JOHN 2 TLB
We all know how important physical health is but here's a plan for your soul health: a) don't question your faith, question your doubts. Don't spend time dwelling on grey areas; God is amazingly colourful and that's where you'll find your faith! b) don't be a lone ranger. It's no accident that the Old Testament contains the story of God's people and that Paul's letters were written to congregations. We grow as we relate not as we isolate! c) guard your thought life. If your 'thinking is controlled by the sinful self, there is death. But if [it's] controlled by the Spirit, there is life and peace' (Romans 8:6 NCV). Practice a bit of mind management! d) give thanks to God before you fall asleep and when you wake up! It'll transform your week. 'In every thing give thanks!' (1 Thessalonians 5:18). e) ditch anything that distracts you from God. Toss out those gossipy magazines and if you've got the guts put the X-box back in its box for a few days! f) always choose the side of grace. Philip Yancey writes: 'I marvel at the humility of a God who descends to live inside...his 'flawed' creatures...Do I show that same attitude towards people of whom I disapprove?' g) don't be vague about your faith. Paul wasn't 'ashamed of the Gospel' (Romans 1:16); neither should you be. h) give a second chance to people who annoy you. God chose them too! Sometimes it's easier to be gracious to non-believers than to uptight 'churchy' people but that just makes you a different kind of judgmental. i) forgive those who've hurt you. Hatred hinders healing. So bring your hurts to God.

content.title: Growing in grace
content.introtext:
WEAR LOVE. IT'S YOUR BASIC, ALL-PURPOSE GARMENT.

COLOSSIANS 3:14 TM
A grandmother celebrating her golden wedding anniversary shared the secret of her long, happy marriage: 'On my wedding day I decided to make a list of 10 of my husband's faults, which for the sake of our marriage I would overlook. I never did get around to listing any. Each time my husband did something I didn't like I would say to myself, "Lucky for him that's one of the 10!"' She was a wise lady! Today's culture is obsessed with physical intimacy and the desires that bring you together but only God teaches the lessons in grace that will keep you together! Here's an idea that will help your relationship go the distance. When your boyfriend or girlfriend upsets you, instead of responding with angry words (or angry silence), stop and remind yourself that this is an opportunity to 'grow in grace.' Don't worry if you didn't do too well last time, you'll get another opportunity and probably pretty soon too and you'll keep getting them. Relationships are full of opportunities to be generous and opportunities to be forgiving. This awesome Bible verse ought to be framed and hung on your wall: 'Dress in the wardrobe God picked out for you: compassion, kindness, humility, quiet strength, discipline. Be even-tempered, content with second place, quick to forgive an offence. Forgive as quickly and completely as the Master forgave you. And regardless of what else you put on, wear love. It's your basic, all-purpose garment. Never be without it. Let the peace of Christ keep you in tune with each other, in step with each other. None of this going off and doing your own thing' (Colossians 3:12-15 TM).

content.title: Watch your ways!
content.introtext:
LET US EXAMINE OUR WAYS.

LAMENTATIONS 3:40 NIV
A lad rushed into a petrol station one day and asked the assistant behind the counter if the shop had a pay phone. She pointed to her right, 'It's just there.' The lad inserted his coins, dialled and waited for an answer. Finally someone came on the line. 'Uh, hello,' he said in a deep voice, 'Could you use an honest, hard-working young man?' The shop was quiet and assistant couldn't help overhearing... After a moment the lad said, 'Oh, you already have an honest, hard-working young man? Well, okay. Thanks all the same.' He hung up the phone and started walking back to his car, a broad smile stretched across his face. 'Hey, just a minute,' the shop assistant said, 'I couldn't help but hear your conversation. Why are you so happy? I thought the man said he already had someone and didn't need you?' The lad smiled. 'Well, you see, I am that honest, hard-working young man. I was just checking up on myself!' If you're serious about walking with God, check yourself regularly. Are you praying, reading God's Word and renewing your mind daily? How about your attitudes? Are they slipping? Your attitudes are like traffic lights that send a signal before you've said a word. Sometimes they flash red, which means 'stop, don't get in my way, I'm too busy to care about you.' Sometimes they flash yellow, which means 'I'm touchy and mixed-up, I could go either way.' Sometimes they flash green, which means, 'I'm ready to make time for you, you can count on me.' The Bible says, 'Let us examine our ways...and...return to the Lord.' What needs to be examined today? 'Our ways!'

content.title: Choosing your heroes...
content.introtext:
I'M...ONLY A MAN, NO DIFFERENT FROM YOU.

ACTS 10:26 TM
Role models inspire and motivate us, especially when they've been through similar things in life that we have. It's good to respect and appreciate them but the moment you set your role model up on a pedestal you're asking for trouble. Watch out that your inspiration doesn't become your obsession. Make sure that you keep your God-given uniqueness and don't become a carbon copy of somebody else. Remember, our heroes wrestle with character issues too. The Apostle Paul knew his limits and described himself as 'not...good enough to be called an apostle,' then added, 'God's grace has made me what I am' (1 Corinthians 15:9-10 NCV). The Apostle Peter even had to deal with people bowing down to him, 'The minute Peter came through the door, Cornelius was...down on his face worshiping him! Peter pulled him up and said, "None of that - I'm...only a man, no different from you."' Unfortunately some of the people we look up to aren't that humble! The danger in hero-worship is losing your individuality and missing the path God mapped out for you. Some of the lessons God teaches us may be similar but ultimately another person's purpose will be completely different from yours. For example, the cool guy in school takes Art so you do too. The problem is he can draw and you can't! There's a strange verse in the Bible that says 'God is...a jealous God' (Deuteronomy 4:24 NKJ) but it doesn't mean He's fussy or stroppy, it means He wants to protect us from anything that robs us of our uniqueness or threatens our relationship with Him. So make Jesus your role model and hero and then you're on safe ground!

content.title: 'Come and av' a go if you think your ard' enough'
content.introtext:
YOU PREPARE A FEAST FOR ME IN THE PRESENCE OF MY ENEMIES.

PSALM 23:5 NLT
In the old days, when a little village came under attack from another village that was stronger than them, they would go to the chief of a bigger town and ask them to fight against the army that was coming to pick a fight. If the chief agreed to help then he and the head of the village would make a covenant (a special kind of promise) with each other. It was vital that this was done for all eyes to see, so they would have a banquet together on top of a hill. By doing this it would become obvious to the opposing side that they were now comrades. Making this covenant was basically saying, 'If you mess with them, you mess with us too.' Did you know that when you say 'Yes' to Jesus you make a covenant with God?! A covenant is your special promise to God, that you will love and follow Him your whole life and His covenant to you is His special promise to love you, provide for you and loads more. One of his special promises is to protect you and fight for you in difficult times. Listen: 'You prepare a feast for me in the presence of my enemies.' So next time the enemy has a pop at you, remind him who you are in covenant with and watch him do a runner. Remember that your heavenly Father is not just the chief of some town or city or even nation; He's the awesome God of the whole universe and He won't stand for any one messing with His mates!

content.title: You are significant
content.introtext:
WHOSE WEAKNESS WAS TURNED TO STRENGTH.

HEBREWS 11:34 NIV
Joni Eareckson Tada tells the story 'Every morning Connie opens Diane's door to begin the long routine of exercising and bathing her paralyzed friend. The sun's rays slant through the blinds, washing the room in a golden glow. The folds of the covers haven't moved since Connie pulled them up around Diane the night before. Yet she can tell her friend has been awake for awhile. 'Are you ready to get up yet?' 'No...not yet,' comes the weak reply from under the covers. Connie sighs, smiles and clicks shut the door. The story is the same every new day at Connie and Diane's apartment. Sunrise stretches into mid-morning by the time Diane is ready to sit up in her wheel chair. But those long hours in bed are significant. In her quiet sanctuary Diane turns her head slightly on the pillow, toward the corkboard on the wall. Her eyes scan each photo. Every torn piece of paper carefully pinned in a row. She's praying. The creeping limitations of multiple sclerosis encroach further each year. Her fingers are curled and rigid. Her voice is barely a whisper. People might look at her and say, 'What a shame. Her life has no meaning.' But Diane is convinced that her life is significant; that her labour of prayer counts. She moves mountains that block the paths of missionaries; helps open the eyes of the spiritually blind in Southeast Asia, pushes back the kingdom of darkness that blackens the alleys of the gangs in East Los Angeles Diane is on the front lines, advancing the Kingdom of God. This woman sees her place in the world. It doesn't matter that others may not recognize her significance, she is a child of the King'

content.title: Love the unlovable
content.introtext:
LOVE...ALWAYS LOOKS FOR THE BEST.

1 CORINTHIANS 13:4&7 TM
Love is a funny thing. There are so many different opinions flying around about what love really is and how to know when you've fallen in love with someone. Did you know that love comes in many forms? There is the friendship kind of love that you feel for your friends and family. Then there is the romantic love that you may feel for a particular person (and hopefully they feel it for you too!). In the Bible Jesus also talks about loving your enemies (Matthew 5:44). That can be so hard and a real challenge. How are you supposed to love someone who does your head in and makes your life miserable? Start by praying for them. Prayer is powerful! If you pray for the person who annoys you and ask God to bless them and if you make a choice to only say nice things about them then gradually you will experience a change of heart towards them. You might not end up being best mates but the anger and negativity you felt towards them will melt away. Try it, prayer works! Jesus says, 'If all you do is love the lovable, do you expect a bonus? Anybody can do that' (Matthew 5:47 TM). God wants us to represent Him on earth and He loves everybody, despite whether they love Him back. So we need to try and love all people. Not with a soppy romantic love but with a supernatural love that comes from God; it's a love that never comes to an end and always looks for the good in people (1 Corinthians 13: 4-13).

content.title: Sheep Poo to Shiny Crown
content.introtext:
MEN AND WOMEN LOOK AT THE FACE; GOD LOOKS INTO THE HEART.

1 SAM 16:7 TM
King David wasn't born with a crown on his head and a load of people around him waiting to peel him a grape! He was the youngest of eight brothers; they were good looking, trained fighters and much more obvious choices as potential king material. No way would anyone even take a look at some scrawny shepherd boy, with sheep poo between his toes and a sling over his shoulder but God saw deeper qualities that weren't immediately obvious. His passionate and courageous heart made him God's perfect candidate to rule over Israel. That meant it didn't matter what other people thought; he was God's choice for the job! When the prophet Samuel came to anoint David as king, God said to him, 'Looks aren't everything...God judges persons differently than humans do. Men and women look at the face; God looks into the heart.' You only have to pick up a magazine and it's obvious that people are obsessed with image. The pressure to look perfect is pushed in our faces every time we turn on the TV. The fact is that God isn't looking to see if you have the latest Gucci sunglasses or Armani jeans before He'll pick you to be part of His group. He has hand picked you for a fantastic adventure and all He is bothered about is that your heart loves Him 100%. Before David was handed his crown he learnt how to be a happy being a shepherd and before anything else, to love God with his whole heart!

content.title: Admit it! Quit it! Forget it!
content.introtext:
FORGETTING THE PAST AND LOOKING FORWARD TO WHAT LIES AHEAD...

PHILIPPIANS 3:13 NLT
What do people mean when they say, 'Oh; forget about it'? You can't exactly choose to forget something can you? In fact because of the way the brain works, if you try to forget something you're more likely to remember it! No, 'forget about it' doesn't mean losing awareness of what happened, it just means let go of it. So what do you need to forget about or let go of? Maybe someone hurt you. So forgive them. If you're the cause of someone else's pain, make a choice to stop it and ask God to forgive you. Then you need to forgive yourself. Paul had it nailed, listen: 'Forgetting the past and looking forward to what lies ahead, I press on to reach the end of the race and receive the heavenly prize' (Philippians 3:13). Paul understood that if he dwelled on the mistakes he'd made and the trials he went through he would spend his life feeling like a failure. That's pointless! In an interview famous tennis player, Andre Agassi was asked what the key was to competing successfully. He said that every point he played he played it like it was his first. He disciplined himself not to focus on the last point; no matter how good it was. If he focused on that he might fall into the trap of pride and get sloppy in his game. If he focused on the bad points he would fear another mistake. So if someone hurts you, make a choice to forgive and move on. You'll soon realise that to forgive and not dwell on the past will make you feel happy and really free of any pain!

content.title: Stop Running Away
content.introtext:
JONAH GOT UP AND WENT IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION TO GET AWAY FROM THE LORD.

JONAH 1:3 NLT
Jonah was a good bloke, he loved God and wanted to do what God asked Him to; until one day God spoke to Jonah and told him to go on a preaching tour in a big, bad city called Nineveh. Now when God said that, Jonah had a funny reaction. Instead of saying, 'OK God, off I go to Nineveh,' he jumped on a boat and went in the opposite direction! A storm came; the sailors panicked and chucked Jonah over board thinking he was cursed. Harsh! If that wasn't enough Jonah then gets swallowed by a massive fish and spends the next three days sitting in its guts. Wow, talk about making a bad choice! It takes all of this for Jonah to realise it's better to do God's will than to run away from it. So often God asks us to do something and because we get afraid of looking stupid we run away or try and ignore God. The fish eventually puked Jonah onto a beach. Rather wisely Jonah didn't run away from his calling a second time, no, he went to Nineveh and did what God said and because of that an entire city was saved from destruction! So even though Jonah may not have been the most popular bloke in the city preaching his message of doom and gloom, he was obedient to God. That always makes more of a statement than going along with the crowd. Don't be afraid to stand up for what you believe in and do what God asks. You never know who might be saved because of you.

content.title: What have you got in your hands?
content.introtext:
OTHERS GAVE WHAT THEY'LL NEVER MISS...SHE GAVE HER ALL.

MARK 12:44 TM
Did you know that Jesus is the master of making a little go a long way? He fed five thousand people with five loaves and two fish; he turned six huge jars of water into gallons and gallons of wine and made money come out of a fish to pay the local taxman! What's that about? It's amazing to think that Jesus Christ the Saviour of the world wants to spend time with you! Not only that, He wants to take hold of your gifting and talents and make them grow and grow. All you need to do is be available. So just how do you make yourself available to God? Start by saying to Him, 'God, I know I don't have much to offer You, but what I do have, I want You to take and make into something awesome. I want what I do to count; but I know it will only count if You are number one in my life.' In the Bible Jesus bigged up a widow because she gives her last two pennies away out of her love for God. He thought it was so cool that He even pointed her out to His disciples, 'Others gave what they'll never miss...she gave her all' (Mark 12:44 TM). If you are willing to give your 'all' to God, you'll be amazed at the amount He produces out of what you have given to Him. Whether it's your time, talents or money God is looking for a heart that is willing to be used in the great adventure of building His kingdom. Are you willing today?

content.title: Hold on to His Promises
content.introtext:
I HAVE MADE YOU A FATHER OF MANY NATIONS.

GENESIS 17:5 NIV
The things you choose to spend your money on really show what you value; and in some cases what you love. You might hate having to save up for stuff; after all it's a buzz to get what we want fast and with no effort involved! If, like most people, you have to save up to get that Nintendo Wii or the latest mobile phone, you will probably value it and be more grateful for it than you would be if it just arrived out of the blue without any sacrifice. Anything you've had to work hard for will have greater value to you than something you got in five minutes. That can be a hard lesson to learn sometimes but if you look in the Bible at the lives of some of some of the greatest people they started out with a promise from God and had to hold onto that promise for years, until they saw what God had promised happen. God said to Abraham, 'I have made you a father of many nations.' He said it when Abraham and his wife were really old and had no kids! But even though Abraham was flippin' ancient, he held onto God's promise and at the ripe old age of about 102 Abraham became the father of Isaac and so started the family line that led to the birth of Jesus and because of Jesus, millions believe in God today...so God's promise to Abraham came true...even though he had to wait a while. So don't worry if God says, 'wait', it will happen in His timing, which is the best!

content.title: Treasured
content.introtext:
WHERE YOUR TREASURE IS, THERE YOUR HEART WILL ALSO BE.

MATTHEW 6:21 NIV
Did you know that you are a treasure to God? Jesus tells His disciples a story about a bloke who was a pearl merchant and one day he finds a beautiful pearl that had massive value and was worth loads of money. So he goes and sells all that he has so that he can own that one pearl (Matthew 13:45-46). He knew that having that pearl was more important than owning everything else. To him the pearl was a treasure and he was willing to do anything he could to get it. Do you know that you have massive value? You are like that pearl. God found you buried in the darkness and saw that even covered in loads of mud you were beautiful and worth so much. So He made a plan to rescue you. He gave away the very thing that He loved the most; His son. Jesus became a living, breathing, walking, talking, hurting, hassled human. Through His life, death and resurrection He paid the price so that we could be rescued from darkness, cleaned up and put on display to show the world how great God is! It says in the Bible, 'Where your treasure is, there your heart will also be' (Matthew 6:21 NIV). If you are God's treasure then that must mean that His heart is totally captivated by you. He loves you and wants you to treasure Him like He treasures you; to value your time with Him like that pearl. That's not too much to ask is it? So ask yourself today, what do I treasure?

content.title: God's presence
content.introtext:
LIKE A TREES ALONG A RIVER BANK BEARING FRUIT EVERY SEASON.

PSALM 1:3
You might have noticed that quite a lot of worship songs talk about God's presence. It means that God makes His reality really obvious in a particular place at a specific moment and, get this, that place can be your life! When God's presence shines through you other people are drawn in. So how do you get God's presence in your life? Well you can think of it like a biology lesson: the secret is in getting the roots of your life planted in God's soil. If you plant a seed in soil that has no nutrients and is really dry, the seed won't grow but if you plant a seed in good soil and water it regularly that seed will grow into the amazing plant God intended it to be. You're like that seed. If you spend time in God's Word, the Bible, which is jammed with 'God nutrients', then God's reality will begin to be transferred into you like a plant getting healthy from good soil. This will have a massive effect on how you live your life and the choices you make from day to day. Because you've packed yourself with 'God nutrients', when you have a tough day you will have His presence inside you to get through it and finish that day a winner! The more you allow His goodness to influence your life, the more your life will point others to Him. You're like a big billboard and people look at you. You can either be advertising Jesus or something not so cool. If you put your roots down in Him your life will show who Jesus really is. His goodness, His love and loads more!

content.title: God's Grace / Favour
content.introtext:
A GOOD MAN [OR WOMAN] WILL OBTAIN FAVOUR FROM THE LORD.

PROVERBS 12:2 NAS
Because God's blessings don't all look the same for everyone, we get the idea that He somehow gives special treatment to certain people. However, the Bible says He 'does not show favouritism' (Acts 10:34 NIV) so that can't be quite right. In the English New Testament the words grace and favour both come from the Greek word, charis [gift] so when it says grace it could also mean favour. Think about it: when you ask somebody for a favour you're asking them for something you don't deserve. You're counting on their kindness and generosity when there's no obvious reason for them to do it, right? Throughout the Bible God's grace/favour is what made it possible for 'nobodies' to do great things. For example, God chose a teenager called Esther to save her people and she stepped out in faith to approach the king, 'she obtained grace and favour in his sight' (Esther 2:17 AMP). God made a way for her to do the job He'd given her. Without God's grace/favour it's certain that Ruth, a Moabite woman, wouldn't have been accepted by the Israelites but because God had plans for her life and her heart was pure before Him, she ended up marrying Boaz, 'a man of great wealth' (Ruth 2:1 NKJV). And from their family line came King David and then Jesus! Pretty impressive huh? David said, 'You bless the righteous; you surround them with your favour' (Psalm 5:12 NIV). When God approves of you, other people start favouring you too; often for reasons even they can't explain! Solomon said, 'A good man [or woman] will obtain favour from the Lord.' So ask for God's favour, expect it and live it out!

content.title: Are you ready for bigger things?
content.introtext:
YOU...ENLARGED ME WHEN I WAS IN DISTRESS.

PSALMS 4:1 AMP
Did you know that the hermit crab looks for a shell that fits him, then lives in it 'til he outgrows it? After that he has to scurry along the ocean floor and find a bigger one; it's a process that repeats itself throughout his entire life. Are there things in your life that no longer fit you but you can't let go just because it's easy and familiar? David said, 'You...freed me when I was hemmed in and enlarged me when I was in distress.' To really grow in God you've got to be willing to get out of your comfort zone and deal with a little 'distress.' What worked for you yesterday may not work today. Maybe it's a club you've outgrown, a relationship you need to think about or a behaviour you need to change. Whatever it is, never become so 'settled' that you can't let go and move on when you need to. Sometimes it's good to be patient and see things through but there are times when those things are holding you back because you've outgrown them. Instead of hanging in and trying harder, at certain points you have to stop and ask yourself, 'Is this situation good for me?' If you're not sure, ask God for 'an understanding mind [to]...know the difference between...right and...wrong' (1 Kings 3:9 TLB). His Word says, 'If you need wisdom...ask [Him], and He will [gladly] give it to you' (James 1:5 NLT). When God says it's time to move on, it's because there's another shell out there that will fit you even better but you can't live in the new until you leave the old one. So how about it; are you ready for bigger things?

content.title: Too close to the line
content.introtext:
AND WE SHOULD NOT ENGAGE IN SEXUAL IMMORALITY.

1 CORINTHIANS 10:8
One of the biggest things to deal with as a teenager is the issue of sex. It's everywhere you look. In advertising it's used to sell just about everything, it's on the TV, in magazines, on the radio and just about everywhere you can think of. Sometimes it can feel like you're the only person in the world not doing it and that pressure can be massive! Sex is a great thing that God made for people to enjoy but what's OK and what's not? How should a young person cope with the constant temptation? Well, temptation is hard to resist, especially when it's backed up by a rush of hormones. So watch out! Once you've crossed that line just a little, chances are next time you'll push it even further (many people disagree on where the 'line' is by the way). So how do you stop from crossing the line? Don't go near it until the time is right (ie. when you're married!). If you're not sure if it's OK or not, just don't go there. The truth of the matter is that God has given a set of guidelines to stop you getting hurt so claiming ignorance ('I didn't know whether that was allowed') is totally missing the point! Don't try to con yourself into thinking you haven't sinned due to a technicality; God knows your heart. Playing 'Let's see how close to the line we can go' isn't clever and it's not God's plan for you. So how far is too far? The answer is simple; just stay well away from the line. That may not be much fun now but one day you'll be glad you waited.

content.title: God wants you to succeed!
content.introtext:
HE SOUGHT HIS GOD AND WORKED WHOLEHEARTEDLY...SO HE PROSPERED.

2 CHRONICLES 31:21 NIV
Let's get one thing straight: God doesn't want you to be a loser but you've got to do certain things: 1) Set realistic goals. Think about what you can really manage and take it a bit at a time. One of the major reasons why many things fail is a lack of focus. So avoid distractions: 'A double minded man is unstable' (James 1:8). 2) Set deadlines. Most people don't plan to fail, they just fail to plan! If you're not organised write things down. Above all, guard and watch your time. 'Use your head. Make the most of every chance you get' (Ephesians 5:16 TM). 3) Do your homework. 'A wise man will hear and increase in learning' (Proverbs 1:5 NAS). If you'll pay for a hot CD but not a good book, you are showing that you value your pleasure more than your progress. Leaders are readers! 4) Trust God. If He's given you a plan or a dream, trust Him even when things look bleak. Be positive and expectant that He's going to come through. 5) Help others become successful. Don't expect everyone to support your dreams, plans and ideas if you don't support theirs! 'Remember that the Lord will reward each one of us for the good we do' (Ephesians 6:8 NLT). That means sometimes you put others first! 6) Put God first. You are His child, He wants you to succeed. What father wouldn't? So make a decision today to do everything you can to deepen your relationship with Him: 'Stop quarrelling with God...and things will go well for you' (Job 22:21 NLT).

content.title: Faith (4)
content.introtext:
FAITH IS THE REASON WE REMEMBER GREAT PEOPLE.

HEBREWS 11:2 NCV
When the Bible says, 'Faith is the reason we remember great people,' maybe you think 'that settles it, I'll never be great'. However you might be surprised when you find out some of the people God bigs-up in Hebrews, Chapter 11. Noah was a farmer-turned-boat-builder who got his name in lights because the boat he built survived the world's biggest ever flood. What we sometimes forget is that afterwards he got bladdered and disgraced his family! Abraham wasn't a prophet or a teacher; he was a wheeler-dealer with some character issues who tried to save his neck by lying and putting his wife in danger. Sarah, a housewife, laughed in God's face when He told her she'd give birth to a child at 90 years old (and you'd probably have done the same!). Then there's Rahab the hooker. How did somebody with her reputation ever become a woman of faith? You'll have to ask God; He included her on the list. How about Jacob the con artist? Would you like to do business with him? Of course there was David, who committed adultery which led to murder. And what about Gideon and Samuel, two big leaders whose children went right off the rails? The bottom line is that all these 'greats' were human just like us. In fact some of them would make us look like saints! You won't find any stained-glass material in this chapter. They messed up, screwed up and fell flat. The only thing they got right; they believed God and He honoured their faith!

content.title: Faith (3)
content.introtext:
WHEN WE TRUST...HIM, WE'RE FREE...TO GO WHEREVER WE NEED.

EPHESIANS 3:12 TM
When you walk by faith God will test you like he tested Elijah! The prophet was sitting alone beside a dried-up stream when God sent him on a 100 mile hike through the desert to Zarephath. At the time Elijah was a wanted man, so coming out of hiding meant really trusting God for his safety. Next, God told him that when he got there a poor widow would provide for him. Elijah found the widow in the middle of a famine, cooking her last meal with her last bit of food; a bit depressing! Elijah challenged her to obey God, promising: 'There will always be plenty of flour and olive oil...in your containers until...the Lord sends rain and the crops grow' (1 Kings 17:14 NLT). Why on earth did Elijah have the confidence to say that to a skint widow during a famine? He had lived a life of faith and proved God to be faithful! You can talk that way when you walk that way! Rubbing shoulders with people who trust God is contagious, it builds your faith. This woman was no exception. She and her son may not have eaten slap up meals every night but God made sure that as long as the famine lasted they had all they needed. So if you don't have everything you want right now, give God what you've got and trust that when the time is right He'll look after you. Paul says, 'When we trust...him, we're free...to go wherever we need.' So wherever God is directing you, even if it's somewhere that doesn't make sense to you right now, don't argue. Go, because His promises depend on your obedience.

content.title: Faith (2)
content.introtext:
JOB...FELL TO THE GROUND AND WORSHIPED.

JOB 1:20 NAS
A few days ago we looked at Job and his attitude to having a seriously bad week. Every day God sends us opportunities to grow spiritually, disguised as problems! After losing his house, his children, his animals and his health, the Bible says, 'Job...fell to the ground and worshiped.' That's not the normal human response to tragedy, is it? Job didn't react that way because he understood what was happening or because he was nuts. No, he did it in spite of his circumstances! He was able to respond that way because: a) he looked inside! He knew that God was teaching him something really valuable and important: 'When He has tried me, I shall come forth as gold' (Job 23:10). Job simply put his trust in God b) he looked forward! He reminded himself that in the end it's all going to be OK when we stick with God c) he looked up! In the middle of a nightmare, Job saw the God who promised to direct each step we take. More importantly, he trusted God's heart of love and knew that as God, what happens is His call. Don't make the mistake of thinking it was easier for Job to trust God than it is for you. Remember, Jesus hadn't even been born at that point so He didn't even have the same proof of God's love as we do! As humans we tend to go for what we know, even if it's rubbish. There's safety in the familiar even if it's boring but that's not God's plan for your life. So what should you do? Look in, look forward and most of all look upwards!

content.title: Faith (1)
content.introtext:
WITH GOD ON OUR SIDE...HOW CAN WE LOSE?

ROMANS 8:31 TM
Faith is like a muscle; using it may cause a strain but in the end it grows stronger. David (the bloke who wrote all those Psalms and killed Goliath) totally understood this. He was always getting into trouble but instead of losing faith in God's promise, David understood that, 'The Lord has set apart [ear-marked] the godly man for Himself' (Psalm 4:3 NAS). So he said, 'In peace I will...lie down...For You...Lord, make me to dwell in safety' (Psalm 4:8 NAS). Even when he was captured by the Philistines he prayed, 'When I am afraid, I will...trust in You' (Psalm 56:3 NAS). When he ended up in a cave after legging it from a very angry King Saul he said, 'I will hide beneath the shadow of your wings until this...is past' (Psalm 57:1 TLB). During the third century, when St. Felix of Nola was running from his enemies, he hid in a cave. Eventually a spider began to weave a web across the small opening, sealing it off and making it look like nobody had been inside for months. As a result the guys hunting for him ran straight pass and didn't even bother to go in. Later, stepping out into the sunshine, Felix declared, 'Where God is, a spider's web is a wall. And where He isn't, a wall is but a spider's web.' Jesus said you'd have problems on earth; people will disappoint you and you'll disappoint yourself. Sometimes you'll end up in a cave because of something you did, other times because of circumstances you'd no control over but God is with you either way. Like Paul said, 'With God on our side ...how can we lose?'

content.title: Everyone hates spiders
content.introtext:
GOD MADE...ALL THE CREATURES.

GENESIS 1:25 NIV
While most people would agree that it's wrong to kill a cat or dog, many of us don't have a problem getting rid of those slightly lesser loved animals like flies or spiders! You see, the problem is that insects generally aren't very nice. We don't want them in our homes and certainly don't want them crawling on us but the question is, do we kill them or catch and release them? Does it really matter? People's views on this question will differ but there's one thing to remember; a person's views matter. You see it's our conscience that determines the answers to these questions and everyone's conscience differs. Sometimes it's according to your level of 'holiness' but sometimes you can simply really feel something is wrong! What you need to remember is when someone feels really strongly about something you don't think matters, respect their opinion, it's probably a God-given one! Throughout our lives God will transform and change our thinking and this includes the way we think about little things. For example, if something comes on the TV, you may suddenly get the feeling that it's not a good thing to watch. When this happens, turn it off! What's more, if someone else thinks it and you don't, remember it's not your place to set them straight and tell them they're being ridiculous. Show them some respect and turn the TV off. Live your life in a way that won't force others to feel embarrassed about their beliefs and if you get a little feeling something's wrong, don't ignore it. Be strong enough to turn over the TV and let the spider go, these things aren't worth falling out over!

content.title: Blessed be His name
content.introtext:
JOB 1:21

'PRAISE THE NAME OF THE LORD
Six years ago today an historical event happened known globally as 9\11. Terrorist attacks on America left the world shaken as the Twin Towers fell to the ground in New York City. As we remember those who lost their lives, the first question we ask is 'God, why did this happen?' It's times like this that our faith is shaken or strengthened. We all know the easy answer that we have free will, we're free to make our own choices and that day, those men chose to hijack those planes but there's not much comfort in that answer. In the book of Job, we see similar questions asked. Job was a top guy with a great life who loved God a lot and God loved him back but Job was tested; it's easy to worship God when life's good but what about when it's not going so smoothly? Job lost his animals, his farm, his servants and even his sons and daughters. Even so, Job was able to say 'The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away; may the name of the Lord be praised.' How many of us say that?! You see, even though we may not want to hear it, the fact is that God IS good. Whatever we go through God still loves us. He never leaves us and proved that by sending us Jesus. Whatever we go through He still laid down his life for us! So remember, as we think of those who lost their lives six years ago remember, God IS good and still deserves all the honour and praise.

content.title: Don't panic
content.introtext:
DO NOT BE AFRAID OF SUDDEN FEAR.

PROVERBS 3:25 NAS
There are times when life throws something at you that's really scary. For some people it's exams, for others it's spiders and for others it's public speaking. The fear-factor that comes with these things has physical effects: you can't breathe, your palms sweat, your chest gets tight, you feel weak... If you recognise these symptoms, you're not alone! Every year almost one in three people have a panic attack. What's the answer? The Bible says: 'Do not...panic...The Lord shall be your confidence' (Pr 3:25 AMP). Here are some tips you can use to help: 1) Breathe: Panic makes you breathe in short, shallow bursts but breathing deeply helps to calm and relax you. Remember, 'He himself gives all men life and breath' (Acts 17:25 NIV). So when you start to feel overwhelmed just breathe the Name of Jesus. 2) Don't panic about feeling panicked! If you do, you'll end up in double-trouble. An old American president once said, 'We have nothing to fear but fear itself.' It's one thing to realise that you're scared but don't add that to your list of worries. It's possible to allow yourself to feel fear without reacting to it and it will help to break the cycle too. 3) Distract yourself: Panic makes you think thoughts that feed your fear so you need to get your mind onto something completely different. Whisper a prayer, quote a verse, listen to some music or talk to a friend. If your panic continues to be an ongoing issue there's no shame in getting professional help. After all, it's God who gives doctors the wisdom to help. So take action today and don't let panic control you!

content.title: Calling the peacemakers
content.introtext:
BLESSED ARE THE PEACEMAKERS.

MATTHEW 5:9 NIV
In this world full of conflict you have to take sides. You have two options; you can be a troublemaker or a peacemaker! You can add to the stress or you can bring a solution. Check this out: A little guy was confronted by three bullies, any one of whom could have flattened him and that's what they had in mind but even though the guy was small he was a quick thinker. He backed off, drew a line in the dirt and then backed up a few more steps. In a statement that sounded like suicide he looked into the eyes of the biggest of the three and said, 'Now, you just step across that line!' The big bully did. At that moment the little guy grinned and said, 'Good, now we're both on the same side!' Peacemakers look for common ground and try to get everyone onto it. Their goal is to find a win-win situation. Barnabas, whose name means 'Son of encouragement,' looked out for the newly converted Paul until he'd got rid of his dangerous reputation as an enemy of Christians. Given Paul's track record, who could blame them? Barnabas wasn't looking at Paul's troubled past; he was thinking about his potential and his risk paid off big time. Saul the persecutor soon became Paul the apostle! Barnabas had to put his credibility on the line for this to happen. Peacemaking means taking a risk on people, judging them by their best moments rather than their worst. Here's another way to think about it; peacemakers see right through petty personal opinions or tedious temporary conditions; they're governed by grace. So, are you ready to be a peacemaker?

content.title: Potential
content.introtext:
FAN INTO FLAME THE GIFT OF GOD, WHICH IS IN YOU

2 TIM 1:6 NIV
Right at the beginning of time God made all that we see in a sequence of amazing creative acts. Have you ever thought that when He made the living things, everything from oak trees to orang-utans, He made them full of potential? Not one of the living things we will find on the face of the earth simply appears by magic in its finished form and then disappears again without rhyme or reason. No, everything has a cycle of growth and everything has the potential to multiply. The thing that sets us apart from every other living thing on the face of the earth is that our potential is not just biological; there's a bigger reason for us being here! In your life there is spiritual potential. That means there are promises and possibilities stored up for you to discover. Jesus makes this really clear 'Everything is possible for him who believes' (Mark 9:23) and Peter adds, 'He has given us His very great and precious promises' (2 Peter 1:4). Sometimes we can have tunnel vision when it comes to considering what God may be calling us into. Our ideas can get very rigid and we start to lose any sense of flexibility. If we learn anything from looking at the way God has journeyed with his creation since those original mighty acts it is this; God gives the potential and then offers the freedom it needs to be worked out. The question is how are you using that freedom? Are you taking every opportunity to become the radical disciple you were created to be? If not; why not?!

content.title: Going the distance
content.introtext:
I'VE RUN HARD RIGHT TO THE FINISH, BELIEVED ALL THE WAY. ALL THAT'S LEFT NOW IS...GOD'S APPLAUSE!

2 TIMOTHY 4:7 TM
Young people tend to live more spontaneous lives than those who are older. Full of energy, looking out for new experiences, with few responsibilities; no wonder so many old people if they had one wish would choose to be young again. We will all change over time and as we do knowing certain things in advance will help, for example: 1) Aging isn't optional but being 'old' is. You can keep a youthful attitude by staying open to new ideas and remembering that you can learn something new every day. 2) Time is a gift. David said, 'Teach us to use wisely all the time we have' (Psalm 90:12 CEV). So much of life is wasted doing things that don't count for anything. How much of your typical day is just wasted time? What can you do about it? 3) Testing times will come. Don't be surprised if you have difficult, painful or stressful situations to go through. Don't let these times make you angry or bitter. Bad health, busted relationships and broken dreams can actually bring about beauty in our lives if we let God teach us how to respond. 4) Laughter revives the soul. You might be fit or foxy now, turning heads as you walk down the street but when Mother Nature and Father Time get through with you, a well-developed sense of humour will come in handy every time you look in the mirror! Since 'A cheerful heart is good medicine' (Proverbs 17:22 NLT), make sure you approach every day with a sense of fun. Put these things into practice now and you stand a much better chance of going the distance.

content.title: Getting from here to there
content.introtext:
A LAND IN WHICH YOU...SHALL...LACK NOTHING.

DEUTERONOMY 8:9 AMP
When God delivered the Israelites from slavery He did it in stages: First: He brought them out of the land of 'not enough.' As slaves in Egypt without power, they were forced to depend on Pharaoh for everything. When you have to keep relying on anyone but God, you're not really free. God won't allow you to get 'hooked' on anybody but Him. Elijah was living happily by a stream in the middle of a famine. Ravens brought him meat each day. What an arrangement! One day the ravens didn't show up and the brook dried up. What happened? God dried up the brook to drive him back to the source! Regardless of whom God uses He alone is the source of all you need. Second: He brought them through the wilderness of 'just enough.' God provided them with heavenly food, manna, just enough for each day. Now it's no fun struggling to barely get by. We tend to appreciate what we had to struggle for and we learn to trust God more. Plus, living through seasons of 'just enough' builds into us an instinct to keep moving on to better things. Third: He brought them into the land of 'more than enough.' God described Israel's future home as 'a land in which you shall lack nothing.' God's ultimate goal for you is abundance, in all areas of life! Is that so you'll have more than the next guy? No! God told Abraham, 'I will bless you; I will make your name great, and you will be a blessing' (Gen 12:2 NIV). 'More than enough' means never having an excuse not to help those in need.

content.title: Share your faith - somebody needs it!
content.introtext:
THEN I WILL TEACH TRANSGRESSORS YOUR WAYS.

PSALM 51:13 NIV
The story goes that Roger Simms was hitchhiking home when he was picked up by Mr. Hanover. As they drove towards Chicago, Roger felt God urging him to share his faith. When he overcame his fear and asked the man if he would like to become a Christian, Mr. Hanover stopped, bowed his head on the steering wheel, began to cry and accepted Jesus. 'This is the greatest thing that has ever happened to me,' he said. Shortly afterwards he dropped Roger at his house and went on to Chicago, which was about an hour down the road. Years later, while preparing for a business trip to Chicago, Roger came across the gold-embossed business card Mr. Hanover had given him years earlier. When he arrived in Chicago he decided to look up Hanover Enterprises and found it located in a skyscraper down town. When he asked the receptionist if he could see Mr. Hanover, she said, 'No, but his wife is here.' 'You knew my husband?' the woman in her 50's asked. Roger explained that her husband had given him a ride and how he'd led him to Christ. 'When was that?' she asked. 'May 7th, five years ago, the day I was discharged from the army.' She began to sob. After several minutes she regained control and said, 'I prayed for my husband's salvation for years, believing God would save him. But right after he let you out of his car, on May 7th, he was killed in a head-on collision. I thought God had not answered my prayer, and I stopped living for Him five years ago.' That day she recommitted her life to Christ. Share your faith; somebody needs it!

content.title: He did it for you
content.introtext:
BY HIS WOUNDS WE ARE HEALED.

ISAIAH 53:5 NIV
Max Lucado writes: 'I received a call from a friend named Kenny. He'd just returned from Disneyworld. "I saw a sight I'll never forget," he said. He and his family were in Cinderella's castle. Suddenly all the children rushed to one side...Cinderella had entered. She stood waist-deep in kids, each wanting to be touched. Kenny turned toward the other side of the castle. It was now vacant, except for a boy; his age was hard to determine because of the disfigurement of his body...he stood watching...longing to be in the middle of the kids reaching for Cinderella. But can't you feel his fear; fear of yet another rejection? Fear of being...mocked again? Don't you wish Cinderella would go to him? Guess what? She did! She walked across the floor, knelt at eye level with the stunned little boy and placed a kiss on his cheek. "I thought you would appreciate the story," Kenny told me. 'I did. It reminded me of another one. The names are different, but isn't the story the same? Rather than a princess of Disney, it's the Prince of Peace. Rather than a boy in a castle, it's a thief on a cross. In both cases a gift was given. In both cases love was shared. In both cases the lovely one performed a gesture beyond words. But Jesus did more than Cinderella. Cinderella gave only a kiss. When she stood to leave she took her beauty with her. The boy was still deformed. What if Cinderella had done what Jesus did? What if she assumed His state? What if she had somehow given her beauty and taken on his disfigurement?' That's what Jesus did for you!

content.title: God's still in charge!
content.introtext:
ARE YOU NOT RULER OVER ALL...OF THE NATIONS.

2 CHRONICLES 20:6 NAS
The country we call 'home,' exists only by God's permission and power. 'He made from one man every nation...having determined their appointed times and the boundaries of their habitation' (Acts 17:26 NAS). Politicians can draw all the maps they want but they aren't worth the paper they're printed on because God is not constrained by any border or boundary. Leaders don't determine the future of countries; God determines the hearts of leaders. 'The king's heart is like a stream of water directed by the Lord; he guides it wherever he pleases' (Proverbs 21:1 NLT). The stubborn will of the most powerful president can be directed by God as easily as a farmer reroutes a shallow ditch on his farm. The Old Testament tells of Cyrus, the powerful King of Persia (Iraq). When God wanted the Jews to return to Jerusalem He simply prodded him to make an 'official announcement' (Ezra 1:1 TM). Earlier in their history God had not only set the Israelites free from 400 years of slavery in Egypt, He caused their captors to equip them with supplies. '[They will] load you down with gifts...so...you will [not leave] empty- handed' (Ex 3:21 TLB). If we enjoy a great economy, personal freedom and good education, we shouldn't limit our thanks to politicians. No, we thank God: 'He makes nations great, and destroys them; he enlarges nations, and disperses them' (Job 12:23 NIV). Look behind the headlines; God has a plan for the Earth's rebellious nations. He makes and breaks leaders and so we should continue to passionately pray, 'Your Kingdom come, your will be done, on earth as it is in Heaven.'

content.title: Hearing from God (4)
content.introtext:
FOR THE REVELATION AWAITS AN APPOINTED TIME.

HABAKKUK 2:3 NIV
When God speaks to you it's not always wise to rush out and tell people. Actually, it can often be totally the wrong thing to do! When God gives you a word of direction it's often followed by a season of preparation. So don't go broadcasting your latest big revelation until God gives you the green light. Why? You need time, maturing and equipping, so that the word you've received can take root and be fulfilled in the way God wants. Look at the example of the Apostle Paul; after the amazing vision of Jesus he had on the Damascus Road he started spouting off about his experience and very quickly it got him into trouble (see Acts 9:20-31). It wasn't the right time for doing that. Paul writes, 'Fourteen years later I went up again to Jerusalem... But I did this privately to those who seemed to be leaders...' (Galatians 2:1-2 NIV). Paul had the wisdom to know that people would find his calling unbelievable. So he waited; a very long time! He allowed God to go ahead of him and arrange the circumstances in his favour. While he was waiting, he allowed the word he had received to grow in his heart and make changes in his life. Then and only then did he start doing what he was called to do. Paul didn't try to convince anybody, he let God do that. The result? 'Their response was to recognise and worship God because of me' (Galatians 1:24 TM). So don't get ahead of God's plan for your life. Don't let your mouth make its own decisions; be sensitive to God's timing!

content.title: Hearing from God (3)
content.introtext:
HIS ANOINTING TEACHES YOU CONCERNING EVERYTHING.

1 JOHN 2:27 AMP
We need to have an attitude that says, 'God, no matter what anyone else is telling me, or what I think myself, if I clearly hear You saying something to me I'm going to honour You and do what You say.' If we pray and hear something from God but then start asking everybody else what they think, we're putting human opinions above God's. This will stop us from developing the trust that is essential for any relationship to exist long term. Okay, some decisions are really big and we need to be sure we've heard God right but at the end of the day we need to trust God to show us the way. Listen, 'His anointing teaches you concerning everything...' (1 John 2:27 AMP). The Apostle John wrote this verse as part of a warning he was giving to young Christians; he wanted them to be really careful who they listened to because at that time a lot of false teachers were leading people astray. He wanted them to know that God gives his Spirit as a guide and direct our lives. We might ask more mature Christians for advice but we must not blindly follow other people. If we are ever going to develop the ability to hear from God and be led by His Spirit, we have to start making our own decisions and trust the wisdom God has deposited in our heart. The devil wants us to think we're not capable of hearing from God. Don't buy it! The Holy Spirit that dwells inside you will give you confidence, comfort and counsel for your life. So, learn to listen to Him!

content.title: Hearing from God (2)
content.introtext:
BE STILL, AND KNOW THAT I AM GOD.

PSALM 46:10
If you're unwilling to listen to God in one area, you'll be unable to hear from Him in other areas. People think they can't hear from God but in reality there are a lot of things they already know He wants them to respond to but they just haven't done them. The more quickly you do whatever it is the Lord tells you to do, the more quickly He reveals the next step for you to take.Hearing from God must be developed by practice; especially if you're a talker! That's why He says, 'Be still and know that I am God.' Most of us are full of energy and want to be active doing something, so it can be difficult for us to be still. Don't just talk to God when you want or need something; spend time with Him; listening! He'll open up many issues if you'll just be still before Him. You say, 'But I don't think I've ever heard God talk to me!' Could it be that you haven't learned to listen? When you ask God for something, it's time to tune your 'receiver.' Even if He doesn't respond at that moment, He will in time. You may be doing something very ordinary when He decides to speak but if you have made listening part of your Christian walk, He'll speak to you at exactly the right time. Maybe you've wasted years going your own way, doing your own thing. It's not too late to go in a new direction. If you're willing to obey God, He'll begin an exciting conversation which will flow between you and Him every day of your life. What's stopping you?

content.title: Hearing from God (1)
content.introtext:
HE WILL BE OUR GUIDE.

PSALM 48:14 NIV
Jesus told His disciples, 'The Spirit of truth (the Truth-giving Spirit)...will guide you into all the Truth (the whole, full Truth)' (John 16:13 AMP). Jesus spoke these words to men with whom He'd spent the previous three years. Now you'd think that if Jesus was with us personally for three years, day and night, we'd have learned all there is to know but Jesus said to expect more because He will always have something to say to us about each new situation we are facing. God wants to speak to you on a one-to-one basis. He wants to lead you step by step into the good things He has in store for you. He cares about the tiniest details of your life. Never hesitate to take what you think are small things to God; after all, everything is small to God! He even keeps track of how many hairs you have on your head (see Matthew 10:30). He cares about the desires of your heart. He wants to reveal truth to you that will set you free from worry, fear and limitation. His plan to share an intimate relationship with you existed before you were even born. The Psalmist said, 'All the days [of my life] were written before ever they took shape' (Psalm 139:16 AMP). Paul said that God 'determined the times set for them and the exact places where they should live. God did this so that men would seek him' (Acts 17:26-27 NIV). It's not rocket science but if God plans all of our days and where we're going to live before we're even born, then it makes sense for us to learn how to hear from Him.

content.title: Growing strong roots
content.introtext:
MAY YOUR ROOTS GO DOWN DEEP INTO THE SOIL OF GOD'S MARVELLOUS LOVE.

EPHESIANS 3:17 TLB
Difficulties, hardship, and tough times; no one looks forward to them but they make us strong! Philip Gulley writes, 'Growing up I had an old neighbour named Dr. Gibbs. When he wasn't saving lives he was planting trees. The good doctor had some interesting theories ... He came from the 'no pain, no gain' school of horticulture. He never watered his new trees. He said watering plants spoiled them; if you water them, each successive generation will grow weaker. So you have to make things tough for them and weed out the weenie trees early on. He talked about how watering trees made for shallow roots, and how trees that weren't watered had to grow deep roots in search of moisture. He'd plant an oak, and instead of watering it, every morning he'd beat it with a rolled up newspaper. Smack! Slap! Pow! He said it made the trees pay attention. Dr. Gibbs went to glory a couple of years after I left home. Every now and again I'd walk by his house and look at those trees he planted twenty-five years ago. They are granite strong, big and robust. They wake up every morning and beat their chests and drink their coffee black. I planted a couple of trees a few years back. Carried water to them for a solid summer, sprayed them, and prayed over them. Three years of coddling has resulted in trees that expect to be waited on hand and foot. Whenever a cold wind blows in, they tremble. Sissy trees. Funny thing about those trees of Dr. Gibbs. Adversity seems to have benefited them in ways comfort and ease never could.'

content.title: No peace? It's 'out!'
content.introtext:
LET THE PEACE OF CHRIST RULE IN YOUR HEARTS.

COLOSSIANS 3:15 NIV
When God speaks to us He gives us a deep sense of inner peace to confirm that He is speaking to us. Beware of false peace! When we have a strong desire to do something it can produce a strong emotion but it's a lot more to do with our own excitement than God's peace. As time passes this false peace disappears and God's 'true will' emerges for our lives. So we should never move too quickly on important decisions. When the devil speaks to us he can't give us peace and when we just try to sort things out in our own minds, we can't get peace. 'But to be spirituality minded is life and peace' (see Romans 8:6 NKJ). Made a decision? Does your own thinking or even the ideas of others outweigh your inner peace? Hold back! You don't have to explain to others why you don't have peace about it; sometimes you won't know why. Just say, 'It's not wise for me to do this because I don't have peace about it.' There's power in having peace! Once you know you've heard from God do all you can to 'keep your peace' and not worry. Peace is an inner 'knowing' that your actions are approved by God. 'Let the peace (soul harmony which comes) from Christ rule (act as umpire continually) in your hearts [deciding and settling with finality all questions that arise in your minds, in that peaceful state] to which...you were also called [to live] (Colossians 3:15 AMP). God leads us by peace. His peace is like a tennis umpire who decides what's 'in' and what's 'out.' No peace? It's 'out.'

content.title: The choice is yours!
content.introtext:
IF ANYONE HEARS MY VOICE AND OPENS THE DOOR, I WILL COME IN.

REVELATION 3:20 NIV
Max Lucado writes: 'Ever wonder why there were two crosses next to Christ? Or why Jesus was in the centre? Those two crosses symbolise one of God's greatest gifts; the gift of choice. The two criminals have much in common; convicted by the same system, condemned to the same death, surrounded by the same crowd, and equally close to the same Christ. In fact, they began with the same sarcasm; the two criminals each said cruel things to Jesus. But one changed. He said, 'Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom.' Jesus answered him, 'I tell you the truth, today you will be with me in paradise' (Luke 23:42-43 NIV). While we rejoice at the thief who changed, we dare not forget the one who didn't. There are times when God sends thunder to stir us. There are times when God sends blessings to lure us. But there are times when God sends nothing but silence, as He honours us with the freedom to choose where we spend eternity. We have never been given a greater privilege than that of choice. Think about the thief who repented. Though we know little about him, we know this: in the end, all his bad choices were redeemed by a solitary good choice. He chose Christ!' No matter how many bad choices you may have made in your past, you can be rescued by one good choice; the choice to give your life to Christ and follow Him. Will you make that choice now? If you do you'll never ever regret it.

content.title: More on Serving
content.introtext:
SERVING THE LORD, NOT MEN, BECAUSE YOU KNOW THAT THE LORD WILL

EPHESIANS 6:7-8 NIV
The Bible talks a lot about sowing and reaping. When you are still in bed dreaming about being Becks or being married to Becks, farmers are out on their tractors ploughing fields. When he sows the seeds he expects to see a crop for this work. When we invest in something or someone it's only human to feel we should reap where we've sown. When we don't, it's easy to get upset. Yet the Bible says, 'Serve whole- heartedly, as if you were serving the Lord, not men, because you know that the Lord will reward everyone for whatever good he does.' (Ephesians 6:7-8 NIV). Nobody knows the sacrifices you've made better than God. He sees your secret and selfless acts on behalf of others and His Word says, 'Then your father, who sees what is done in secret, will reward you.' (Matthew 6:4). Now if God chooses to reward you richly, don't let anybody make you feel bad about it. Just keep giving your best and keep serving, regardless of what He puts into your hand or how much praise and recognition you receive or don't receive. In the book of Matthew, Jesus tells a story of a boss who gives his workers a job to do, later he rewards their efforts. They aren't given the same responsibilities or the same rewards (Matthew 25). Your part is to be grateful for whatever He gives you, do the best job you can and enjoy the rewards and greater opportunities that follow. Remember, you're not serving so people will big you up but so that God Himself with say 'well done' (Matthew 25:21). Go for it!

content.title: Serving
content.introtext:
SO JOSHUA DID AS MOSES HAD SAID TO HIM...

Exodus 17:10
If you've got a job or you help out at church or even just have chores around the house, think about Joshua. Josh served Moses, doing what Moses said but looked only to God for his reward. Your boss may pay you but he doesn't decide your future; God does that! So what difference does that make? It means no job God gives you will ever be beneath you! When you pray 'God, use me,' He may well ask you to serve someone else. If you make the mistake of looking to that person for your reward and it doesn't come, you'll feel used and resentful. It's God who sets the rules for you. God's the one who requires you to honour Him by serving with submission (that means not moaning, groaning and giving it loads of attitude) and excellence. He's the one who calls you to give the best you can. He's the one who says it's not okay to always turn up late and grumpy; or wait until your mum has asked you ten times before you get round to taking the bin out! Remember God rewards us according to our service; not what others think we're worth. Sometimes we can be busy and wanting to be bigged up by people but we are not serving them. Stop striving and get back to serving! Listen, 'God is not unjust; He will not forget your work...' (Hebrews 6:10 NIV). Be encouraged; whatever tasks you face today remember that God records and God rewards; that should be enough for you!

content.title: So far so good! (3)
content.introtext:
When I was a child.

1 Corinthians 13:11 NIV
