In the wilderness satan offered Jesus three things (see Luke 4). He also offers them to you: 1) satisfaction! Jesus was hungry and satan tempted Him to turn stones into bread. This was satisfaction without God, because God's plan was to feed His Son supernaturally through angels. But Jesus refused to settle for less - and so should you! 2) success! Taking Jesus to the top of the temple, satan said 'Jump off, God will protect You and everyone will believe in You.' This was an offer of success without the cross, the easy way out! And hasn't satan made you that same offer: 'You don't have to take up your cross daily like the bible says.' satan lied then, and he's lying to you now. 3) significance! Satan offered Jesus the kingdoms of this world and their glory if He'd just bow down to him. Jesus rebuked him with a reminder from Scripture that God alone is worthy of being glorified. Satan will take every legitimate desire you have and try to get you to fulfil it in an illegitimate way. He will offer short cuts and easy answers that aren't part of God's plan. But God 'will provide the way of escape.' You say 'I don't see the way of escape.' That's because you're focused on the temptation instead of the way out. God's promise of escape doesn't mean you won't have to persevere and be faithful to Him. And, as in the case of Christ, it involves knowing and being able to use the Scriptures. But it does mean that when God's plan of victory over temptation has been fulfilled, you'll come out victorious!

content.title: Don't be impatient
content.introtext:
Let patience have its perfect work, that you may be...complete, lacking nothing.

James 1:4 NKJV
Just because it hasn't happened yet, doesn't mean God has changed His mind. While you are waiting, God is working. The timing may not be right for Him to get the ultimate glory, and you the maximum benefit. That's why the Bible says: 'Let patience have it's perfect work, that you may be perfect [mature]...lacking nothing.' Impatience is a sign of immaturity. Children can't wait for anything! So, are you being childish or showing maturity? God sets His watch to accomplish His purpose, not ours. Paul writes: 'We know that all things work...according to his purpose' (Romans 8:28 paraphrase). We need to be asking God about his plans and purpose. When you understand God's purpose you won't allow things to get in the way of it. That includes hurry and worry. You'll also know how to spend your time, your energy and your money, who you should spend your life with and who you shouldn't. God says, 'I make known the end from the beginning' (Isaiah 46:10 NIV). First God sets the goal, and then He determines the steps that lead to it. What are we supposed to do while we are waiting? Listen: 'Though the fig tree does not bud and there are no grapes on the vines, though the olive crop fails and the fields produce no food, though there are no sheep in the pen and no cattle in the stalls, yet I will rejoice in the Lord, I will be joyful in God my Saviour' (Habakkuk 3:17 NIV). Begin thanking God today for what He's done, and what He's going to do on your behalf, because He absolutely will come through for you!

content.title: Breaking barriers
content.introtext:
You have stayed long enough at this mountain.

Deuteronomy 1:6 NIV
A teenager was telling a pensioner why the older generation doesn't understand the younger. 'You grew up in a primitive world,' he said. 'We've got space travel, nuclear energy and computers.' Smiling, the old man replied, 'You're right, we didn't have those things, that's why we invented them!' In other words, the reason we are where we are now is because someone went first and made it possible! So, what are you doing to break the mould and do something new? Sometimes we have to smash the barriers that are holding us back. To get beyond your mental barriers you must stop saying things like, 'That's just the way I am,' or, 'My family never amounted to much, so I won't either.' No, you're contradicting God! God said, 'I will pour my Spirit into your descendants and my blessing on your children' (Isaiah 44:3 TM) When God rescued Israel from Egypt and they headed for the Promised Land, a journey that should have taken 11 days took 40 years. They ended up circling the same mountain repeatedly because they'd been oppressed so long that mentally they couldn't grasp what God had prepared for them. Finally He told them, 'You have stayed long enough at this mountain...take possession of the land...the Lord swore he would give to your...descendants.' If your history (or even your family's) is one of failure and despair, rise up and say, 'Enough's enough! I'm going to trust God for bigger and better things!' It's in such moments that your destiny is shaped. Think: the decisions you make today will affect not only you but future generations - so make sure they're the right ones!

content.title: God's favour
content.introtext:
When God approves of your life, even your enemies will end up shaking your hand.

Proverbs 16:7 TM
You can't please everybody all the time. And it's a big mistake to try. Your constant need for approval can end up costing you God's best. When you're doing anything worthwhile, expect opposition from those who aren't in on God's plan for your life. That goes with the job. Notice, Jesus 'made himself of no reputation' (Philippians 2:7 KJV). He wasn't always well thought of by others, in fact a lot of people hated him, but He knew He had God's approval - and that's what mattered to Him! In Proverbs 21:1 Solomon says that just like changing the direction of a moving river, God can change hearts and give you favour with those who'd otherwise reject you. He also said, 'When God approves of your life, even your enemies will end up shaking your hand.' Does that mean you won't come across opposition or people who disagree with you? No, but when you do, just concentrate on pleasing God and let Him deal with the fallout. Remember, God takes up where you leave off. When you've done "all that you can do" He can step in and open doors with the right people at just the right time. The truth is, He can get you a better opportunity than you could get on your own, and give you blessings that, humanly speaking, you don't deserve or qualify for. Just as the Holy Spirit enabled Jesus to fulfil His life's mission (see Luke 4:18-19), God will call, equip and enable you to fulfil His plan for YOUR life. So stop trying so hard to make things happen on your terms, and begin praying for God's favour!

content.title: Stages of spiritual growth (3)
content.introtext:
I am writing to you, fathers, because you know Him who has been from the beginning.

1 John 2:13 NAS
What makes you a spiritual adult? Knowing God; it's that simple! But this raises a question. How can you know that you know God intimately? It's like a good marriage: two people fall in love and become so close that each one knows what the other is thinking and feeling without a word being spoken. But such intimacy is not developed overnight. It's the product of time spent together and commitment to each other! Paul speaks about, 'Things which eye has not seen and ear has not heard, and which have not entered the heart of man, all that God has prepared for those who love Him. For to us God revealed them through the Spirit' (1 Corinthians 2:9-10 NAS). The mature follower of Christ sees things the human eye can't see, hears things the most acute ear can't hear and has thoughts they didn't originate on their own. That's because God's indwelling Spirit is helping them to think God's thoughts. What an advantage! You'll know you are spiritually mature when God lets you pick up on thoughts and insights from His Word that go far beyond what someone told you, or what you heard in a sermon. That's because the Holy Spirit is now free to send His message clearly and directly to you. In other words we will 'know the things freely given to us by God' (1 Corinthians 2:12 NAS). But that means we have to be close enough to hear God speaking to us. Such intimacy doesn't just happen. It's not an afterthought. It must be your number one priority and the consuming passion of your life. Is it?

content.title: Stages of spiritual growth (2)
content.introtext:
I am writing to you, young men, because you have overcome the evil one.

1 John 2:13 NAS
The second stage in spiritual growth is adolescence. John writes, 'Young men...you are strong, and the Word of God abides in you, and you have overcome the evil one' (1 John 2:14 NAS). The transition from adolescence into adulthood can be a bumpy ride. Teenagers clash with their parents and other authority figures because they're moving from dependence to independence. They wrestle with conflicting feelings of wanting their freedom, yet not really wanting it; especially if the parents are still paying the bills. They hate being told what time they have to 'be in', particularly when their friends don't have to worry about it. They don't like getting approval for clothes, parties, or for using the family car. They especially hate hearing, 'As long as you're under my roof you'll live by my rules. When you get your own family you can make up your own rules.' But like it or not, as teenagers we still need help, support and guidance. That's all true of the 'spiritual teenager' as well. They don't know as much as they think they know. They need guidance, support, and correction from more mature Christians so they can learn how to avoid falling into the enemy's trap. They need instruction and training in God's Word to make them strong and keep them ready at all times. And they need opportunities to serve, discover and develop their gifts, and gain experience. So, how can you tell when you've outgrown your spiritual adolescence and begun moving into adulthood? John answers, 'You are strong... the Word of God abides in you, and you have overcome the evil one.'

content.title: Stages of spiritual growth (1)
content.introtext:
I am writing to you, little children, because your sins have been forgiven.

1 John 2:12 NAS
There are three stages to spiritual growth. The first is childhood. Have you got any little rugrats in your family?! If you have you'll know that there's one thing toddlers are good at; it's tripping and falling. Until they learn to walk confidently they need someone to pick them up, dry their tears, stick a plaster on their scraped knee, and reassure them that falling down doesn't mean they'll never be able walk like a grown up or that they're not part of the family. There are two things a spiritual toddler needs to understand: first, the difference between their stage of growth, and their spiritual position before God. Don't get these two things mixed up! Trusting in the finished work of Jesus (becoming a Christian) is the only thing that gives you right standing with God. From that moment on you are a fully accepted and rescued child of His. That's how He sees you. If you forget that you'll be in trouble, because every time you fall or mess up the Devil will try to make you doubt your salvation. Think about this; suppose you're sitting in a maths lesson and you enter some wrong numbers into your calculator. What do you do? You have a little button called 'clear' which allows you to erase your error and start over. That's what the blood of Jesus does for you; it gives you a fresh start. Asking God to forgive you and deciding to live differently helps you to grow; we need to do it every day. The important thing to do whenever you trip up is to run quickly to Jesus.

content.title: Going Deeper
content.introtext:
That I may...become more deeply and intimately acquainted with Him.

Philippians 3:10 AMP
When a storm hits, a tree needs roots that are strong and deep and when hard times hit us we need spiritual depth. Check out Job! When the bottom dropped out of his world, Job said: 'But he knows where I am and what I've done. He can cross-examine me all he wants, and I'll pass the test - with honours... I've followed him closely, my feet in his footprints, not once swerving from his way... I've obeyed every word he's spoken, and not just obeyed his advice-I've treasured it' (Job 23:10-12 NAS). We need the spiritual depth of Paul, who prayed three times for what he calls 'the thorn in his flesh' to leave and three times the Lord said 'no' (although we don't know for sure what the thorn was, many think it was hardship and persecutions from others). In response, Paul said, '...these limitations that cut me down to size - abuse, accidents, opposition, bad breaks. I just let Christ take over! And so the weaker I get, the stronger I become' (2 Corinthians 12:9 TM). Instead of looking for a way out Paul declared, 'I chose to go through this so that I can have the privilege of experiencing more of Christ's power working in my life.' Don't you want what these people had, so that your spiritual life is such that you walk in step with God whether you feel good or not; whether you get a 'yes,' 'no,' or 'wait,' in answer to your prayers; even when you don't get your own way? Spiritual depth must become your all-consuming goal, and the highest priority of your life. Is it?

content.title: Shout 'wonderful'
content.introtext:
Love...always hopes, always perseveres...never fails.

1 Corinthians 13:6-8 NIV
When you meet someone who needs encouragement, give it to them! Why? Because more people die of broken hearts than swelled heads. And that's true, whether they live in a mansion or a mud hut. There is a cheesy story about a little boy who wanted to play darts with his father. He said, 'Come on, Dad, let's play darts. I'll throw and you shout "amazing!"' You may smile, but the truth is we tend to become what the most important people in our lives think of us. So whether it's friends or family think the best, believe the best, and express the best toward them; for your words are helping to shape their destiny. And remember, change happens by inches, not miles! The only way we can break old habits, old ways of thinking about ourselves, is to form new ones - and that takes time and practice - lots of it! You can't tell people something just once and expect them to get it. No, they need to hear it over and over before they start thinking differently about themselves. And how you tell them, the look in your eyes and the tone of your voice, can determine whether they really believe it. So think about it. Find creative ways of encouraging them; send a card, buy a trophy or medal and get it inscribed with a message, write a song or poem, carve a sculpture of them out of ice - well maybe not; but you get the idea. For most us actions speak louder than words. Be persistent! Never give up trying to big them up, encourage and help them. Remember, 'Love...always hopes, always perseveres... never fails.'

content.title: 'Staying the course'
content.introtext:
The testing of your faith produces endurance.

James 1:3 NAS
Endurance means 'sticking at it.' But endurance is only a word until you have to deal with a parent's divorce, a prolonged illness or the rebuilding of your life after a tragedy. Endurance is also a word which carries a lot of meaning when it comes to describing the preparation, practice and hard work that leads to success. It takes commitment to keep going when friends fail you, discouragement whispers 'give up,' and doubt says 'it can't be done.' That's when endurance takes on new meaning. It becomes your anchor in the storm, your compass in times of confusion, and the head of steam that gets you up the next hill. Remember, Jesus knows how it feels, and believe it or not, He is using those hard times to help us grow. Also He gives us two great promises: 1) His comforting presence (see Isaiah 43:2-5) 2) the assurance that He won't permit more pressure than we can handle (see 1 Corinthians 10:13). But there's another thing to remember; other people are watching! Paul (with a bit of help from Eugene Petersen) writes, 'People are watching us as we stay at our post...working hard, working late, working without eating; with pure heart, clear head, steady hand; in gentleness, holiness and honest love; when we're telling the truth...when God's showing His power; when we're doing our best setting things right; when we're praised, and when we're blamed; slandered, and honoured; true to our word, though distrusted; ignored by the world, but recognised by God...immersed in tears yet always filled with deep joy; living on handouts, yet enriching many; having nothing, having it all' (1 Corinthians 6:1-10 TM). That's called 'Sticking at it.'

content.title: A 'yes' face!
content.introtext:
LOVE...IS NOT IRRITABLE OR TOUCHY.

1 Corinthians 13:4-5 TLB
The author, Chuck Swindoll writes 'The most significant decision I make each day is my choice of an attitude. When my attitudes are right there's no barrier too high, no valley too deep, no dream too extreme, no challenge too great for me.' If you believe that you'll take charge of your emotions, begin to focus on what's good, and reject anything that makes you a petty, bitter person. And your face will say 'Yes.' One day President Thomas Jefferson and a group of friends were travelling across America on horseback. They came to a river that had overflowed its banks because of a recent downpour. The river had washed away the bridge so each rider was forced to cross it on horseback, fighting for his life against the current. This caused a traveller who was not part of the group to step aside and watch. After several riders had plunged in and made it to the other side, the stranger asked if President Jefferson would carry him across. The President agreed without hesitation. So the man climbed on and the two of them made it safely to the other side. As the stranger slid off the horse onto dry ground, one of Jefferson's mates asked, 'Why did you select the President?' The man was shocked and admitted he'd no idea that it was the President who'd helped him. 'All I know,' he said, 'is that on some of your faces was written the answer "no," and on some was written the answer "yes." His was a "yes" face.' A good attitude has a 'yes' face. Try to remember that today!

content.title: What are you depending on?
content.introtext:
There is a way that seems right to a man, but...it leads to death.

Proverbs 14:12 NIV
There is a broken rope on display at the Alpine Museum in Bern, Switzerland. It is associated with a tragic story. Some climbers who scaled the Matterhorn (a seriously dangerous mountain) roped themselves together for the return descent, but one slipped and dragged three others with him into an abyss. The other climbers braced for the shock on the rope that linked them together, expecting it to halt their companions' fall. The tug came, but then to everyone's horror the rope snapped, plunging their four friends to their death. Nobody knows why an inferior rope was used for such a hazardous venture, but they do know it wasn't genuine Alpine Club rope which was guaranteed and distinguished by a red strand running through it. Just as reliable equipment is crucial in preparing for the life-and-death adventure of mountain climbing, it is even more essential in preparing for the most important journey you'll ever make; the one from here to eternity. And an 'anything-goes' attitude; loose connections to the church; casual claims that you're doing your best and you're a 'good' person won't suffice. Solomon said, 'There is a way that seems right to a man, but...it leads to death.' Peter says: 'Jesus is the only One who can save' (Acts 4:12 NCV). Assurance of a place in God's kingdom, now and forever, comes only through accepting Jesus as your personal Saviour, believing that He died for your sins and rose again to give you everlasting life. God will not ask for any more or any less. Today Jesus is waiting to save you; will you let Him?

content.title: Battling the 'what ifs?'
content.introtext:
A miserable heart means a miserable life; a cheerful heart fills the day with song..

Proverbs 15:15 TM
An old sea captain once asked a naval student how he'd handle a sudden storm. 'I'd throw out an anchor, sir,' he replied. 'But what if another storm approached?' asked the captain. 'Then I'd throw out another anchor,' he said. 'And what if storms just kept coming?' the old man asked. 'I'd keep throwing out anchors,' said the student. 'Hold on, son,' said the captain, 'where are you getting all those anchors?' 'From the same place you keep getting all those storms, sir,' came the reply! When you're in the thick of things, it's easy to get overwhelmed by the storm that's raging inside you and start listening to the 'what ifs.' What if they dump me...what If I don't get on the course...what if mum and dad split...what If that relative doesn't get better. The list is endless. And because satan knows that 'fear involves torment' (1 John 4:18 NKJV), he'll keep pouring it on. If he can't get you puffed up through pride he'll try to bring you down through fear. It's one of his most effective weapons. But you don't have to take it! Paul says, 'Leave no room...for the devil [give no opportunity to him]' (Ephesians 4:27 AMP). Jesus told us not to be 'fearful...intimidated...and unsettled' (John 14:27 AMP). Remember 'A miserable heart means a miserable life; a cheerful heart fills the day with song'. Here's the bottom line: God is '...completely dependable. If He said it, He'll do it! (1 Thessalonians 5:24 TM). So, no matter how big your problem is today, keep trusting God and He will bring you through!

content.title: Manipulative relationships
content.introtext:
Fear of man is a dangerous trap.

Proverbs 29:25 TLB
Sometimes we are so desperate to make a relationship happen we will pay a costly price. Teen movies are packed with parables like the geeky kid who has to get a make over to win the school's approval or the best friend who never says no and gets pushed around, manipulated and taking for granted. The moral of the tale is: can we ever be happy always trying to make other people happy? Solomon said, 'Fear of man is a dangerous trap.' Relationships can't thrive with one person calling all the shots while the other struggles for approval. Paul said he had no interest in 'trying to make people accept him.' His only interest was pleasing God (see Galatians 1:10 NCV). God will never ask you to compromise your values or disobey His will just to be in the good graces of another person. In fact, it's better to be alone than to allow anyone other than God to control you. Let people know up front that, while you'd like their approval, you can live without it if you have to. Respect others, and make it clear you expect the same in return. Above all, never let your emotions win out over wisdom, or drown out the voice of God in your life. When you're insecure you can be drawn into wrong relationships. Security is a fundamental part of your identity as God's child. Paul says you 'are God's workmanship...created...in Christ Jesus' (Ephesians 2:10 NIV). God wants you free to be who you are. That's why when you ask Him to guide your relationships; He'll help you to form the right ones.

content.title: Remembering
content.introtext:
Remember from where you have fallen, and repent and do the deeds you did at first.

Revelation 2:5 NAS
Many teenagers have perfected a silent groan and sarcastic roll of the eyes the moment they ever hear an adult say 'I remember when...'. In their minds the past is well ... past it! It's old news, it's out of date, it's boring. What's the point in looking back when we should be looking at forward! Maybe mobile phones, game consoles and ipods ALWAYS keep improving as time goes on; but do we? Often our walk with God isn't what it used to be, sometimes we need to look back and remember. In the book of Revelation, Jesus has a message for a bunch of Christians in a city called Ephesus, but is He speaking to all of us? 'Remember from where you have fallen, and repent and do the deeds you did at first.' Go back in your mind to your first days as a Christian. Do you remember when a) you talked about Jesus and your heart would be buzzing b) prayer was exciting and you felt empowered as you spent time with Him c) the Bible was filled with mind blowing insights and ideas you'd never seen before d) you were desperate for people to find out about how amazing God was? What happened? Do you feel like one of the Christians Jesus was speaking to? Distance from God is a frightening thing because you don't even know it's happening! We need to get back into step with Him. When we try to fit God in instead of putting Him first, we are going to lose touch. This week what could you start doing again that 'you did at first'?

content.title: Kingdom subjects (2) - JOIN ME?
content.introtext:
Live generously and graciously toward others, the way God lives toward you.

Matthew 5:48 TM
About 5 years ago Danny Wallace put a advert in a local newspaper which simply said 'Join Me'. He asked anyone who wanted to join him to send a passport photo and that was it! Danny didn't expect to anyone to reply, especially since the advert said nothing about what or why they were joining or even what 'joining' really meant. Amazingly, in few weeks 4000 people sent him photos and became 'joinees.' After a while the joinees were emailing their new 'leader' to ask what they had joined; what did their group do? Danny didn't know, he'd just done it for a bit of a laugh. Then he had an idea, tell them to live generously. Every Friday everyone had to perform a random act of kindness towards a stranger. Shopping was being carried, cuppas being paid for, flowers were taken to old people's homes, and cakes were left on doorsteps. Of course it's not just Danny's mates, across the world a lot of people are kind and make a difference everyday. Jesus told HIS joinees to live generously but He also went further than that. He said live the way that God lives towards you.' Lets think about that! That's means not just being kind to strangers, the needy or deserving, but being kind to the undeserving, the cruel, the selfish. It means generosity that's driven by grace. It means loving our enemies! After all this is how God lives towards you. 'While we were God's enemies, He made us His friends' (Romans 5:10 NCV) Jesus has shown how to love, how to serve, how to live, how to be kind; now He says 'Join me'. It's up to you.

content.title: Kingdom Subjects (1)
content.introtext:
GROW UP. YOU'RE KINGDOM SUBJECTS. NOW LIVE LIKE IT. LIVE OUT YOUR GOD-CREATED IDENTITY...

Matthew 5: 48 TM
Bono from U2 once said: 'I decided to act like a rockstar and suddenly I had become a rockstar.' But what did people think of the young Paul Hewson (Bono's real name) when he was walking around in his now famous sun glasses and 'acting' like a rockstar? Maybe they thought he was just a dreamer, but did he care? He'd made a decision, he was going to live like the person God had designed him to be. What have you decided to live like? Jesus is telling his followers to 'live out your God-created identity'. Yet so often we're busy wanting to be like other people. We see their gifts, their looks, their opportunities and find ourselves asking God to change us and make us more like them. God does want to change us, but He won't change you into someone else, He will only change you into the person He created you to be. Part of being that person is to live like a 'kingdom subject'; to live like a child of God. 'Act your age and not your shoe size' is a saying that comes straight out of the mum's manual of 'How to Wind Up Your Kids.' But lets be honest, 8 of 10 times your mum often has a point. Sometimes we do need to grow up. Jesus says 'Grow up. You're kingdom subjects. Now live like it'. He knows what we are capable of, what our potential is and hates to see us compromise, settle for second best or fall short. When we call ourselves Christians, it means we represent Jesus. So today decide to represent Jesus by being the person He has created you to be.

content.title: Winning the biggest battle of all
content.introtext:
Christ...is your example. Follow in his steps.

1 Peter 2:21 TLB
Richard Halverson, an American author, writes, 'Do you want to be a winner? Compete against yourself, not somebody else. Outrunning your rival doesn't mean you ran your best race. You can win over another and still not fulfil your potential. To be your best you must compete with yourself; Alexander the Great conquered the world, yet cursed his own lack of self-control. Victory over others may in fact be the very thing that contributes to the winner's failure to conquer self. Winning makes him arrogant, independent, thoughtless; and sometimes cruel. The one who stops maturing spiritually because he thinks he knows more scripture than others, or has more success in ministry, is still far from being what Christ has planned for him.' Wow, read that again and let it sink in! Sometimes it's easy for us to think we are more sorted because we might be doing better than someone else. We might be doing better but are we doing our best? Oh and if you're going to start comparing, compare yourself with the top dog himself! 'Christ...is your example. Follow in His steps: He never sinned, never told a lie, never answered back when insulted; when He suffered He did not threaten to get even; He left His case in the hands of God who always judges fairly' (1 Peter 2:21-23 TLB). Go ahead, measure yourself by that standard! And when you see how far short you fall, get down on your knees and ask God to mould and fashion your life into the full potential, the divine original He intended. Do that and you win the biggest battle of all!

content.title: Stand Up
content.introtext:
...AFTER YOU HAVE DONE EVERYTHING...STAND

EPHESIANS 6:13 NIV
Since we've all got long lists of weaknesses, what do we do when the enemy comes along? Check this out, 'after you have done everything... stand'. In Romans 14:4 Paul says, '...the Lord is able to make [you] stand' (NIV). You don't have to stand in your own strength, you can stand in the strength of Jesus. By yourself you're an easy target for the enemy, but in the strength of the Lord you can stand and not give in. So today when satan shows up with his temptations, announce that you're going to stand in Jesus. Make a decision that you're going to stand until the ground stops shaking, until you feel peace again, until the wave of loneliness passes, until your friendship is restored, until the illness is passed, until the struggle is over, and until the tempter runs out of steam and stops trying to topple you! When you do the standing - God does the strengthening! Paul said, 'I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me' (Philippians 4:13 NKJ). Jesus doesn't just strengthen you once or twice or three times; He'll strengthen you every single time. Every time you face a difficult challenge, every time a memory comes back to haunt you, every time you're reminded of your imperfect past, every time you face a difficult decision. Drawing from God the strength you need to stand up to the enemy will take effort. It will take your praise, your prayer, and your getting into the Bible with an intensity you've never had before. But the fact is Jesus is with you and you can stand - if you really want to!

content.title: The 'P' Word
content.introtext:
CREATE IN ME A PURE HEART, O GOD...

PSALM 51:10 NIV
What's purity? The 'P' word may evoke loads of different thoughts in your mind - it might make you think of something different from the kind of person you are. You may think that it's something you long to be, but you feel dirty from all the stuff you've done in your life, so it's totally out of your reach. You know what? In a way all those thoughts have an element of truth to them. You can't make yourself pure by how often you pray or go to church. You can't even make yourself pure by giving yourself a scrub in a bubble bath! Something is pure if it has no contamination and you can only be made pure by Jesus. Only He has the power to turn your mistakes round for good, mend your broken heart and clothe you with pure... purity! Someone who is contaminated has no way of becoming pure by their own efforts. But, if you have said 'Yes' to Jesus as your Lord and Saviour you can trust that today you stand '...Holy and blameless in His sight...' (Ephesians 1:4 NIV). He has made you pure. You may be thinking, 'that's all good but how am I supposed to live a life that matches up with how God sees me?' Well God gives us some amazing advice through the words of King David, 'How can a young person live a clean life? By carefully reading the map of your Word...' (Psalm 119:9 TM). God's word is like a map of a city - it shows us the right roads to go down and where there is a dead end. Navigate your day with His word!

content.title: Understanding temptation
content.introtext:
...GOD...DOES NOT TEMPT ANYONE.

JAMES 1:13 NAS
Trials and temptations are very different. Trials are allowed by God to form character in us. Temptations are sent by satan simply to bring us down. There's no way a temptation to sin can be called a trial sent from God. He doesn't test our faith by setting us up to sin. Just because it's so easy to click on a porno website doesn't mean it must be okay with God if you do! Just because your teacher can never tell if you're lying doesn't mean you should! Get real! James wrote: 'Let no one say when he is tempted, "I am being tempted by God"...each one is tempted when he is...enticed...' (v13-14). The word 'entice' describes a fisherman putting bait on a hook to get a fish to bite. The fish is looking for a snack, not to become dinner for the fisherman. No mouse goes looking for a mousetrap. What the mouse wants is the cheese. But its appetite for cheese cons it into thinking that the cheese is a free meal, and the trap is sprung. Eating well nourishes your body; but too much bad food produces all sorts of health problems. Money can really bless you; but spending irresponsibly can trap you in a spiral of debt. When a desire for something becomes all consuming, hear the warning bell ringing! But the Good News is you're not in this fight alone. Peter writes: '...the Lord knows how to rescue godly people from their trials...' (2 Peter 2:9 NLT). Victory comes when you draw closer to the One who defeated the tempter both in life and in death. So call on Him today. He's ready to help you!

content.title: Influence
content.introtext:
...SOMEHOW OR OTHER YOU WERE INFLUENCED AND LED ASTRAY...

1 CORINTHIANS 12:2 NIV
The Oxford dictionary defines 'influence' as: 'the power or ability to affect someone's beliefs or actions'. So, are you an influence or are you influenced? One of the biggest influences on us is the culture around us. There's Music Culture - Hip Hop with its bikinis and bling, Metal with its Marshall Amps and hair dye. The latest overnight success interviewed in NME or on MTV as if the world needed another Pop Idol! There's Tech Culture; the latest and most funky software and gadgets; Shopping online and never doing anything old-fashioned like picking up a pen - why write when you can type! We live in a media driven culture that's very fast paced and we hear a lot of things during our day from news clips, celebrities, advertising and politicians to name a few. But in all of what we hear we have a choice to let it influence us or not. Remember that dictionary definition? 'the power or ability to affect someone's beliefs or actions'. God wants us to make sure that the power is flowing in the right direction - His power through us to the world - not the other way round. As Christians, the culture that should influence us the most should be the culture of God's Kingdom. What's that? Kingdom culture is God's values being lived out daily, like loving your neighbours as yourself (see Luke 10:27) and being kind to people even when they're not kind to you (see Matthew 5:44). You see God's way of doing things isn't the same as the world's way, but it has the best results. Today, make sure you are an influencer not one of the influenced.

content.title: The hammer approach!
content.introtext:
IT IS BEST TO LISTEN MUCH, SPEAK LITTLE, AND NOT BECOME ANGRY.

JAMES 1:19 TLB
Famous psychologist Abraham Maslow said, 'If the only tool you have is a hammer, you tend to see every problem as a nail.' What he means is that some of us have strong personalities and always take the hammer approach when something gentler will do. If that's your problem, try using the following T's : 1) Total picture. A man walked into a bar, 'Do you have anything to cure hiccups?' he asked. The bartender slapped him across the face. 'Oi! what's that for?' said the man. The bartender smiled 'Well, you don't have hiccups any more, do you?' 'I never did' the man replied. 'I wanted something to cure my wife, she's outside in the car.' Do you come to conclusions before you actually have a proper grasp of the issue? Chill out for a mo' and think; then you'll be more likely to get the total picture. 2) Timing. If the parent doesn't get the injured child to the hospital quickly enough, her life might be lost; and if you don't apologise when you've wronged someone, the relationship could be lost. When you act, is as important as taking the right action. Also knowing when not to act. Lady Dorothy Nevill observed: 'The art of conversation is not only to say the right thing in the right place, but to leave unsaid the wrong thing at the tempting moment.' 3) Temperature. As tempers flare, we drop more bombs instead of calling a ceasefire. Here's a tip: a) if the reaction is worse than the action, the problem usually increases b) if the reaction is less than the action, the problem usually decreases. So, don't take the hammer approach!

content.title: Easily hurt?
content.introtext:
A WORD OF ENCOURAGEMENT DOES WONDERS.

PROVERBS 12:25 TLB
Ask yourself, 'Do I hurt people, or am I easily hurt by them?' Then consider these truths: 1) Hurting people hurt other people. The German poet Herman Hesse wrote: 'If you hate a person, you hate something in him that is part of yourself. What isn't part of ourselves doesn't disturb us.' Hurting people lash out in response to what's happening inside them. They feel or believe something negative within themselves. Try to remember that. 2) Hurting people are more easily hurt again. Let's say you've got a splinter in your finger and it becomes infected. Then someone brushes against it. You howl with pain, 'Aaaah! You hurt me!' But the real problem is not that someone accidentally touched it - the problem is you still have a splinter and you've not dealt with it! Hurting people overreact, overexaggerate, and overprotect. Ask any counsellor who's dealt with a hurting couple. Emotionally speaking one half 'throws up' then the other half 'cleans up.' Usually the one with the most pain does the most damage. 3) Quick fixes don't work. The kindest thing you can do for hurting people is ask them, 'Are you prepared to work through the issues and get beyond your pain?' When a drainage company was working under the streets cleaning out a sewer they found: sixty-one diamond rings, several vintage coins and a whole load of silverware! It was an unpleasant job - but they discovered all sorts of valuables in the process! Now, in the same way you may need to do some digging and deal with some pretty nasty stuff, but you're going to discover some treasures you didn't know existed.

content.title: Touching Jesus
content.introtext:
A WOMAN IN THE CROWD HAD SUFFERED...

MARK 5:25 NLT
Mark records, 'a woman in the crowd had suffered for 12 years with constant bleeding.' She was desperate. But her desperation gave birth to an idea - 'She had heard about Jesus...' (v27 NLT). And Jesus was in town! He was there on a mercy mission, on his way to help the synagogue leader. It's a bit odd to find the ruler and the woman in the same story. He's powerful. She's pitiful. But they both need Jesus. His daughter is dying. Tragedy has a way of levelling the social ladder. She thought, '"...If I can just touch His robe, I will be healed"' (v28 NLT). So she pushed through the crowd until Jesus' robe was in sight. She stretched out her hand. 'Immediately...she could feel...that she had been healed...' (v29 NLT). She felt power enter. Jesus felt power exit. 'Jesus...asked, "Who touched my robe?" (v30 NLT). Next we read: '...The woman...knowing she was the one...knelt before him, and gave him the whole story' (Mark 5:33 TM). Wow! How long had it been since someone listened to her story? With the priest waiting, a child dying and a crowd pressing, Jesus made time for a woman on the fringe. Using special intimate language He says, '"...Daughter, your faith has made you well..."' (v34 NLT). And we've been her, haven't we? Illness took her strength. What took yours? Harsh words? Bad advice? Disappointments? Controlling relationships? Is her hand your hand? Jesus is there for you even when it's hectic all around. He wants to hear your story. You can receive the power you need today. Even the emergencies can wait until you are restored!

content.title: 'In time of need'
content.introtext:
...GRACE TO HELP IN TIME OF NEED.

HEBREWS 4:16 NAS
What does God's grace remind you of? Have you ever thought about it like an ambulance racing to treat someone in an emergency? The crew of paramedics offer assistance to the victim on the spot. First, they give immediate grace to the most serious symptoms or injuries. Then they move into the ambulance, which is equipped with more grace - more medical facilities - to deal with the problem. And as the paramedics are administering more grace to the patient, the ambulance races to the hospital where even more grace is waiting. Once the patient is admitted, the hospital keeps dispensing grace to meet the need until the problem has been addressed and the patient can go home again! As the old hymn goes: 'Twas Grace that brought me safe thus far, and Grace will lead me home.' Imagine Jesus as that paramedic. He came to you, found you dying in your sin and started the job of pouring grace on your wounds. And, a bit like the driver of the ambulance, He also transported you from where you were, to a place that has all the grace you will ever need as long as you live, until you are finally and fully restored at the resurrection to reign with Him forever. So, how can we be on the receiving end of grace like this and take the time to thank Him? 'But I'm tired' you say. That's ok, just whisper. 'But you don't understand. I'm hurting and I feel like quitting.' Jesus understands, just tell Him. Today He'll meet you where you are and bring to you all the grace you need!

content.title: The Holy Spirit
content.introtext:
...the Holy Spirit...will teach you all things...

JOHN 14:26 NIV
Did you know that when you said yes to following Jesus you weren't left on your own to try and figure everything out for your self, no way! God gives all His children an amazing gift, His Holy Spirit. Listen: 'But the Counsellor, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in my name, will teach you all things and will remind you of everything I have said to you' (John 14:26 NIV). The Holy Spirit is there to help us get to know God better and to have a close friendship with Him. You might be saying to yourself, 'how do I receive this gift?' The same way you receive any present, all you have to do is accept it, and then say thanks. Wow, now you have a really special super-close friend for life. The Holy Spirit is God's Spirit so He will never lie to you, always love you and to top it off is really good at giving direction and advice. But hold on, it doesn't stop there! When you said yes to following Jesus you joined an amazing team. God's Church is made up of all sorts of people with loads of gifting and talents and all with one purpose. What? To see Jesus' name made famous in the world and to see the whole planet transformed by the power of His love! Paul describes God's master plan like this in his letter to the Christians in Ephesus, 'God's purpose in all this was to use the church to display his wisdom in its rich variety...' (Ephesians 3:10 NLT). Today you're part of that great display, part of that rich variety. That's so cool!

content.title: Mind Blowing
content.introtext:
...IN HIS LARGENESS NOTHING GETS LOST...

PSALM 36:5 TM
Have you ever stopped to think about how massive God actually is? Well today we're going to do just that. Listen: '"I am...the [beginning] and the [ending]"' (Revelation 1:8 NIV) that's one of the ways in which God describes himself! He's the one who created the whole universe, flung the stars into space, spoke and created...well, everything! He's so massive that no human brain will never really be able to 'get it'. So here's something that should blow your mind for the rest of today - or maybe the rest of your life; even though He is the awesome, massive, all powerful, all knowing God, His strongest desire is to have a relationship with YOU!!! Check this out: 'God's love is meteoric, His loyalty astronomic, His purpose titanic (not the ship, 'titanic' means BIG), His verdicts oceanic. Yet in His largeness nothing gets lost...' (Psalm 36:5 TM). God may be the creator of the mountains and the stars and the big blue sky, but he is also the one who thought up butterflies, the snowflake and chocolate, yes He invented the cocoa bean! Why should that matter? Well doesn't that show you a glimpse of God's heart? His attention to the details not only in how He creates but in the way He relates to His children. '...in His largeness nothing gets lost...' You have the attention of the creator of the universe and everything in it and He loves you enough to want to talk to you, help you, heal you and be your best friend. Don't you think that's truly mind-blowing stuff!

content.title: Whose choice is it anyway?
content.introtext:
"...CHOOSE...TODAY WHOM YOU WILL SERVE..."

JOSHUA 24:15 NCV
Peer pressure is a powerful thing. You want to be liked by people but at the same time you don't want to say yes to things that you know are going to have a bad ending. For example, if someone offers you a cigarette you are immediately faced with two choices. 1) You say yes to one, then that leads to another and then before you know it you're hooked and smelling like an ashtray. 2) You say no and have lungs that will last you a life time! You see God has given us the ability to make choices and to be able to know what is wrong from what is right; but often we try to place the blame of our bad choices on someone else. 'They made me do it.' Isn't an excuse you can use with God. Why? Because God has given us all free will and that means the ability to say No to peer pressure. When you say yes to something you are saying, 'I give you the right to have some form of control in my life.' That might sound like a bit of an overstatement but think about it, you'll find it's true every time. So be careful what you agree to. There's never a situation where you can say 'But I had no choice.' You always have options and alternatives. When the choice is there you'll know deep down in your heart what the right decision is, you just need to ask God for the courage to choose it, no matter what your mates might think of you.

content.title: Small deeds count
content.introtext:
"DO NOT DESPISE THESE SMALL BEGINNINGS, FOR THE LORD REJOICES TO SEE THE WORK BEGIN..."

ZECHARIAH 4:10 NLT
What seems small to you might be huge to someone else. During one World War II mission an RAF pilot came under attack from Nazi anti-aircraft guns. These guns were deadly because they could fire very rapidly, they had a long range and worst of all, they fired 75mm artillery shells that would explode on impact. Amazingly, even though his fuel tank was hit the plane didn't explode, and the pilot was able to make a bumpy landing. After the raid the pilot asked one of the crew to try to locate the German shell, so he could keep it as a souvenir. After investigating the crew member came back to him saying that not just one, but eleven artillery shells had been found in the fuel tank, none of which had gone off! They were all clean and harmless, and with one exception, empty. The exception contained a carefully rolled piece of paper. On it a message had been scrawled in the Czech language: 'This is all we can do for you now.' A brave worker forced to work on an ammunition assembly line had disarmed the shells so they wouldn't go off and had scribbled that note. He couldn't stop the war, but he could save one plane. He couldn't do much, but he could do something, and he did. Famous preacher John Wesley said, 'Do all the good you can, by all the means you can, in all the ways you can, in all the places you can, at all the times you can, to all the people you can, as long as you ever can.' With God, small deeds count!

content.title: That's real love
content.introtext:
LOVE NEVER FAILS.

1 CORINTHIANS 13:8 NIV
Author Richard Selzer writes: 'I stand by the bed where a young woman lays, her face post-operative, her mouth twisted in palsy; clownish. A tiny twig of the facial nerve, the one to the muscles of her mouth, has been severed. The surgeon had followed with religious fervour the curve of her flesh; I promise you that. Nonetheless, to remove the tumour from her cheek I had to cut the little nerve. Her young husband is in the room. He stands on the opposite side of the bed, and together they seem to dwell in the evening lamplight, isolated from me, private. Who are they, I ask myself, he and this wry-mouth I have made, who gaze at and touch each other so generously, greedily? "Will my mouth always be like this?" she asks. "Yes," I say, "it will be. It is because the nerve was cut." She nods and is silent. But the young man smiles. "I like it," he says, "it's kind of cute." All at once I know who he is. I understand, and I lower my gaze. One is not old in an encounter with God. Unmindful, he bends to kiss her crooked mouth, and I am so close I can see how he twists his own lips to accommodate her, and to show her that their kiss still works.' When trouble comes and hurts the people you love; do you stand by them to the end or do you run and hide to try and protect yourself? The Apostle Paul talks about love, Listen, 'It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres' (1 Corinthians 13:7 NIV). That's real love!

content.title: True Disciple
content.introtext:
"COME, FOLLOW ME..."

MATTHEW 4:19 NIV
The word 'disciple' means being an apprentice to someone. And back in the day it was easy to tell if someone had done that. Peter, James and John made a decision to spend every day with Jesus in order to learn how to be like Him. They did the same kinds of things you do; ate, slept, worked, had a laugh, and learnt loads too. They just did all of these things with Jesus. And now it's your turn. What happened to those three fishermen 2000 years ago can happen for you. What you're doing now, your personality type - these are not obstacles. Throughout history when people came to understand what Jesus was really about they would give up anything - money, comfort, home, security - to get the chance to be taught by Him. And now it's your chance too! Check out these words from Dr. Bob Moorehead's book, Words Aptly Spoken: 'The die has been cast. I have stepped over the line. The decision has been made - I'm a disciple of His. I won't look back, let up, slow down, back away, or be still. My past is redeemed, my present makes sense, and my future is secure. I'm finished with low living, sight walking, smooth knees, colourless dreams, tamed visions, worldly talking, cheap giving, and dwarfed goals. I no longer need preeminence, position, promotions, plaudits, or popularity. I don't have to be right, first, tops, recognised, praised, regarded, or rewarded. I now live by faith, depend on His presence, walk by patience, am uplifted by prayer, and labour with power.' That's what it means to be a follower of Jesus!

content.title: Loved
content.introtext:
YOU ARE THE ONE WHO PUT ME TOGETHER...

PSALM 139:13 CEV
There are some things in life that are so basic we don't even need to learn them - we just know naturally that they are good things that make sense. For instance, when a baby starts to cry because she's hungry, her mother will pick her up, hold her in her arms and feed her. By doing this the baby is not only being fed the food she needs to keep her body healthy, she is also receiving the love. But check this out: some years ago, studies were done to try and figure out why babies in orphanages, who were being regularly fed, were still dying. It was discovered that they were dying because they weren't being held or cuddled because the attendants were too busy to give them the individual attention they needed. These babies were dying from lack of relationship and love! Even when you've grown up you're still designed to have a relationship with your parents that has the basic elements of love, comfort and security. If you don't have that it can effect your emotions and your future relationships. That's why it is so important that, in your relationship with God, you let Him love you because what you may be missing out on He wants to give you. Have you ever heard of couples falling in love over the Internet before they met face to face? It happens a lot. If two people who've never seen each other can fall deeply in love just through writing to each other, how much more should you be able to develop a deep relationship with Jesus? Think about it.

content.title: What if?
content.introtext:
TRUST GOD FROM THE BOTTOM OF YOUR HEART; AND DON'T TRY TO FIGURE OUT EVERYTHING ON YOUR OWN...

PROVERBS 3:5 TM
'What if?' is a question we have all asked ourselves millions of times. 'What if I don't pass my exams? What if I don't get into the university I want to go to?' 'What if they stop fancying me and I end up alone?' There's not a problem with asking questions about life and the world around you. In fact lots of people in the Bible even asked God questions - sometimes really hard questions. The issue is what's behind the question. Is your 'What if' question asked out of fear, doubt or worry rather than trust? What does it mean to trust? The dictionary says it's, 'To place somebody or something in the care of another person.' Wow, that is a tough challenge for some of us; especially if you've trusted someone in the past and they let you down. But with God things are different, 'God....will not lie...He does not change his mind...what He says He will do, He does. What He promises, He makes come true' (Numbers 23:19 NCV). When we decide to trust God with our future and the decisions we're literally saying to Him 'God I am placing my life into Your care and I am choosing to trust that what ever challenges I face or decisions I have to make You will be watching over me and helping me to do what is best for the exciting life You want me to lead.' Trusting God takes the massive weight of trying to figure everything out ourselves off our shoulders! So today when you start to think 'what if?' stop yourself and make a choice to trust.

content.title: Why hurry?
content.introtext:
...HASTE MAKES MISTAKES.

PROVERBS 19:2 NLT
Author, John Ortberg writes: 'When I first moved to Chicago I called a friend - the wisest spiritual man I know - and asked him, "What do I need to do to be healthy spiritually?" He said, "You must ruthlessly eliminate hurry from your life." There was a long pause, and I finally said, "Okay." I wrote that one down. "Now, what else do you have to tell me, because I don't have much time and I want to get a lot of wisdom out of this conversation?" He replied "There is nothing else. Hurry is the great enemy of spiritual life. You can hardly do anything that Jesus did if you're in a hurry. Jesus was often busy, but never hurried. Hurry is an inward condition that can make you feel frantic and preoccupied that you're unable to receive love from the Father, unable to be present with other people, or to give love to them."' Have you ever said this to yourself: 'I'm just going through a busy spell, things will just settle down in time' No they won't! Life will always be hectic until you decide to get it under control. And if you're always waiting for stuff to chill out before you obey God, you'll never do what God has planned for you! The key is to cut out hurry. No one can do that for you - not your mum, dad, brother, sister, or your best mate. You have to do it yourself. To help you do that here's two verses for you to think about today: 1) 'Be still, and know that I am God...' (Psalm 46:10 NIV). 2) 'Enthusiasm without knowledge is no good; haste makes mistakes' (Proverbs 19:2 NLT).

content.title: Confession
content.introtext:
...I SAID, "I WILL CONFESS MY TRANSGRESSIONS TO THE LORD" - AND YOU FORGAVE THE GUILT OF MY SIN.

PSALM 32:5 NIV
People who keep secrets from God also keep their distance from God. But people who are honest with God find themselves getting closer to Him every day. When you talk to God how honest are you with Him? Do you just tell Him what you think He wants to hear? Do you use words and phrases that you've hear 'holy people' use in prayer meetings? Or do you talk honestly, from the depths of your heart about what's really going on in your life, warts and all? If you read Psalms you'll notice that a load of them are written by King David, they're poems and songs that are directed at God and they are brutally honest about how he feels, a mixture of passionate love and painful frustration for God and his people, '"...Have Mercy on me oh God..."' (Psalm 51:1), 'How priceless is your unfailing love!' (Psalm 36:7), 'But I call to God, and the Lord saves me' (Psalm 55:16). David made mistakes like any normal human being but he was honest with God, he didn't try and hide his mistakes. He tells God and knows that He won't be met with a big stick but with gentleness and forgiveness. 'People may be right in their own eyes, but the Lord examines their heart' (Proverbs 21:2 NLT). God can see into every person's heart and knows all their secrets so it's pointless to try and hide when you talk to God, there's nothing you can tell Him that will shock Him. There's nothing you can say that will make Him love you any less. So be honest, you've got nothing to loose.

content.title: Just Hanging Out
content.introtext:
DON'T FOOL YOURSELF, BAD FRIENDS WILL DESTROY YOU.

1 CORINTHIANS 15:33 CEV
Have you noticed that if you spend time with a person who is really fun and laughs a lot you find yourself laughing more and seeing the funny side to things too? Just like if you spend time with a person who is always backstabbing and being nasty about people behind their backs you may begin to realise that you're starting to do it too. The relationships you make and the people you hang out with will influence you in the end. Anyone can become so caught up in the wrong crowd and in bad company it's that easy to make choices we never would have made on our own. That's why it's important that you choose your mates carefully. It's also why you need to make your relationship with God your number one priority. When you spend time hanging out with God, talking to Him and listening to what He has to say it will have an amazing effect on your life. How? Well let's take one part of God's character, Love. God is Love ...He can't stop Himself from loving you. If you hang out with the one who knows how to love people perfectly then that love will start to rub off on you. You'll find yourself going out of your way to smile at people you used to ignore. You'll find yourself having patience with people who normally do your head in. The fact is the relationship you have with God directly affects your relationships with other people? So make God your number one priority today - make sure you spend quality time with Him!

content.title: Monuments
content.introtext:
[MY] LIFE IS WORTH NOTHING UNLESS...

ACTS 20:24 TLB
It's said that in Mount Hope Cemetery, you'll find several strange gravestones. Farmer John Davis had them erected. He began his working life as a hired labourer but eventually managed to gain a considerable fortune. In the process he didn't make many friends. Angry with how his life had turned out he vowed not to leave anyone a penny. When his wife died Davis erected an elaborate statue which showed both her and him at opposite ends of a sofa. He was so pleased with this that he planned a second monument, with his wife kneeling at his future graveside placing a wreath. Then he had a sculptor place a pair of wings on her back. One idea led to another until he'd spent a quarter of a million dollars on monuments to his wife and himself. Whenever someone from his town asked him to contribute to something charitable like a new hospital ward the old man would say, 'What's this town ever done for me?' After using up all his money on statues, Davis died at 92, lonely, miserable, and flat broke. His monuments...it's strange...each one is slowly sinking into the Kansas soil, fast becoming victims of time, vandalism and neglect. There's a certain poetic justice in the fact that within a few years they'll all be gone. Oh, by the way, only one person attended Farmer Davis' funeral: Horace England, the salesman from the tombstone company. What a way to go! But not Paul: '[My] life is worth nothing unless I use it for doing the work assigned me by the Lord Jesus.' Can you say that?

content.title: True giving (2)
content.introtext:
...SEE THAT YOU ALSO EXCEL IN THIS GRACE OF GIVING.

2 CORINTHIANS 8:7 NIV
As a Christian the reason you do anything good is because Jesus saved your life and gave you a brand new one. Paul writes: '...Jesus Christ...Rich as he was...gave it all away for us - in one stroke he became poor and we became rich' (2 Corinthians 8:9 TM). God gave us His best in Jesus, but we still give Him our sloppy seconds. Instead of going out of our way for someone, we make excuses and fit them in when it suits us. Or we say we're gonna spend time with God but get so busy we just rant at him for a few minutes while trying to brush our hair / make toast / run to the bus stop, instead of really making time to talk. Have you ever been given a present you hate, so you put it in a drawer for a while and then pulled it out as a present for someone else's birthday? Be honest! Well, that's how some of us approach giving to God - and to be honest its not just cheeky and rude - it's plain disrespectful! God made everything to give: He created the sun to give light during the day and the moon and stars during the night. He created flowers to give seeds. God Himself is a giver: 'For God so loved the world that he gave...' (John 3:16 KJV). Your giving is not determined by your how much money you've got in the bank, or how much free time you can fit into your week. No, you give coz God has already given so much to you and you love to make Him smile!

content.title: True giving (1)
content.introtext:
...SEE THAT YOU ALSO EXCEL IN THIS GRACE OF GIVING.

2 CORINTHIANS 8:7 NIV
God loves a happy giver, whether it's giving your time, giving your money or giving your dedication to something; it all puts a smile on God's face. The apostle Paul talks about a bunch of people who gave generously in loads of ways even though things were tough. Listen to this: '...I want to report on the surprising and generous ways in which God is working in the churches in Macedonia province. Fierce troubles came down on the people in those churches, pushing them to the very limit. The trial exposed their true colours: They were incredibly happy, though desperately poor. The pressure triggered something totally unexpected: an outpouring of...generous gifts...They gave offerings of whatever they could - far more than they could afford! - pleading for the privilege of helping...This was totally spontaneous, entirely their own idea, and caught us completely off guard. What explains it was that they had first given themselves unreservedly to God and to us. The other giving simply flowed out of the purposes of God working in their lives' (2 Corinthians 8:1-6 TM). Check this out about givers from Macedonia: 1) They gave their lives to Jesus, with no strings attached. 2) They understood that everything they possessed was given them by God in the first place. This kind of giving isn't just giving because somebody is begging, or giving because you feel guilty, or giving because you're trying to do a deal with God. No, this is giving out of the massive blessings God has already given to you. You might not have much money, but with God you're rich in loads of other ways. So share it!

content.title: 'Happy Easter!'
content.introtext:
...HE WHO RAISED CHRIST FROM THE DEAD WILL...GIVE LIFE TO YOUR MORTAL BODIES...

ROMANS 8:11 NIV
Years ago a missionary in Brazil discovered a tribe of Indians living in a remote jungle area. Disease was ravaging their population and they urgently needed medical help. However, the only clinic was on the other side of a raging river the Indians believed was inhabited by evil spirits. In their minds, crossing the river meant certain death. Although the missionary assured them he'd crossed it safely many times, they were still scared stiff. When he led them to the bank and placed his hand in the water, they looked concerned. Then He even waded in and splashed water on his face - they started to get really panicky. Finally he dived into the water and swam under the surface, emerging safely on the other side. Having proved that the river had no special powers the missionary raised a triumphant fist. The tribe broke into cheers and all followed him across. Today is when we celebrate Jesus diving into the river of death. He defeated it by submerging, crossing over and rising again on the other side! Dr Erwin Lutzer said. 'We don't need a Saviour who can just "help" us; we need [one] who can resurrect us. We don't need a Saviour who helps us when life gets tough; we need [one] who can help us when life ends.' Easter proves Jesus is '"...the resurrection, and the life..."' (John 11:25 NCV). Jesus kicked the ends out of the grave, transforming it from a dead-end street into a highway from here to heaven! And Paul says, '...He who raised Christ from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through his Spirit...' No wonder we say 'Happy Easter!'

content.title: Stop Guessing
content.introtext:
"BUT WHO EVER LISTENS TO ME WILL LIVE IN SAFETY AND BE AT EASE, WITHOUT FEAR OF HARM"

PROVERBS 1:33 NIV
Have you ever done a test or exam and spent so long over one question that you end up rushing all the rest when you realize you've only got 10 minutes left! It's lethal isn't it because you just start scribbling an answer before you suddenly realize 'Pants! I've totally misunderstood the question! In the same way why do we try and guess what we think God might have to say in answer to a question we have rather than actually spending the time in His presence listening to what He says is the best way. This is just daft coz God's way is always the best way and it's important to ask His opinion on stuff. Why? He sees the whole picture and he knows what sneaky trick the enemy could have ready to try and make you trip up. He wants to protect you from that. King David learnt a big lesson when he was leading Israel. They were at war and David went to talk to the Lord about what they should do to win. God, told him and they won a great victory. When it came to the next fight David made a mistake and he didn't go and get God's tactics; he assumed that if they did it the same way as before they'd win again, but they got battered instead. Because they'd done it that way before their enemies we're ready for them. It's the same in our lives, we shouldn't try and guess the answer but go to the one who is the answer, and it will save you a lot of heart ache and trouble in the end.

content.title: In Hope
content.introtext:
...IN HOPE THAT THE CREATION ITSELF WILL BE LIBERATED...

ROMANS 8:20-21 NIV
What would this day have been like for the disciples? For three fantastic years they'd being living the dream. They'd been the entourage of the No.1 celebrity of the day. But there was more than that, more than just being the centre of attention in every town and village they visited. Deep down in their own hearts they knew that they'd found the One, the Messiah, the hope their nation had been waiting for. Life was making sense, miracles were happening every day, and they weren't just spectators - they were in the thick of the action. And then it all got a bit serious. They found themselves looking over their shoulders after dark. They started hearing whispers and rumours. And Jesus himself started saying crazy things about having to leave them to go elsewhere, to a place they couldn't follow Him. Today is a day of remembrance for us but not really a day of sadness because we know the end of the story. But for the disciples and the other close friends of Jesus this Friday afternoon was heart-breaking on an unimaginable scale. Jesus had tried to encourage them to trust Him but they'd just not understood. They couldn't see what He could see. And how often are we just like them? When God allows sadness and suffering to cross our path we can quickly find ourselves feeling depressed or victimised because we don't see the other side. Paul reflects back on the 'frustration' of the whole world and says even that was 'in hope' of a future liberation. That's the liberation we celebrate over this weekend, Jesus bringing freedom to all creation through His death and resurrection!

content.title: Signposts
content.introtext:
I HAVE SET THE LORD ALWAYS BEFORE ME...

PSALMS 16:8 NIV
The words 'I have set the Lord always before me' are the simplest description of a spiritual life. There are a few signs God gives us to let us know He's involved in our lives: 1) Reassurance: Whether you're taking an exam, or moving to a different place, the message is: '...Do not be afraid. I am with you...' (Genesis 26:24 NIV). 2) Guidance: Maybe you're really confused about what to do about a situation and then an idea comes to you. It might be a big one or a small one, but it will help. Or you're about to say something that might hurt someone's feelings, and suddenly a little voice inside your head says 'be quiet.' 3) Conviction: You're about to do something you know is wrong and suddenly you get the sense, 'no, don't do it.' Listen to that voice cause it will stop you from making unnecessary mistakes, help you to make the right choices and lead you in the plan and purpose that God has for your life. 4) Joy: 'You have made known to me the path of life; you will fill me with joy in your presence...' (Psalm 16:11 NIV). It works like this: you make an extra effort, you hit the target and you feel a surge of satisfaction - that's what happened when God created the world. He was well chuffed with it, He looked at it and said, '...it was good!...' (Genesis 1:10 NIV). God can use any of those things to let you know he's around. If you '...set the Lord always before [you]...' (Psalm 16:8) you'll begin to be aware of Him everyday. How exciting that!

content.title: Someone else's suitcase
content.introtext:
YOU SAW ME BEFORE I WAS BORN...

PSALM 139:16 NLT
Imagine trying to live out of someone else's suitcase. Their clothes might be too big, their shoes too small. You wouldn't want to wear their underpants or use their toothbrush. Yuk! So why do we try to be someone we're not? We waste so much time trying to look like the latest pop star or super model; we get jealous of the popular people and even change ourselves just to get them to like us. But the fact is that fashions change like the weather, one day you're popular and the next you're old news. Our identity isn't found in a magazine or hanging on a clothes rail. As Christians our identity and security should be found in Jesus. What does that mean? Instead of letting your mates determine how you feel about yourself, you find out what Jesus thinks. How? If you get hold of a Bible, there are loads of bits in it that show you what God thinks of His kids. Check out Psalm 139, (it's near the middle); you'll start to get an idea of how much God cares about you. He has a purpose for you, the question is do you believe it? Listen: 'You saw me before I was born. Every day of my life was recorded in your book. Every moment was laid out before a single day had passed' (Psalm 139:16 NLT). If He bothered to take the time to make you He's going to make sure that His plan for your life isn't missed. Remember he wants the real you, not the fake you that's trying to live out of someone else's suitcase!

content.title: Be who you're meant to be
content.introtext:
...THE SPIRIT HELPS US IN OUR WEAKNESS...

ROMANS 8:26 NIV
The Bible says that you are like a poem. Listen: '...we are His workmanship...' (Ephesians 2:10 NIV). It's immediately obvious but the word 'workmanship' actually comes from the Greek word 'poeo' which is used in our English word 'poetry'. So if you're 'His workmanship' then you're an expression of God's creative personality! No two poems and no two people are the same. '...we can each do different things. Yet the same God works in all of us...' (1 Corinthians 12:6 CEV). God uses all types: Geeks, Moshers, Skaters, Chavs; from people who are loaded to the poorest of the poor. Whether you're loud or shy, fat or thin, funny or serious, short or tall; in Jesus we all have one thing in common. What? He's given you His Holy Spirit to help you display the amazing characteristics of God in your life. By choosing to do things like love instead of hate and forgive instead of holding a grudge you are choosing to live like Jesus. 'The Spirit has given each of us a special way of serving others.' No exceptions. And when we work according to God's plan and not our own, our gifts affect the world we live in and in the end make an eternal difference. If you're read this and saying to yourself, 'that's ok for other people, but I'm just little old me, I can't do anything on my own.' You know what you're right that's why God gave you His Spirit, '...the Spirit helps us in our weakness...' (Romans 8:26). Without God's help you're stuffed so today let the Holy Spirit work through you and be who you're meant to be.

content.title: Give Him what you've got
content.introtext:
"GIVE, AND IT WILL BE GIVEN TO YOU..."

LUKE 6:38 NIV
It's about 2000 years ago and Jesus has been busy teaching a crowd of people - and it's not just a little bunch of people; it's more like what you'd get at a big music festival in the park. The Bible says there were about 5,000 people hanging out listening to what Jesus had to say! It's boiling hot and on top of that Jesus knows the people must be hungry so He turns to one of His disciples and says, "where shall we buy bread for these people?" His mate is shocked coz he knows that even if he was loaded it would cost a bomb to feed that many people. But Jesus is just testing him to see if he would think, "no way we can't afford it", or "God can, so bring it on!" Andrew, another disciple, tells Jesus that he's found a boy with a packed lunch containing five little rolls and two little fish. The boy hands over his packed lunch and sits down with the rest of the crowd. Jesus says thanks to God for the food and then gets His 12 disciples to start dishing it out. Can you imagine what must have been going through their heads? But as they did what Jesus asked, a miracle happened and 5000 people got a slap up fish supper. In fact there was so much left over they filled up 12 big baskets! The reason this is such a popular story is because it illustrates one of the number one things about Jesus: if you make what you have available to Him, He'll take it, bless it and then do a miracle!

content.title: Be humble
content.introtext:
HE MUST BECOME GREATER; I MUST BECOME LESS

JOHN 3:30 NIV
An MP took his 8-year-old daughter to visit Westminster Abbey. The awesomeness of it overwhelmed the little girl. As she stood gazing up at the high ceiling her father said, 'Sweetheart, what are you thinking?' She said, 'Daddy, I was thinking how big you seem at home, and how small you look in here.' In God's presence, you might experience all kinds of things; love, happiness, acceptance. And sometimes you might just became aware of how little you are in comparison to Almighty God. God's presence has a way of humbling us. But what does that really mean? Humility is an amazing quality to have; it means that you're respectful of others, that you don't live your life trying to get every one to notice you; that you check out ways to help people, even those who aren't thankful. John the Baptist was the bloke chosen to spread the news about Jesus coming. Loads of people grew to respect him and he had a load of groupies who would follow him around every where. But when Jesus turned up John had enough guts to step aside and let Jesus do His stuff. Listen: '"He must become greater; I must become less"' (John 3:30 NIV). It takes guts to be humble coz it won't always mean you get what you want. But, don't sweat it! God gets us humble for a reason. '"...God opposes the proud but favours the humble"' (1 Peter 5:5 NLT). A humble heart is like a flashing, bleeping signal on God's radar screen, and he looks to ways He can bless you and use you to play a big part in His plan and purpose.

content.title: An unlikely platform
content.introtext:
...USING THE BOAT FOR A PULPIT, HE TAUGHT THE CROWD.

LUKE 5:3 TM
Luke writes: 'He climbed into the boat...using the boat for a pulpit, he taught the crowd' (Luke 5:2-3 TM). When you read the Bible you see that Jesus had a knack of making the most of absolutely every opportunity. Instead of getting freaked out by the crowds nearly pushing Him into the lake He just hops into a boat and brings His words of wisdom from a new vantage point. But it never would've happened if the guy who's boat this was, Peter, had got all shirty about it. Can you imagine? 'Hang about mate, what d'you think your doin' in my boat, I've had a rough night and then last thing I need is you and your fan club wrecking my beach.' Later in his life Peter wrote: '...You are royal priests...As a result, you can show others the goodness of God...' (1 Peter 2:9 NLT). So how does that fit in with the boat story? Well, what does a priest do? He represents God to people - and you're supposed to do that too - every minute of every day! Yes, there should be no time or place when Jesus can't use your life as a platform to communicate his amazing love. Listen to what Paul says, 'Let every detail in your lives - words, actions, whatever - be done in the name of the Master, Jesus...' (Colossians 3:17 TM). Old preacher Henry Giles once said, 'There is no task so low that we may not elevate it; so dull that we may not enliven it if we understand that what we are doing is service to our Lord Jesus Christ.' So, the word 4U 2day is - be a platform for Jesus.

content.title: Live = Serve (2)
content.introtext:
...THE SON OF MAN DID NOT COME TO BE SERVED, BUT TO SERVE...

MARK 10:45 NIV
Jesus entered the world to serve. And we should do the same. Whether it is our school-world, our work-world, our community-world or our church-world. Serving requires no special training or qualifications. Here's three things to know about serving: 1) To serve is to love the overlooked. Jesus sits in your class wearing thick glasses, outdated clothing and a sad face. You've seen Him. Jesus lives on your street, pregnant again, no one knows the father. You've seen her.
