If you haven't realized it already you will eventually, because the twists and turns of life have a way of teaching us - this world is not our home. We aren't fluent in its language and we aren't comfortable in its culture. This world promises a lot but only delivers a little. But that's okay - we have an eternal address written on our hearts: '[God] has...set eternity in the hearts of men...' (Ecclesiastes 3:11 NIV). But even though our eyes are fixed on heaven, the journey ahead of us is likely to be long, and there will be storms. Some of our dreams may well die along the way. Our bodies will eventually get weak and creaky. We'll see friends trip and fall on our right and our left. And there will be days when it's hard to see the city of blinding lights because of the thick black rain clouds. Yes, we want to go on, but some days the road seems too steep. So always, always, always remember this: God never said the journey would be easy, but He did say the arrival would be wonderful. So have faith in Him and in His amazing promises to you. Imagine that amazing feeling when the trials of the trip are forgotten in the joys of your heavenly welcome!

content.title: A lifetime guarantee
content.introtext:
SURELY YOUR GOODNESS AND UNFAILING LOVE WILL FOLLOW ME ALL THE DAYS OF MY LIFE...

PSALM 23:6 NIV
Goodness and unfailing love. God wants to do us good, we know that, but this is even better: because we all fail, we need to know that God's love never will. His feelings towards us are of passionate affection. And if that doesn't impress you, try this phrase: 'all the days of my life.' Think of the days that could lie ahead of you: getting married and keeping together, having kids and trying to raise them well, times of ill health and times of financial need. Listen: 'Goodness and unfailing love shall follow me all the days of my life.' All of them! And what will the Shepherd do during those days? He will pursue you. What a surprising way to describe God. We've got a funny picture of a God who lives in a distant place; who sits enthroned in the heavens and pushes buttons. But no, like a Shepherd who walks behind, gently coaxing His sheep forward, our Lord is always close to us. He tracks us down and wins us over. Have you sensed Him pursuing you? So often we miss Him; we don't know our Helper when He's near. Yet He's always there. Sometimes he might show himself through the kindness of a stranger; through the question of a child or the commitment of a loved one. And even when we wander this way and that, seemingly deaf to his voice, He still pursues. Never forcing us but never leaving us. He just keeps on walking and talking, convincing us that He is who He is, and that He can be trusted to lead us home. What more could we ask for?

content.title: He'll be with you!
content.introtext:
...THOUGH I WALK THROUGH THE VALLEY OF THE SHADOW OF DEATH...

PSALM 23:4 NKJ
Springtime grazing leaves the pasture bare. So, the shepherd leads his flock to richer grass, beyond the hills and into the mountains. Valleys are dark and deep. Jagged rocks can cut. Wild animals can attack. But the shepherd knows the path because he's walked it many times. Before King David led Israel, he led sheep. So he writes: '...though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil; for You are with me...' And what the shepherd does with his flock, God does with us. In every season of life we can trust God to lead us. And as each day fades into night we're getting closer to His house where we'll feel more at home than anywhere we've ever been. Jesus spoke about it in John, Chapter 14. The disciples didn't know it was His farewell message. No one did - but it was. He spoke about death: 'Don't let your hearts be troubled. Trust in God, and trust in me. There are many rooms in my Father's house; I would not tell you this if it were not true. I am going there to prepare a place for you. After I go and prepare a place for you, I will come back and take you to be with me so that you may be where I am' (John 14:1-3 NCV). What an arrangement, you have a personal guide through every stage of your earthly life, then your own suite in the best hotel in the universe! With Jesus as your Shepherd, you really do get the best of both worlds!

content.title: He's looking out for you
content.introtext:
THE LORD IS MY SHEPHERD...

PSALM 23:1
Jesus said, '"Suppose one of you had a hundred sheep and lost one. Wouldn't you leave the ninety nine in the wilderness and go after the lost one until you found it?"' (Luke 15:4 TM). Can you recall when you were that one lost sheep? Do you remember when Jesus found you? Where would you be without Him? Eighty percent of Jesus' listeners made their living off the land. Many were shepherds living in the countryside with their sheep. No flock ever grazed without a shepherd and no shepherd was ever off duty. When the sheep wandered, the shepherd found them. When they fell, he picked them up and carried them. When they were wounded, he fixed them up. Sheep aren't clever; they tend to stray into running creeks for water, then their wool gets wet and they can drown. They need a shepherd to lead them to '...still waters' (Psalm 23:2 KJV). They have no natural defence - no claws or sharp teeth. They need a shepherd with a big stick to protect them from predators (Psalm 23:4). They have no sense of direction. They need someone who knows the way to lead them '...On paths that are right...' (Psalm 23:3 NCV). So do we. We tend to get swept away in we should have avoided. We have no natural defence against our enemy who goes about as a '...roaring lion, seeking someone to devour' (1 Peter 5:8 NAS). And finally, we lose our way, don't we? No doubt about it, we need a shepherd. Not a cowboy to herd us, a true shepherd to lead us - and aren't you glad we have one looking out for us every minute of every day.

content.title: The hidden disciplines
content.introtext:
...DISCIPLINE YOURSELF FOR THE PURPOSE OF GODLINESS.

1 TIMOTHY 4:7 NAS
Disciplined people don't need cheering crowds to feed their hunger for excellence. Jascha Heifetz, perhaps the greatest violinist of the 20th century, practiced four hours every day, until his death at 87 years of age. That's more than 100,000 hours of practice, interrupted by occasional public performances! The great painter, Leonardo da Vinci, desired nothing less than anatomical perfection for his paintings. He spent countless hours studying the human body. For one painting he became so frustrated by his inability to paint the body as he wished that he drew thousands of hands until he felt it was just right. Centuries later we gaze in awe at his work but don't see the hours of preparation. We're not aware of the patient training of da Vinci's hand, eye and mind for the sake of those magnificent images. It's easy to forget that it's the discipline we didn't see, that made our most gifted musicians and artists the best at what they did. And what's true of them is also true for Christ-like people. If there's a person you respect because of their spirituality, you can be certain that person has practiced certain disciplines and rhythms. They weren't born that way. The life you respect and wish for yourself didn't automatically come with age, or a promotion to some position. No! They paid the cost for their spiritual depth - hours of trying, failing, and trying again; suffering through hardship; learning to rely on God, surrendering again and again Holy Spirit because they found life works better that way. This is why Paul encouraged Timothy, 'Discipline yourself for the purpose of godliness.'

content.title: How do you treat hurting people?
content.introtext:
"FEED THE HUNGRY! HELP THOSE IN TROUBLE!"

ISAIAH 58:10 TLB
'Don't get sidetracked by the pain or problems of others. After all, it's probably their own fault. They got themselves into the mess. They just need to find Jesus and the problem will solve itself. Anyway, I don't know anyone who's 'hungry' to feed and all my mates have clothes.' Who thinks like that? Sadly, some peeps who actually call themselves Christians! What happened to being committed and compassionate? Jesus wouldn't give an inch when it came to the truth, but watch Him around hurting people. He was '...moved with compassion...' (Matthew 9:36 KJV). Unfortunately, loads of us only moved with disgust - 'dirty tramp, he should just get a job'. But then that's easier, isn't it? That way we don't have to get our hands dirty, take risks, feel what it's like to hurt, or deal with the difficult side of an issue that has no easy answers. Many years ago God had a conversation with a very religious bunch of people. These people asked God, '"...Why don't you see our sacrifices? Why don't you hear our prayers?"' (Isaiah 58:3 TLB). God's answer should make us sit up and do some real soul-searching. He said, 'Feed the hungry! Help those in trouble! Then (and only then) the Lord will guide you continually, and satisfy you with all good things, and keep you healthy too.' Guidance. Security. Satisfaction. Health. And there's more! Jesus said that we'll all be evaluated and rewarded according to how we treat hurting people (see Matthew 25:34-40; Colossians 3:12-14; James 5:11). So ask yourself today: 'How do I treat them?'

content.title: We are managers, not owners
content.introtext:
THE EARTH IS THE LORD'S, AND EVERYTHING IN IT...

PSALM 24:1 NIV
Your attitude towards giving is like one of the warning lights on a car's dashboard. When one of those lights comes on, something under the bonnet needs attention before there's a breakdown. In the same way when God flashes on the indicator light of money and giving in your life, it's not because He's short of cash. No, He's pointing out something in your heart that you can't afford to ignore. And He wants to deal with it. You see, for as long as there have been Christians there have been stingy Christians! The book of Acts tells us a story about a married couple named Ananias and Sapphira who got greedy with the profit of their property sale, with some really heavy consequences (e.g. they ended up dead, see Acts 5:1-11). This is a pretty extreme example but that doesn't mean we can just ignore it. A stingy attitude doesn't just include sudden paralysis and inability to reach for your purse or wallet at offering time. It also means never offering to buy the coffees in Starbucks, or having a reputation for being the person who will never even offer you one of their chips! The attitude is basically selfish, 'This is mine and it's not for sharing'. So what's the answer? Well the best place to start is by realizing that you are a manager - not an owner. You're simply looking after what belongs to God, a job which is often more about distribution than warehousing! So when God asks you to give, regardless of how much, remember, He's just asking for what He already owns.

content.title: Heaven and the Simpsons
content.introtext:
...WHAT IS MORTAL MAY BE SWALLOWED UP BY LIFE

2 CORINTHIANS 5:4
One of the most difficult bits of the Bible to understand is the end of it. The book of Revelation is full of coded images whose meaning a lot of people fall out about. But there are two things that we can be certain of - Jesus is coming back, and He wins! So what might it be like at the end of the wolrd? Well this is where we can get a little bit of help from The Simpsons! There's an episode in which Homer accidentally transports himself to the 'Third Dimension'. One minute he's an ordinary 2 dimensional cartoon, the next he's a 3 dimensional CGI character - like Buzz Lightyear. He's really freaked out when he looks down at his belly and sees that it bulges so much! So what's this got to do with the end of the world as we know it? Well, think of what would happen if heaven crashed into earth (see Ephesians 1:9-10, Revelation 1:2-3). The thing about heaven is that it is eternal - it has more dimensions than earth. Got that? OK, now imagine earth is Homer, in 2D, but Heaven is in 3D, (no wonder the prophets in the Bible who had heavenly visions struggled to explain them, like Homer struggles to cope with being transformed from 2D to 3D) the result would be the most massive event ever, it would affect everything and everyone. Now, this is just an exercise in imagination, but the Bible does give us more clues about what this ultimate event will be like. It does say, '...what is mortal may be swallowed up by life' (2 Corinthians 5:4 NIV) - and whatever that really means it sounds exciting!

content.title: Let go!
content.introtext:
TRUST IN THE LORD...

PROVERBS 3:5 NIV
Have you ever tried to hold on to something really wriggly - like a hyperactive hamster? Or something slippery - like a frightened frog? It's practically impossible! So why do you think you can keep the people or circumstances of your life tightly in your grip? LET GO! Really, go ahead: surrender it to God. You'll be amazed at how much more energy you'll have, and how much simpler life will be. Once you make the choice to surrender it to God, those difficult days will soon seem like a distant memory. A Bible boffin called Tozer once wrote: 'Father, my cowardly heart fears to give up its toys. I cannot part with them without inward bleeding, and I do not try to hide from you my terror of the parting. I come trembling, but I do come. Please root from my heart those things which I have cherished so long and which have become a very part of my living self, so that you may enter and dwell there without a rival.' So, you say, 'Surrender what?' 1) Your Rep! What good is street cred compared to God cred? Find your security and your identity in Him. 2) Your plans! Sure, think ahead, but be ready for God to rearrange things and take you along a new path. Nothing this side of Heaven is permanent, including relationships. Enjoy the time you have with your mates and your loved ones, but avoid the temptation to get clingy. 3) Your stuff! If your attention is occupied with the stuff you own, your clothes, gadgets, exotic butterfly collection - whatever - you aren't fully available for God. No, you're still clinging to minor things. Stop. Let go! You're cluttering the awesome life God has made possible for you.

content.title: Deciding and doing
content.introtext:
...FROM THE ONE WHO HAS BEEN ENTRUSTED WITH MUCH, MUCH MORE WILL BE ASKED.

LUKE 12:48 NIV
As you read the Bible more and more, you'll begin to realize that God looks for people that He can trust with responsibility. The people who have been used by God in amazing ways are not just dreamers, they are doers. They are not those who play it safe, but those who get off the fence and get the job done - whatever the cost. Sometimes the decision to do nothing is wise, but you can't live your whole life like that! Don't be paralysed by the need to weigh everything too carefully. Don't make your catchphrase, 'On the one hand...but then again on the other.' There's an old saying about five frogs on a log. It's a hot day and four of them decide to jump off, into the cool water of the pond below. So how many frogs are left on the log? Five. Even though they reached a decision, they still couldn't be bothered to actually follow through with it. Make sure you keep working on trimming down that delay between deciding and doing. Finding and fulfilling God's destiny for your life means making decisions - tough decisions, lonely decisions, costly decisions, unpopular decisions, unpleasant decisions, and courageous decisions. It also means the end of excuse making: '...from the one who has been entrusted with much, much more will be asked.' You say you don't like how things are going in your life. Really? What are you going to do about it?

content.title: Discover what's inside you
content.introtext:
...LET'S JUST GO AHEAD AND BE WHAT WE WERE MADE TO BE...

ROMANS 12:6 TM
Fifty years ago The Golden Buddha was discovered in the city of Bangkok, Thailand. For years a huge, ugly, concrete Buddha had sat in a scruffy temple in a poor part of town. Then a wealthy developer bought the land on which the temple was built - the five ton statue had to be moved. In the process it cracked. As the pieces crumbled the engineers noticed something underneath the concrete shell, something shiny and metallic. They pulled the shell away and inside they found the world's largest chunk of sculptured gold, standing 10 feet high. For hundreds of years it had been there - but no one knew it. And you are a lot like that statue. Your real value is inside, if only you'd break out of that hard shell you're hiding in to protect yourself. Do you know that the things you achieve in your life flow out of the way you see yourself. If you think you're average, you'll perform in an average way. Once in a while you may have a great day and be really excellent. You might even think, 'That was awesome, I really outdid myself!' However, unless deep down you start believing in your God-given gifts, value and potential, you'll retreat to your old level of living because you think: 'That's not the real me.' That's just sad. Let's end today being inspired by the words of Paul; 'Since we find ourselves fashioned into all these excellently formed and marvellously functioning parts in Christ's body, let's just go ahead and be what we were made to be, without enviously or pridefully comparing ourselves with each other, or trying to be something we aren't' (Romans 12:5-6 TM).

content.title: Joseph and pizzas
content.introtext:
...GOD INTENDED IT FOR GOOD...

GENESIS 50:20 NIV
Have you ever been to a real pizzeria? Not the kind of place where everything is pre-packaged. No, the kind of place where they take a ball of dough, slam it down, twirl it around and flatten it. Only then do they think about putting all that good stuff on top. Think of yourself as pizza dough and God as the person working it. He's got some good stuff He wants to lay on you, but before He can do it He's got to knock you into shape. Take Joseph as an example. What happened to him wasn't fair! When your own family sells you as a slave and the new boss' wife has you banged up for sexual harassment, you've got a right to ask: 'God, what's going on?' Before God promoted Joseph to the palace he wanted to know how he'd hold up under pressure. And the same goes for you. Joseph was called to save his family and lead his nation. But big jobs call for big tests of character. Sadly, you don't always understand this when you're going through test though. Try to take this on board today though - in the end, it's worth it. When Joseph's brothers finally met him as ruler of Egypt he told them 'As far as I am concerned, God turned into good what you meant for evil. He brought me to the high position I have today so I could save the lives of many people' (See Genesis 50:20-21). Talk about seeing things clearly! Joseph's story shows us that someone else's action against you is not the end. God knows that somewhere down the line He'll be able to use all that painful stuff to bring your life into focus and make you a better person.

content.title: In the ordinary
content.introtext:
"HOW MANY LOAVES DO YOU HAVE?" HE ASKED. "GO AND SEE..."

MARK 6:38 NIV
Being a Christian is often about finding the extraordinary, within the ordinary. Opportunities for growth and blessing are constantly coming your way; how many do you let pass by unnoticed? How often do you stop and pray: 'Father, show me what I'm not seeing. Your Word says You can turn a curse into a blessing. If I can't change this right now, how can I use it to grow wiser and do better next time? Have You permitted this problem because You have the solution, but You want me to reach for You more passionately before You reveal it to me?' Before Jesus fed the five thousand He told His disciples (who'd decided to send the crowd away to find their own food), '...You give them something to eat' (Luke 9:13 NIV). They replied, '...That would take eight months of a man's wages!...' (Mark 6:37 NIV). That's when Jesus asked, '"How many loaves do you have?...Go and see..."' (Mark 6:38 NIV). They wanted to send the problem away - to take the easy way out. He challenges them to look for the extraordinary, in the ordinary. When you do that you recognize that God isn't sat on a cushion a million miles away having a pedicure. No, God is present and active in the world by his Holy Spirit, moving and motivating people. The key to this miracle was that God wasn't confined to the ministry of Jesus, he was moving on the heart of a young boy, stirring him to donate his lunch. When you've finished crying out to God in heaven, look around you. You'll probably find he's already prepared His answer, and its waiting for you here on earth.

content.title: It's time to pray!
content.introtext:
PRAY CONTINUALLY.

1 THESSALONIANS 5:17 NCV
Prayer is truly amazing; it's like having a hands-free kit to God! You might feel like your parents, teachers and brothers and sisters don't listen to you, but when you pray, God listens. It's the greatest privilege imaginable - a hotline to the control centre of the Universe - and its not a premium rate number - it's free! The Bible is full of people of prayer. When the people of Israel dissed God by worshipping a golden calf, Moses prayed and saved them from the destruction God had every right to bring on them. One translation of Exodus 32.11 says, 'Moses soothed the face of his God'. Through the prophet Ezekiel, God described the sort of prayer warrior he's looking for: 'I sought for a man among them who would...stand in the gap before Me on behalf of the land, that I should not destroy it; but I found no one' (Ezekiel 22:30 NLT). Let's not let that be the story of this generation! You might wonder why God puts such importance on prayer? The simple answer is that God loves being in a friendship with us. It's almost as if our passion stirs up his passion. If our prayers don't move us how can we expect them to move him? Also, remember that prayer isn't just a private thing - it's great to pray with your mates. Listen: 'When two of you get together on anything...and make a prayer of it, My Father in heaven goes into action' (Matthew 18:19 TM). Does any other activity promise such results? Get texting your friends straight away - it's time to pray!

content.title: Ready 2 change?
content.introtext:
I PRESS ON TOWARD THE GOAL...

PHILIPPIANS 3:14 NIV
People who drive forward progress in the world are often called an 'agent of change'. If you want to become an agent of change, first of all you yourself must change! And it isn't to do with your intelligence, your looks or your family background; it's all about your attitude. You have an advantage today, because you're young and young people cope much better with change than people who are getting on a bit. Young people are excellent learners and are still full of creativity. 'The system' hasn't crushed all your good ideas yet; and you must make sure you never let it! So what can you see in the world around you that needs to change? Is bullying a problem at your school? Can you start a campaign to stop it? Are people in your college ignorant about trade justice? Can you get them to shop fair trade? An agent for change looks at the world around, sees how it could be better, then does something about it. It's the best way to live your life and the sooner you start, the more you'll achieve in your lifetime. The apostle Paul was an awesome agent of change. Near the end of his life, he wrote: '...Forgetting what is behind and straining toward what is ahead, I press on toward the goal to win the prize for which God has called me...' (Philippians 3:13-14 NIV). Paul learned from his past, but he refused to live in it. You can just imagine him waking up every day and thinking to himself, 'It's a new day full of possibilities; Lord help me to max every moment!' What would life be like if you got out of bed with that kind of attitude?

content.title: Who wants 2B a teacher? (2)
content.introtext:
THEY ARE LIKE TREES PLANTED ALONG THE RIVERBANK...

PSALM 1:3 NLT
When you start passing on what you've learnt to other people you'll find that your own development speeds up too. You start understanding things more deeply. You see, the truth doesn't change, but your understanding of it should. Howard Hendricks writes; 'When I was a college student ...I worked in the dining hall. On my way to work at 5.30 each morning I walked past the home of one of my professors. Through a window I could see a light on at his desk. He was pouring over his books. One day he invited me home for lunch and I said: "Would you mind if I asked you a question? What keeps you studying? You never seem to stop." He answered "Son, I would rather have my students drink from a running stream than a stagnant pool."' Do you want to be a teacher? Then make sure you are always in the flow of the freshest ideas available. The Bible says, 'they are like trees planted along the riverbank.' It's a poetic picture of what it's like to be a person who is close to God and soaked in His Word. If you want to teach others you must first ask God to teach you. Peter writes: '...grow in ...grace and knowledge...' (2 Peter 3:18 NIV). This requires the attitude that you haven't yet 'arrived.' Being a teacher doesn't mean you are a know-it-all. It doesn't mean you have to be able to answer every difficult question. It just means you are willing to pass on what you have learned yourself. So, if you want to strengthen your teaching, do everything in your power to strengthen the teacher - you!

content.title: Who wants 2B a teacher? (1)
content.introtext:
YOU, HOWEVER, KNOW ALL ABOUT MY TEACHING, MY WAY OF LIFE...

2 TIMOTHY 3:10 NIV
Teachers don't have it easy! Every day they're dealing with young people who are up one minute and down the next. Their day starts early and their schedule is packed. So would you want to be a teacher? Well you can be - but maybe not at the front of a classroom. Anybody who helps other people to learn about something is a teacher. Now, a teacher isn't a teacher without students. The relationship between teachers and their pupils is really important. If the relationship is tense or awkward nobody is going to learn very much. So, if you think you have a talent to teach, know your students. That takes commitment and time. Good teaching has a price tag: you've got to be willing to give out your energy for others. It's cheesy but true. People don't care how much you know, until they know how much you care. Next, you need to earn the right to be heard. Credibility must precede communication. In our celebrity society everything is fake. People want to know if you are for real. That will mean being willing to become vulnerable. It's the broken who become masters at mending. Don't be afraid to let people know what you're struggling with, and what you've struggled with through the years. It will help you no end if people begin to get a grip of who you are in terms of who you are now, in relation to where you come from and what you've been through. And never be afraid to talk about the God you know personally, and what He's done for you. That'll make an impact every time!

content.title: When hope comes to town
content.introtext:
...A TIME IS COMING AND HAS NOW COME...

JOHN 4:23 NIV
Phase one: Hopeless. This woman had lived through five failed marriages, become the embarrassment of the town, and lost her ability to trust others or respect herself. Then Jesus showed up. As soon as Jesus spoke to her she knew that this was no ordinary conversation - no ordinary man. His words began giving her a glimpse into another world, the kind of world she'd given up believing in years before. Jesus was describing a world in which relationships are restored, religious divisions are ended and satisfaction is deep and lasting. And when Jesus mentioned this woman's past He wasn't pointing an accusing finger. No, He was the Good Shepherd walking for miles to find one lost sheep. Like a caring nurse He poured healing love into her deepest wounds. He opened a door out of her misery and into the life she always longed for. Phase two: Hope. This woman knew the real thing when she saw it. Suddenly she knew that despite her past, her future could be different; she seized her moment! When Jesus said, '...the water I give them takes away thirst altogether. It becomes a perpetual spring, giving them eternal life.' 'Please, sir,' the woman said, 'give me some of that water!...' (John 4:14-15 NLT). She reached by faith and received what He had for her. Then redeemed, recycled and redirected, this woman with a questionable past went back to her village to tell other people about Jesus You know something - what Jesus did for her He'll do for you. What He said to her He says to you: 'Your time has come. Your breakthrough is at hand. Believe it, receive it and walk in it.'

content.title: Stay sharp!
content.introtext:
...THE DULLER THE AXE THE HARDER THE WORK

ECCLESIASTES 10:10 TM
Did you hear about the two lumberjacks who challenged each other to see which one could cut down more trees in a day? At daybreak the first one began furiously chopping down trees. He worked up a sweat and by noon he had cut down eight trees. Meanwhile the other lumberjack had only cut down four, because he took the first two hours to sharpen his axe. As he sharpened it, his challenger laughed at him thinking 'Why is he wasting so much time - he's handed me this contest on a plate!" That's when things got interesting. By early afternoon the first lumberjack was slowing down. It took him almost an hour to cut down one tree, while the second guy was picking up speed. The first lumberjack started to get worried. He was definitely as strong as this other guy. But strength wasn't the deciding factor. It was all about whose axe was sharper. The sharper the axe the quicker the trees came down. By late afternoon the second lumberjack who'd sharpened his axe, had taken the lead by several trees and won easily. There's an important lesson there for you. Your striving to get stuff done in your own strength may work for a while, but eventually it will leave you dull; emotionally and mentally. It's up to you to make sure you don't lose your edge and miss what God has for you next! So are you getting the message, don't be in a rush to jump straight in to everything. You may just need to hang back for a while and make sure that before you start God sharpens you up for the job!

content.title: Not a spectator sport
content.introtext:
...STOOP DOWN...TO THOSE WHO ARE OPPRESSED...

GALATIANS 6:2 TM
In the early days of the Special Olympics, nine competitors lined up to run the 100m dash. Everyone took off, eagerly but one soon stumbled, and fell. A couple of the others saw it happen. They stopped, turned around and helped him up. Then they all proceeded to cross the finish line together. It was a totally unique sporting moment. Nothing like that is going to happen in the regular Olympics! Some years ago a sports magazine carried the photo of a famous woman runner, holding her leg in agony after falling on the track as the others raced past her. What made the Special Olympic runners come back for their friend who'd fallen? Because they realized that they had weaknesses too. They knew it could have been any one of them lying there on the track, so they reached out to him. In a very real sense the three runners who came in last deserved the medals that day. If the runners in the regular Olympics had gone back to the woman who fell, helped her up, then crossed the finish line together, they may not have won. But they would have grown as human beings that day. God is more interested in our growth, than in the medals we win for ourselves. Are you getting the idea? We only grow in grace as we run together, stopping to lift and encourage each other along the way, and finish victoriously together. That's why it's so important for you to be connected to, and committed to, a local church where being a Christian is more than just a spectator sport!

content.title: What you see
content.introtext:
...I SAW A VISION...

ACTS 11:5 NIV
Before others catch the vision, it's born in the heart of one person. That's the way it's always been, even if we go back 4000 years. Before one Hebrew slave caught the vision of the Promised Land, Moses 'saw' it. He saw his people no longer bound by chains, free to build homes, grow crops and worship God. But his vision was clouded by frustration and anger. Time in the desert helped him to see things more clearly. The Bible says: '...he persevered because he saw him who is invisible' (Hebrews 11:27 NIV). For many years Moses was sustained by what he saw. And your vision, if it's of God, will also sustain you through the desert times. God often gives a vision bigger than we are. Then He'll gather a team around that vision - people with different strengths and abilities. He gave Joshua to Moses to be his young assistant. He gave him Aaron to speak persuasively and Miriam to lead worship. He gave him his father-in-law, Jethro, to save him from a leader's most dreaded fate - death by admin. Finally He gave him 70 more leaders with the right 'spirit' to complete the job. Moses was a unique guy with a unique job to do. This story is an amazing inspiration - and not because he was perfect. No, Moses struggled with being human too. But he allowed his life to be used for God's higher purposes. He knew his life had no point if it wasn't fully available for Him. When you surrender your life to God you'll discover something wonderful - God's not limited by your limitations!

content.title: Limited by our senses
content.introtext:
WE WALK BY FAITH, NOT BY SIGHT.

2 CORINTHIANS 5:7 NAS
The reason many of us aren't growing spiritually is because our faith doesn't reach beyond our sight. Real faith begins where our senses end. When we can see how something will happen, we usually don't feel the need to trust God for it. And since we can't see very far, living by sight keeps us living small. Think of the African impala; it's an amazing deer-like animal that can leap 10 foot (3m) high and 30 (9m) feet out with just one jump. But did you know that you can put that impala in a three-foot (90cm) high cage with no roof and it will not even try to escape, even though it has more than enough power to clear the cage. That's because the impala won't jump if it cannot see where its feet are going to land. The impala lives by sight, so it's easy to keep it caged. The same goes for you! But having faith isn't just about a blind belief in anything! Some children believe in the Tooth Fairy but that doesn't make it real. FAITH MUST BE BASED ON TRUTH. As Christians we CAN say 'God, I know that whenever You speak You're telling the truth, and I can stake my life on it.' Faith establishes what we believe about God. Too many of us act like we've more confidence in ourselves than we do in Him. If faith is the decision to grab hold of the power and promises of God, then if our faith is lacking we won't see the supernatural work of God in our lives - and we'll live in the natural with all its limitations.

content.title: Be a friend who prays
content.introtext:
...WHEN A BELIEVING PERSON PRAYS, GREAT THINGS HAPPEN.

JAMES 5:16 NCV
The Book of Mark says: 'Four men arrived carrying a paralysed man on a mat. They couldn't get to Jesus through the crowd, so they dug through the clay roof above his head...they lowered the sick man on his mat, right down in front of Jesus. Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the paralysed man, "My child, your sins are forgiven"' (Mark 2:3-5 NLT). The word prayer doesn't show up once in this paragraph. But look closely and you'll see it in action; four men lowering their sick mate through the roof into the presence of Jesus. He stops preaching, looks at the man and then announces, 'My child, your sins are forgiven.' What stirred Jesus? Mark answers, 'Seeing their faith.' The faith of four friends triggered Jesus' power on his behalf. This guy had no movement, no treatment, no answers, and no hope. But what he does have is friends who know how to lift him into the presence of Jesus. The paralytic might be thinking 'don't drop me!' The homeowner might be groaning 'I never asked for an extreme makeover on my roof! But Jesus? He was smiling! Their faith stirred His strength. He healed the man. The paralytic left the house with a clean soul and strong body. Faithful friends carry those they love in prayer, into God's presence. And when they do God responds. How? When? The four men didn't know. And we don't know either, but we know this: 'When a believing person prays, great things happen.' So be that kind of friend. Go ahead, carry your loved ones into the presence of Jesus, then watch what happens!

content.title: Thriving in tough circumstances
content.introtext:
HE GREW UP...LIKE A ROOT OUT OF DRY GROUND...

ISAIAH 53:2 NIV
Isaiah points out that Jesus sprang up '...like a root out of dry ground...' Now there are not many plants that can 'spring up' when there's no water. That is a hard thing to do. So what was Isaiah talking about? He was talking about the fact that it was seriously tough for Jesus to 'spring up'. God left heaven, got dressed up in a man's body, lived among a bunch of people who wanted to kill Him, lived in a nasty environment filled with betrayers and religious hypocrites and battled it out with satan. Unsurprisingly, Jesus had to get away a lot - not far away - just into some private space with His Father. Jesus needed to physically separate Himself from what was going on, even though He was involved emotionally and spiritually. How do you live a perfect life in a place where your own people despise, reject and ultimately crucify you? Jesus spent loads of time in prayer and always came back encouraged and ready for battle. Jesus always kept one thing in mind: He came to do His Father's will. That was His thing, it got Him through and it put Him on the cross. It was Jesus' main focus, top priority and by sticking to that 100% He never went wrong, not even once. Jesus also said that as the Father had sent Him, '"...so send I you"' (John 20:21 KJV). How's that for challenge? Not only was it Jesus' job to do God's will, it's ours too! That should be OUR focus, OUR top priority and by sticking to that we can't go far wrong either!

content.title: How's your prayer life?
content.introtext:
PRAY WITHOUT CEASING.

1 THESSALONIANS 5:17 KJV
Prayer's not a monologue where one person does all the talking, or a ritual where we've got to say things in the right order, or a job to get out of the way like brushing our teeth before going bed. So how does Jesus teach prayer? '"...Find a quiet, secluded place so you won't be tempted to role-play before God. Just be there as simply and honestly as you can manage. The focus will shift from you to God, and you will begin to sense His grace"' (Matthew 6:6 TM). For loads of people, prayer has nothing to do with real life. They think of it like the National Anthem at a footie game: a nice opening, but nothing to do with what happens on the pitch afterwards. Other people treat prayer like a lucky charm you pull out and rub when things are tough: 'A prayer a day keeps the devil away.' Paul writes, 'Pray without ceasing.' Man that's a lot of prayer! That definitely isn't something you do once in a while, or something you have to remember to say before bed. Try sticking the word breathe there instead of pray: 'breathe without ceasing' - there are not many people who can manage that for long! We don't breathe only when we feel like it; or decide, 'I can't be bothered with oxygen today,' and stop breathing. We don't get frustrated and say, 'This isn't getting me anywhere. I'm not going to do it any more.' No, we cling to the breath in our bodies like it's life. So, just as breathing isn't an optional part of your natural life, prayer isn't an optional part of your spiritual life. Without it you die spiritually. So, how's your prayer life?

content.title: The God-given ability to succeed
content.introtext:
...IT IS [GOD] THAT GIVES YOU THE ABILITY [IDEAS AND CREATIVITY] TO PRODUCE WEALTH...

DEUTERONOMY 8:18 NIV
Do you want your life to count in God's big plan for the planet? 1) GET SERIOUSLY CREATIVE: When God gives you the ability to succeed, it often begins as an idea. But remember you have to do something with that idea, make a plan, talk to people, get it done! Your idea (or someone else's) might come from God. Stop and think: if God's a creator and we are made in His likeness, shouldn't we be creative too? 2) GET USING YOUR GIFTS: The gift God gave you is your key to success. He didn't give it to you to be wasted on stuff that has no point or purpose or denied out of a false sense of humility. No, He gave it to you to be invested-to be used! Jesus told the story of three blokes who were given money to invest. The first two doubled theirs; the third buried his in the ground because he was afraid of messing it up. Look out! Fear is one of your greatest enemies. It numbs your spirit and bangs up your creativity. Use what God's given you. Trust God and take some risks. 3) GET ON WITH IT!: OK, sometimes it's wise to wait. But lots of the time being over cautious will just lead to missed opportunities, disappointments and regrets. Your friends and leaders can help you work this out. But if you know in your 'knower' that God has told you do something for Him, if you've got the ideas and the gifts, don't make excuses, get on with it! Make it happen. Seize the day. Grab the 'now' moments of your life - the 'right time' you're waiting for may never arrive.

content.title: Fakin' it
content.introtext:
...I HAVE FINISHED MY COURSE...

2 TIMOTHY 4:7 KJV
Be yourself. Life's too short to be anything else. Paul said 'I have finished my course.' It's important that you run the race God gave you (not many sprinters try to win marathons!!). Have you ever seen the movie 'Catch Me If You Can'? It's based on a true story. Frank Abagnale Jr lived a mad life as a doctor, airline pilot, lawyer and celebrity (collecting bucks and babes on the way.) But it was all a con. He might deserve an Oscar for all his frontin', but the truth is he was a fraud. It all began early in his life when he realized he'd the talent to convince people he was 'somebody' through his sheer confidence and acting ability. He began to make shed loads of cash and soon found himself addicted to faking it. Before it was over he'd helped perform surgery in an operating room, conned banks out of thousands of dollars, flown an airplane as a pilot, and gone places most people only dream of going. The problem was - it was all a show. A few years into it he wanted out. The glamour was gone. He was desperate to come clean and be real. But he had created such a web of lies that it wasn't easy. The FBI was onto him, and he ended up spending years in prison. Frank had a great talent, but he wasted it pretending to be someone else. Sometimes it's easier to put on a front but God's blessing will only be seen in your life when you're committed to being who He called you to be. To live any other way is to be lonely, fearful and unfulfilled. So, be yourself!

content.title: If you plan to do it - do it now!
content.introtext:
...WHAT IS YOUR LIFE? YOU ARE A MIST THAT APPEARS FOR A LITTLE WHILE AND THEN VANISHES.

JAMES 4:14 NIV
Coral reefs are the earth's oldest living organisms, some have been alive for a hundred thousand years. Certain olive trees in the Mediterranean live for over 1000 years. Most other living things burn out much more quickly. Bowhead whales can live up to 200 years. Giant turtles are still young at 100. 'What about me?' If you lived in Africa you might not make 50, but in Europe you should hit 70 at least. That sounds pretty good if you're young, but it soon starts slipping away when you get past the half-way point! The Bible says your life is like a mist, and mists aren't known for their permanence; just a puff of little breeze and there gone! So why are you still waiting? You don't have forever, get at it! You say you've always wanted to play the piano; stop talking about it and start taking lessons! Or that you've always dreamed of going on a mission to Africa; so get in touch with a mission agency. You say you hate your bedroom wallpaper. Quit complaining; scrape it off and paint it the colour you like! You say you feel better when you exercise; start jogging! Or that you're angry about the way your local newspaper always prints bad news about young people; so write them a letter! If you flick back right to the beginning of your Bible you'll see that there was once a time when God allowed people to live 10 times longer than they do now. But that time is long since over. So get out of neutral and get going! Put your life into God's hands and let Him show you what He can do with it!

content.title: The most incredible book ever written (2)
content.introtext:
"THE WORD OF THE LORD WILL LIVE FOREVER..."

1 PETER 1:25 NCV
Voltaire, the French sceptic, once wrote from his Paris office: 'I will go through the forest of Scripture and girdle all the trees so that in one hundred years Christianity will be but a vanishing memory.' In a hilarious twist of divine irony, the room he wrote that in was later bought by the British and Foreign Bible Society and packed with Bibles. What book can possibly be a rival to the Bible? Some people are impressed by the Best Selling book charts. The Da Vinci Code has remained near the top of this chart for a few years now. But what if a book is Number One for 300 years? Your Bible is the most widely published and translated book in history - available in over 2000 different dialects. Why? Because it works! Put it's words into action in any part of your life and see what happens. a) apply it to your finances. Manage your money the way the Bible says: give, save, give to the needy, don't waste it. Give it a try and see the results b) try it where you spend you days, in work or at school or college. Follow the Bible's code of work conduct. Be honest. Be on time. Be efficient. You may just do very well! c) test the Bible on your relationships. Forgive your enemies. Refuse to diss other people. Do all you can to be at peace with everyone. Be quick to listen and slow to speak d) but most of all, apply the Bible to your soul. '...There's nothing like the written Word of God for showing you the way to salvation...' (2 Timothy 3:15 TM).

content.title: The most incredible book ever written (1)
content.introtext:
"THE WORD OF THE LORD WILL LIVE FOREVER..."

1 PETER 1:25 NCV
Imagine a museum of art commissions a painting to be painted by 40 different artists. They work in their different studios with know idea what everyone else was doing. Yet when all 40 canvasses are put together on one wall like a giant jigsaw, they create the perfect landscape. What are the chances? Or imagine 40 architects set out to design one building. Some of them know what others are doing - others are clueless that anyone else is doing anything at all. When they gather to put together notes, the result is a magnificent blueprint. Doesn't sound likely does it? But it did with the Bible. William Gladstone, Prime Minister of England, stated: 'I have known 95 great men in my time. And of these, 87 were followers of the Bible.' No publisher commissioned the Bible. No committee outlined it. No earthly editor oversaw it. Though separated by 16 centuries, and written by a random assortment of kings, soldiers, shepherds, farmers and fishermen, from Moses in the Arabian desert to John on the windswept island of Patmos - one theme threads the Bible together. That theme is eternal life through Jesus Christ. Your Bible is the most incredible book ever written. Each day that passes validates Peter's prophecy: 'The Word of the Lord will live forever.' The question is: does it live in your heart? Does it affect how you live? Does it set your priorities? Do you hunger for it? Can you say 'Oh how I love your law! I meditate on it all day long' (Psalm 119:97 NIV)?

content.title: Focus on the new, not the old!
content.introtext:
...THE OLD HAS GONE, THE NEW HAS COME!

2 CORINTHIANS 5:17 NIV
What loads of us haven't yet grasped is that God really isn't trying to polish you up to make you better. When a car gets to a certain state, you have to start thinking, 'is it really worth repairing, or would I be better getting a new one? Not many people go to the effort of doing up a beat up old banger! When we became Christians, God decided to scrap the old us. It wasn't worth trying to repair the broken bits, so he scrapped it and gave us a brand spanking new, top of the range life - with all the special features! We've got an insurance policy for life, fuel that will never run out, no speed limit - we can go as far and as fast as we want to. God doesn't want us to try to use will power, or guilt or pure effort to live a new life. He wants us to have the best. The life God has for us is unfailing, everlasting and the best you can get. When God asks you to work on something in your life, don't try to fix an old problem, throw it away and fill yourself with Jesus. Focus on Him and accept you are new, you don't have to do that old stuff anymore, you don't have to live with that old problem anymore. You can live a new life, a new way. Paul writes, 'For it is God who works in you to will and to act according to his good purpose' (Philippians 2:13 NIV). Our job is just to get as close as you can to God and do what He asks.

content.title: Do you practice humility?
content.introtext:
BUT IT IS NOT SO AMONG YOU...

MARK 10:43 NAS
Wouldn't it be ace if just being around humble people automatically made us humble. The disciples proved it didn't. In the Bible, Mark tells a story involving James and John, two brothers; a story that makes most parents nod and smile. It happened before John got all mature - still a disciple, still young, and still not quite getting it: '...James and John...came to Him..."Teacher...Let one of us sit at your right and the other at your left in glory.'' Jesus replied: "You don't know what you are asking..."' (Mark 10:35-38 NIV). Then He got the disciples together and said, '"...You've observed how godless rulers throw their weight around, he said, and when people get a little power how quickly it goes to their heads. It's not going to be that way with you..."' (Mark 10:42-43 TM). Our world is run by chain of command. In workplaces there can be Directors, Executives, Managers, Team Leaders and then everybody else. Jesus barely took a breath after comparing the two kingdoms, then added, 'It's not going to be that way with you.' In God's Kingdom there's no ladder to climb. The poor don't pamper the privileged - quite the opposite. Once He got their attention, Jesus spelled it out, '"...whoever wishes to be great...shall be your servant"' (Mark. 10:43 NAS). Genuinely humble people have one thing in common - they don't think of themselves as humble! In fact, they rarely think of themselves at all! They're too busy with doing what God wants and looking after others. So, do you practice humility?

content.title: Your growth - God's glory!
content.introtext:
...TO HIM BE GLORY...

2 PETER 3:18 NIV
After writing, 'Grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord...' Peter adds: '...To him be glory...' Ever thought about what that means? We all want to grow and get good at stuff to have people admire us but, actually, our reason for growing should be totally for God's glory! Paul writes, '...glorify God in your body, and in your spirit...' (1 Corinthians 6:20 KJV). Why does it matter how we live, what we do and how people see us? Because we're supposed to reflect God's glory! The problem is, we're always focussed on what we're doing instead of God and His glory. Imagine 50,000 fans at Old Trafford singing 'Glory, Glory, Man Utd' at the tops of their voices; well the way we act should be like a there's a huge crowd around us singing 'Glory, Glory, Jesus Christ!' It should be really obvious in all we do that God's glory just flows out of us. So what are we supposed to do? Draw attention to God. Promote Him. God wants to go public. Since He's invisible, He's created people whose full time job is to make Him visible so that everyone can see Him. Companies who want to be seen don't just stick a one-liner in the yellow pages, they go for prime time TV. We are billboards advertising God's grace to a screwed up world. He wants us to grow so that we can display Him more. In fact, God has trusted us with His public image. Bigging up God is our most awesome privilege and responsibility. Think we're exaggerating? Paul writes, 'Whether you eat or drink or whatever you do, do it all for the glory of God' (1 Corinthians 10:31 NIV).

content.title: Starving bakers
content.introtext:
"I AM THE BREAD OF LIFE. HE WHO COMES TO ME WILL NEVER GO HUNGRY..."

JOHN 6:35 NIV
Imagine finding a new bakery. You love going there because the baker creates amazing sandwiches, pasties and cakes, better than any you've ever tasted. Soon word gets out and crowds start gathering. The baker doesn't have enough help and ends up trying to serve all the customers herself. Gradually you see a change. She's getting thin. Very thin! What's up? You decide to sit and watch. Suddenly the problem becomes obvious. She's busy serving everyone else but never stops long enough to feed herself. Even with food all around her, she's starving. Can you relate? This is a problem which loads of people have, they spend so much time looking after, teaching, serving, encouraging and doing things for other people that they never stop to take time out for themself! If this is something you recognise in yourself or people you're close to, it's your job to do something about it! This is what Jesus did: 'After He had dismissed the multitude, He went up into the hills by Himself to pray...' (Matthew 14:23 AMP). Jesus spent time with God, he knew it was total priority. If it's you, take some time out, be with Jesus. If it's a family member, try to talk to them or even find a way to free up some time for them! Tell your mum to put her feet up while you make tea. Offer to do the shopping or wash the car. If it's a leader, tell them they need time out and the rest of you will survive without them for one day. Who ever it is, take action!

content.title: Keep your sense of humour
content.introtext:
HE WILL YET FILL YOUR MOUTH WITH LAUGHTER...

JOB 8:21 NIV
One of the best ways to reduce stress, is to keep your sense of humour. Don't panic, don't overreact, and don't use unnecessary force. If you do people will avoid you. Happy people get more done than their oh-so-serious counterparts. Actually, being joyful can make a total difference to life, how you see it and how people are with you. Would you rather buy something from a stressed-out, mardy or nasty salesman, or someone who's good to be around? Would you rather hang out with someone who's worrying or moaning or miserable or someone that'll always cheer you up? 'A cheerful heart is good medicine...' (Proverbs 17:22 NIV). However, remember these things when it comes to humour: Make sure your jokes are at no one else's expense. Don't make jokes about things that people might be sensitive about. Weight, bad hairdos and being a bit slow might make some people laugh, but to the people being joked about, even if they laughed it probably hurt them inside. No one likes to be the butt of the joke. Be careful with teasing and don't joke about people you don't really like as a sly way of undermining them. It is not a good thing to turn every one and everything into a joke. It's always wise to let the joke be on you; you know you're not going to offend yourself! So don't be a joker all the time, there are times when it's just not appropriate. Love people; if they know you love them, they'll love to laugh with you.

content.title: Be an encourager!
content.introtext:
PLEASANT WORDS ARE...HEALING...

PROVERBS 16:24 NIV
Tom had a rough time in school. He just couldn't keep up. Eventually his teacher gave up on him, called his mum and told her to take him home because he couldn't learn and would never amount to much. But Tom's mum had a different opinion - she was a nurturer; she believed in him. She taught him at home, and every time he screwed up she gave him hope and encouraged him to keep trying. Tom grew up and became an inventor creating all sorts of things including the electric light bulb! Yeah, you guessed right - his name was Thomas Edison. How good is that? When people have love and hope, there's no telling how far they can go! Solomon writes: 'Pleasant words are like a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.' So, what about your words? Do they build up or tear down? How do people feel when they're around you? Do they feel small and rubbish, or do they want to be around you because you make them feel they can be somebody? The Bible is the ultimate book of hope. It tells us that Jonah got a second chance to go back to Nineveh and the whole city turned to God (see Jonah 3:1); that the Prodigal Son came back from a wasted life and was restored to his family (see Luke 15:11); and that Peter, the man who screwed over his best friend and Lord, became an awesome leader in the New Testament church. Do you want to become great in God's Kingdom? Become an encourager, a nurturer, and a restorer!

content.title: Who do you have? (2)
content.introtext:
TWO ARE BETTER THAN ONE...

ECCLESIASTES 4:9 NIV
Who protects you? When the Christians in Jerusalem wanted nothing to do with the newly converted Saul of Tarsus, Barnabas acted on his behalf. You don't have enough voices. You need others to speak up for you. Who shares your tears? Mary of Bethany was the only person in the room who understood what Jesus was going through as He came closer to His hour of death. Only she shared His tears. Who's close to you? Close enough to pick up on the signals, to sense when fears and tears need to be shared? Sure, there are times when we need a kick up the bum, but there are also times when we need to be encouraged to lie low, to process our emotions. Who does that for you? Who challenges you? Is somebody able to say 'you shouldn't have done that'? Even with 20/20 vision, one pair of eyes is not enough. You have blind spots. Satan is always ready to remind you of your faults and failings. But a true friend is the one who exposes and challenges any selfishness, self-dependence, and helps you to give God back the control over your life. Who has a laugh with you? Does this sound wrong, even sinful? What! You must never let the seriousness of life overrule your having fun and chilling out, actually enjoying life! Who seeks God with you? Praying together keeps us honest. It also keeps us dependent on God. We don't wanna open up, to get real about our areas of struggle. Yet it's only in the honesty of shared prayer that we move closer to God - and to one another.

content.title: Who do you have? (1)
content.introtext:
TWO ARE BETTER THAN ONE...

ECCLESIASTES 4:9 NIV
Father Edward Farrell said, 'Listening is rare. There are certain people to whom we feel we can talk because they have such a deep capacity for hearing, not just our words, but hearing us as a person. They enable us to communicate on a level we've never reached before. They enable us to be as we've never been before. We will never truly know ourselves unless we find people who can listen, who can enable us to emerge, to come out of ourselves, to discover who we are. We cannot discover ourselves by ourselves.' Note the words 'There are certain people...who enable us to be as we have never been before.' Those are the people you need most. Think about these questions: Who coaches you? What older, wiser, and more experienced person stands watching, waving and encouraging you on? A coach doesn't try to run the race for you. No, he sets the standard for the race and tells you how you did. Who does this for you? Who stretches your mind? Who points out you're not quite as good as you like to think; who won't let you get away with being a muppet? Who listens to and encourages your dreams? Dreams often don't make sense, they're not supposed to. They're the work of visionaries; they are out-of-the-box, usually awful and occasionally good. These are the people who, when others laugh and say you're dreaming, you've got no hope, remind you that God '...calls those things which are not, as though they were' (see Romans 4:17 NIV). These are the people you need!

content.title: Hungering for God's Word
content.introtext:
LIKE NEWBORN BABIES, LONG FOR THE PURE MILK OF THE WORD, THAT BY IT YOU MAY GROW...

1 PETER 2:2 NAS
Babies cry. It's what they do. They cry and cry until the milk arrives! The fact that mum's tired and stressed doesn't matter. When that baby is ready to eat, the world stops. Peter calls the Bible 'pure milk,' which means it's full of wholesome goodness - none of that skimmed, watered down stuff. Pure milk is the opposite of a dummy, which looks real but provides no nourishment. Too many of us are not growing strong in God because we're feeding on substitutes. We've got a dummy stuck in and haven't realised there's no milk coming from it! Don't get fooled into accepting anything but the authentic, full fat truth of Scripture. Reading the W4 U2D each day is great, but it's only a snack, its no substitute for the Bible - your proper meal. Christian books and CD's are like nice treats, but not your balanced diet. What's more, babies don't drink for 2 hours on a Sunday morning, they're always feeding. Babies eat all the time for one reason - they're hungry. We don't feed on God's Word more because we're not hungry for it, we've settled for a dummy. Get this: without a big fat daily plateful of God's Word, you'll end up stunted, weak and very, very vulnerable. We need to remind ourselves what's good for us. Even if you'd prefer a snack, get your staple food first. And if you struggle to understand it, get another version! There are loads of versions of the Bible written in different styles, yes, even ones you can understand! Today's lesson; take out the dummy and get the milk.

content.title: When God puts you on hold (3)
content.introtext:
WAIT FOR THE LORD; BE STRONG...

PSALM 27:14 NRS
If you've been on a load of planes, chances are you're familiar with the term 'holding pattern.' That's when your plane can't land because of bad ground conditions. Generally the pilot announces that he's been told to maintain a holding pattern while waiting an update from the control tower. It happens regularly, so planes have to carry enough fuel to stay airborne till they can land safely. The Bible says, 'Wait for the Lord; be strong...let your heart take courage...' When God puts you in a holding pattern it's not just a question of having enough faith to receive His promise, it's also a matter of having enough 'spiritual staying power' to stay airborne until your day comes. That's why you need to carry enough spiritual fuel to handle delays and wait for clearance. The Bible refers to the Holy Spirit as '...a rushing mighty wind...' (Acts 2:2 KJV). Anytime a wind comes from the presence of God it blows away anything that was in its path, it dries the ground under your feet so you can move ahead. It gets rid of the spirit of fear and even frustration that makes you want to quit. David asked God, '...Why do you take care of human beings?' (Psalm 8:4 NCV). Even in times of frustration and waiting, God is still thinking about you and working everything out for your good. His delays aren't denials. So, when your spirit senses a change in the wind, be happy, it's a sign that He's clearing you to land and good things are about to happen!

content.title: When God puts you on hold (2)
content.introtext:
"NOT BY MIGHT NOR BY POWER, BUT BY MY SPIRIT..."

ZECHARIAH 4:6 NIV
Somebody has said that patience is the quality you admire in the driver behind, but not the guy in front! We need to understand this patience principle if we're going to get through life without going nuts. Some things take time, they can't be done '"...by might, nor...power..."' So how are they done? '"...by my spirit..."' David said, 'My times are in Your hands...' (Psalm 31:15 NIV). David understood that nobody can short circuit God's plan for you. Once you realise that, you find peace - and stop trying to 'make things happen.' When God drops a seed into your life it needs time to take root and grow. And you don't have to be worried about the how's and the when's, because when it's planted in a fertile, faith-filled heart, the results are guaranteed. The hard part is knowing that you're on the verge of a breakthrough, then having God tell you to wait. It's when you think He's forgotten you and every second feels like a lifetime, that your patience gets a some serious exercise. David said: 'I waited patiently for the Lord...and...He...set my feet on solid ground and [gave] me...a hymn of praise...' (Psalm 40:1-3 NLT). When you honour God's timing, you always land on solid ground, and end up with a reason to praise Him. So, when you know you've a call from God but He puts you on hold, stay on the line till He gets back to you. It's well worth waiting to get your answer directly from Him. Think about it! Would you dare trust any other answer?

content.title: When God puts you on hold (1)
content.introtext:
...DON'T TRY TO GET OUT OF ANYTHING PREMATURELY...

JAMES 1:4 TM
The Bible says, 'To every thing there is a season...' (Ecclesiastes 3:1 KJV). So no matter how hard you pray, you can't pray your life's seasons away. There are some situations you aren't meant to change - you're just meant to survive! Paul calls these times, '...light and momentary troubles...' (2 Corinthians 4:17 NIV). When you can't change your circumstances you've just got to learn to grow through them. In winter, trees take advantage of the season to rebuild their strength and prepare to be fruitful next season. Their sap and substance goes underground. Then in the spring it pushes its way back up again in the form of new growth. Looking back over your life you'll find that your achievements are seasonal. Growth comes, then struggle, and so on. Each season has its purpose. God has a reason for not wanting you to be productive all the time. When He lets wintry weather to blow through your life He's getting you ready for spring. James writes, 'Consider it a...gift...when tests...come... under pressure, your faith...shows its true colours. So don't try to get out of anything prematurely. Let it do its work so you become mature and well-developed, not deficient in any way.' One of the issues you'll struggle with in a winter waiting time is the urge to hurry, to make big permanent decisions based on circumstances that are about to change. Don't do it! Every situation doesn't need immediate action. Remember, patience comes from trust, and you can't trust a God you don't know. That's why you need to spend more time getting chilling out with Him and reading His instruction manual.

content.title: Intoxicated
content.introtext:
DO NOT GET DRUNK ON WINE...INSTEAD, BE FILLED WITH THE SPIRIT.

EPHESIANS 5:18 NIV
When you're offered an alcoholic drink, you'll very often hear someone say 'go on then, I'll just have one'. It wouldn't be unusual to them see that person at the end of the evening, staggering about, shouting, laughing, crying, singing or even throwing up. So why is that? Isn't it obvious? Alcohol affects your judgement. When you're sober you can decide to 'just have one', but once you had one you've got the taste for it and fancy another 'Oooh, just one more!', before long nothing seems to matter any more! Basically the alcohol controls you. That's why we say you're 'under the influence', because something else is running the show. And what alcohol is to your body negatively, the Holy Spirit is to you positively. When you're under His control, He makes you walk in ways you wouldn't normally walk, and talk in ways you wouldn't normally talk. That's why, rather than spending our time and energy trying to change ourselves, we need to concentrate on being - and staying - filled with God's Spirit. You see, if you're sober you may not do karaoke, but if you're drunk you probably will! So if you want to change something about you but can't or daren't, you get filled with Gods spirit, and then you can! But a word of caution: those under the influence of the Holy Spirit will not be nasty or rude, selfish or showing off trying to impress people. No, the Holy Spirit is a gentleman. The power He provides is a controlled life that you can't get any other way. And that power is available to you today.

content.title: A daily dose of Scripture
content.introtext:
"IT FELT LIKE A FIRE BURNING IN US WHEN JESUS...EXPLAINED THE SCRIPTURES TO US."

LUKE 24:32 NCV
Shortly after Jesus died he appeared to two of his followers on the road to Emmaus. They were totally broken-hearted: '...sadness [was] written across their faces' (Luke 24:17 NLT). In fact they were in so much pain, they didn't even click who Jesus was. He'd risen from the dead, and even though they hadn't realised, He'd come to take their sorrow. And how did He do this? A quick prayer? Did He leap out a tree shouting 'tadaaaa!!!!?' '...Jesus took them through the writings of Moses and all the prophets, explaining from all the Scriptures the things concerning himself' (Luke 24:27 NLT). He talked to them about the Bible! He chose the one thing that never fails - God's Word! Did it make a difference? For those two it did: 'It felt like a fire burning in us when Jesus talked to us on the road and explained the Scriptures to us.' Trying to live a powerful Christian life without a daily dose of the Scriptures is like trying to run your car without petrol, work on an empty stomach, or pay for the cinema with a blockbuster card, it just won't work. Reading the Bible each day reminds us what's true; it's like medication you need each day - a dose of reality. The world is so easy to get caught up in and soon a little problem can seem like an enormous life or death situation. The Bible helps us to keep perspective, to keep our eyes fixed on what's important and not freak out at every little thing. God's got your life in hand, you just need to make sure you never forget that.

content.title: Faith says, 'It is so'
content.introtext:
WITHOUT FAITH IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO PLEASE GOD...

HEBREWS 11:6 NIV
'Faith that pleases God is acting like it's done, even when it's not, just so that it will be; because God said so!' That statement sounds a little bit like it's saying pretend something's real when it's not. But no, it's saying even when there's no evidence for what God said, believe it anyway. So here's a challenge, how do you know whether you believe what God said? Well if you believe, you do it! Maybe you think people like Noah had it easier than we do because God spoke to them directly. True, God did speak to them, but that didn't make their obedience any easier. Remember, Noah worked for years building a boat with no water around him, and kept telling everyone a flood was coming, just because God said! Even though we can see it all worked out ok for guys like Noah, we still experience the turbulence of life. Ever been on an airplane when it started shaking or dipping suddenly without warning? Remember how you felt when the captain spoke over the intercom, calmly explaining that this was no big deal. Your options were to have faith in the captain - or believe what you saw and felt. Depending on your choice, you either white-knuckled the rest of your flight, or relaxed and enjoyed it. Faith takes you beyond the limits of your logic, reason and senses. It lets you believe that if God said it, it's true. Basically, faith is acting as if God is telling the truth.

content.title: Identity theft
content.introtext:
...CHRIST LIVES IN ME...

GALATIANS 2:20 NIV
Your identity is worth loads not only to you, but also to the thief who wants your name and bank details. Loads of us, especially when we're young go to huge lengths to create an identity that a certain group will like. It might be a chav, a mosher, a goth, a townie, a skater look or even a combination of different looks. Your look may include piercing, certain types of designer gear, certain hair styles, mountains of bling weighing you down or even charity shop retro gear. Whatever group you identify best with and want to be most like, chances are it goes deeper than 'you just like that look'. One of the biggest challenges young people face today is that of self image. We don't know who we are and we're not even sure who we're supposed to be! Girls have the extremes of the 'well rounded' Jordan look or the skinny Keira Knightley look. Boys can go for the well groomed Rio Ferdinand style or be an Indie rock star with shaggy hair - and everything in between! But real identity goes much deeper and it can only be found in God. Once you've figured out who He made you to be, your identity is totally secure. You don't have to conform, change, dress or act a certain way. So who are you? You're a totally forgiven, fully accepted, deeply loved, created in His image, beautiful and incredible child of God. Once you fully grasp that, you'll have a satisfaction inside like you've never known before!

content.title: The danger of amnesia
content.introtext:
"...BEWARE THAT IN YOUR PLENTY YOU DO NOT FORGET THE LORD..."

DEUTERONOMY 8:11 NLT
A spider dropped a single strand down from the rafter of an old barn and began to weave her web. Months went by and the web grew. Its elaborate maze caught flies, mosquitoes and other small insects, providing the spider with a delicious feast. Eventually all the others spiders got really jealous of it. Then one day the spider noticed a single strand stretching up into the rafters. 'I wonder why it's there? It doesn't catch me any dinner.' The spider decided it was unnecessary and looked messy and climbed as high as she could to cut it off. In that moment the entire web began to fall in upon itself, tumbling to the floor, taking the spider with it. Do you think it's possible that we sometimes make that same mistake? In a well known song by Matt Redman one line sings 'every blessing you pour out I'll turn back to praise'. It's very easy to pray and thank God for the little when times are tough and we can see Him clearly at work but what about when things get comfy, when life's great and we've all we need and then some? Is it possible that like the spider we can actually make the mistake of forgetting who provided all we have? Do we get so smug and reliant on ourselves that we totally forget the strand that supports us? We're not the first to suffer from amnesia, the whole nation of Israel did it too, and Moses warned them: '"...Beware that in your plenty you do not forget the Lord your God and disobey His commands...I assure you of this: if you ever forget the Lord your God...you will certainly be destroyed"' (Deuteronomy 8:11 & 19 NLT).

content.title: The cure is within you
content.introtext:
"I WILL...PUT A NEW SPIRIT IN YOU..."

EZEKIEL 36:26 NIV
Everyone knows that when a woman becomes pregnant she has cravings she never had before. And when God saves you, He places within you new desires and appetites. This new nature is desperate for fellowship with God; it wants to please Him more than anything. These are intense cravings, which is why, when we sin, we can't enjoy it. Oh, you'll still 'blow it,' but it'll cause an intense struggle in your soul 'cause now you have to try and ignore what you really want. Paul writes: '...Let the Holy Spirit lead you in each step. Then you will not please your sinful old selves.' (Galatians 5:16 NLV). The order is crucial here, because loads of us get it backwards. We think that if we can just stop doing what we want and start doing what God wants, then we can start walking in the Spirit. But it's just the opposite. It's the Holy Spirit doing His bit on the inside that produces spiritual victory on the outside. Everything we need to walk with God and do what He wants - is already within us! If you get a cold and go to the doctor asking for a cure he'll send you away empty-handed; everything you need to fight the virus is already in you. There are no medicines for a cold, the cure lies in your body. Are you looking for strength and grace to obey God and do what's right? It's already right there! Everything you need for victorious Christian living was put in you the day you accepted Jesus. Just tap into it!

content.title: Learning to be still
content.introtext:
BE STILL, AND KNOW THAT I AM GOD...

PSALM 46:10 NIV
A news reporter once found himself unprepared for a television interview with Mother Teresa. It went a bit like this: 'When you pray,' asked the reporter, 'what do you say to God?' 'I don't say anything,' she replied. 'I listen.' He tried another tack. 'Well, okay...when God speaks to you, then, what does He say?' 'He doesn't say anything. He listens.' He looked bewildered. For an instant, he didn't know what to say. 'And if you don't understand that,' Mother Teresa added, 'I can't explain it to you.' Here's a secret, this is how wise people get wise! It's in the place of silence that the Holy Spirit takes the truths in the Bible and suddenly helps us to understand exactly what they mean! Not only that but then he shows them how they fit in with our lives, where we've been going wrong and this changes us. As He transforms our heart to beat in time with His, our decisions are right at the heart of His plan and we begin to reflect His character. Go ahead, try it. Open the Word of God in a peaceful place and sit in quietness before Him. In time, the Holy Spirit will illuminate a passage and it will come to life in your mind. Before you know it the messed up situation that drove you mad will unravel. As you learn to 'be still' in God's presence, your greatest problems will suddenly become more manageable. He will reveal Himself to you. He will calm your emotions and relieve your mind. You'll discover new direction, freedom from worry, and a fresh sense of peace.

content.title: Icebergs
content.introtext:
"EACH TREE IS RECOGNISED BY ITS OWN FRUIT..."

LUKE 6:44 NIV
The Titanic received five iceberg warnings just before it went down. When the 6th message came during the wee hours of the morning: 'Look out for icebergs!' The operator wired back 'Shut-up! I'm busy!' Thirty minutes later the great vessel - whose captain said, 'Even God couldn't sink this ship' - was sinking fast. What happened? They forgot the truth about icebergs. What they saw above the water couldn't have sunk the great ship but unfortunately most of an iceberg is below the water. Do you know what? That iceberg represents your life! The 10% above the water is how people see you and the 90% below is how you really are - your character. And it's what's below the surface that sinks your ship. So what's character? a) self-discipline - being able to do what's right, even when you don't feel like it b) core values - the way you live even when there is pressure to do something else c) sense of identity - a self-image based on who God, not others, says you are d) emotional security - the ability to be emotionally stable and consistent. The impact your life has comes from who you are, not what you have. Jesus said, '"Each tree is recognised by its own fruit...The good man brings good things out of the good stored up in his heart, and the evil man brings evil things out of the evil stored up in his heart..."' (Luke 6:44-45 NIV). Whatever's happening today on the outside of your life comes from what's happening on the inside. God cares about the inside as that affects what you do on the outside. Think about it!
